text: Negative space, in art, is defined as the area that surrounds the subject of an image. Think the black blanket of night cast against the jagged edges of a skyscraper, or the misty blue ocean punctuated by a lone figure in the middle. Negative space allows our eyes to focus on the subject, no matter how subtle it may be. It also allows us to revel in the beauty of simplicity, the artistic equivalent of staring at a cloudless sky. Today we're honoring a group of photographers who know the power of negative space. The following images were contributions to Eyeem's Negative Space Challenge, which dared artists to utilize empty space in radical and inviting ways. To see more contributions from the photo challenge, visit Eyeem’s blog here. By Roj Bagz By Bentom Wyemji By Shio By Fernanda Cruz By Shinnya By XeNcHeN By David By urban poetry By menboong By Andrew Hays By Louie By Adrianna By Victoria Gaetani By Minnie Mun By Sylvia Hoogland By no space art By Silvia By shabab By shinnya by XeCHeN by David by David By Urban Poetry By Menboong by Louie by Louie By Louie by Adriana By Adrana By VictoriaGaetani by Adranna By Minna Mun by Sylvia Hoogsland By SylviaHoogland by Silvia by shabAB By noSpaceArt.

text: Russian Olympic bobsledder Nadezhda Sergeeva appeared in an Instagram video this month. Three days later, she tested positive for a banned substance at the Pyeongchang Winter Games. The video showing Sergeeva wearing a sweatshirt emblazoned with the words, “I don’t do doping. I am ZASPORT,” has since been deleted from Instagram. The clip was reportedly posted to Instagram on Feb. 15 by Russia-based videographer Roman Bibishev. Sergeeva denied taking the drug that triggered the positive result. She finished 12th in the two-woman bobsleigh event in Pyeonchang. The International Olympic Committee banned Russia from the 2018 Winter Games over its state-backed doping program. The IOC said it considered lifting the suspension for Sunday’s closing ceremony so OAR athletes could march under the Russian flag. In the end, the committee decided to keep the ban in place because of the two failed drug tests. It is the second Russian athlete to fail a doping test at thePyeongChang Games. Alexander Krushelnitsky, an Olympic curler, was forced to return his bronze medal last week after testing positive for meldonium, a potential performance-enhancing drug. It's unclear if Sergeeva will be allowed to compete in the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, where the IOC banned Russia over the same doping program, but allowed a group of athletes to compete under the Olympic flag.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Owen Suskind stopped speaking at the age of 3. His non-verbal state, his parents soon learned, stemmed from autism. By versing themselves in the language of Disney, Owen’s parents were able to reacquaint themselves with his inner life, and eventually help him regain his speech. The book has since served as the jumping-off point for a film directed by Academy Award winner Roger Ross Williams, whose documentary “Life, Animated” is up for an Oscar this year. The movie opens at a crossroads: Owen, a young adult, is preparing to live independently. He tells his own story to Williams, explaining his interest in Disney heroes, villains and plots. He also shares his own creative endeavor, a story he wrote called “The Land of Lost Sidekicks,” a world filled with roaming characters who’ve been left behind by their heroic counterparts. In Owen's story, which Williams says is parallel to Owen's life, the sidekicks have to find their inner heroes. “We all need story to survive, but this is about the power of story to transform one life in such a profound way.” Williams emphasized that the message of his film, ultimately, was about the enduring power of storytelling. The year, Williams is one of five black directors nominated for an Academy Award in the Best Documentary Feature category. He says he wants to tell the story of the outsider, and humanize the outsider.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Google is bringing the At a Glance widget to more Pixel smartphones. The redesigned widget was first unearthed in July through an APK deep dive by 9to5. It has a pill-shaped outline and a customizable appearance, allowing you to make it look exactly how you want it. Despite its appearance on more Pixel phones, the new widget is still missing from the Pixel Tablet and Pixel Fold. The rollout seems to be taking place via server-side update, so it's a safe bet that this will change in the future. It should be noted, though, that the redesigned widget still looks different from the fixed launcher version. The widget is available on the Google Pixel 2, Pixel 2 XL, and the Google Nexus 6P, as well as the Motorola Razr Plus and the Galaxy Z Fold 5. It is not yet available for the Galaxy S5, Galaxy S6, or the Galaxy Note 5, but it is expected to be added in the near future. For now, you can enable the widget by tapping on the three-dot icon to pull up the Assistant At A Glance menu.
label: SAFE

text: Jacques Dubochet was one of three scientists to scoop the 2017 Nobel Prize for Chemistry. The professor at the University of Lausanne in Switzerland took a lighthearted approach to his CV. Dubochet detailed how he was “conceived by optimistic parents” in October 1941. The Swedish Royal Academy of Sciences awarded the Nobel Prize, and $1.1 million, to Dubochet, Joachim Frank from New York’s Columbia University and Richard Henderson of MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology in Cambridge, England, for their developments in electron microscopy. His resume has not yet been updated with the accolade, however. The Nobel Prize was awarded on Wednesday, but Dubochet's resume hasn't been updated yet with the award, however, nor has his resume been updated since he was awarded the prize. The prize was awarded for developments in the field of molecular biology and the development of the X-ray spectrometer, which is used to detect DNA in the blood and other bodily fluids. The winner was announced at a ceremony in Oslo, Norway, on Wednesday. The award was handed out by the Swedish Academy of Science and the Royal Society of Chemistry. For more information, go to NobelPrize.org and the Nobel Center for Chemical Research in London. text: Biological dark matter represents newly-discovered microorganisms that have never before been seen. Most of this Earth-based microbial dark matter is usually only found in volcanic lava caves or underground caverns. Astrobiologists are fascinated by the Azores network of volcanoes and their subterranean habitats because they offer clues to how future missions to the Moon and Mars will hunt for microfossils below the surface. Caves on Mars are likely to persist over longer timescales than on Earth. If we can find a cave that's old enough on Mars, is it possible that we might find microf fossil traces of life on Mars? It will require a great deal of analysis to be able to say whether they were once living, says Penelope Boston, a geomicrobiologist and astrobiologist at NASA Ames Research Center. If all goes according to NASA’s current lunar plans, I can imagine that our current robotic program will provide us with an advanced cave bed within the next twenty years.
label: SAFE

text: The future of fossil fuels will be at the heart of COP28 negotiations in Dubai. The world struggles to meet the goal of limiting warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. "The oil and gas industry is facing a moment of truth at COP28 in Dubai," IEA says. Oil and gas use would fall by 75 percent by 2050 if governments successfully pursued the 1. 5C target, the report says. "Producers must choose between contributing to a deepening climate crisis or becoming part of the solution by embracing the shift to clean energy," says IEA Executive Director Fatih Birol. the Paris-based energy watchdog said the industry's engagement has been "minimal" so far, accounting for less than one percent of global clean energy investment. It invested $20 billion in clean energy last year, or just 2.7 percent of its total capital spending, the IEA said. The think tank Carbon Tracker said in September thatOil and gas sector emission reduction pledges have stalled and in some cases gone backwards.

text: Critics fear President-elect Bernardo Arevalo could be blocked from taking office amid a probe into university protests. Human rights advocatesandobservers have warned that the request is the latest attempt to derail AreValo’s presidency. The request to remove Arevalos political immunity comes as part of a larger investigation into the occupation at USAC, which lasted over 380 days. But critics, however, have denounced the whole investigation as an attempt to suppress free speech and dissent in Guatemala. This, after many conservative political parties suppressed dissent in the country in the 1980s and 1990s. In the years prior to its transition to democracy in 1985, dissent had been censored and suppressed under a series of violent dictatorships. But even after democracy was established,activists,journalists, and public figures continued to face intimidation, despite free-speech protections enshrined in the constitution. The case against the university protesters is particularly jarring because of its wide scope, says Claudia Samayoa, a human rights activist.

text: Only 393 of the more than 3,500 titles published in the U.S. in 2014 represented Nonwhites. Only 168 of submitted 2014 titles were written and/or illustrated by a person of color. The lack of diverse children's books has reached a crisis level, says Ellen Riordan, president of the Association for Library Service to Children. Riordan: "The lack of exposure to other cultures fuels intolerance and cultural invisibility. Our hope is that you'll join us is celebrating multiculturalism not only on April 30, but throughout the year as library staff work to put diverse books in the hands of youth""Día! Diversity in Action" is a national literacy initiative that takes place in communities, libraries and schools across the year with annual culminating events held on April30. Last year alone nearly 600 Día! diversity in Action programs were held across the US, according to ALSC data collected by ALSC. The organization is the world's largest dedicated to the support and enhancement of library service to children, with more than 4,000 librarians, literature experts, publishers and educational faculty, ALSC is committed to creating a better future for children through libraries. "Día!" is also known as El día de los niños/El día of los libros (children's day/book day) and aims to promote cultural acceptance and promotion in schools, libraries, communities and throughout the country. The event will explore how to use culturally diverse literature to support families and teen literacy.

text: Gabe Amo is the son of Ghanaian and Liberian immigrants. He succeeds former Democratic Rep. David Cicilline, who stepped down this summer. Amo served in the Obama and Biden administrations, most recently as the deputy director of the White House Office of Intergovernmental Affairs. His win marks an ongoing transition away from the state’s Italian American political hierarchy, which was embodied by the late Vincent “Buddy” Cianci, Providence's charismatic longtime mayor who went to prison for corruption. The last Republican to represent the 1st Congressional District was Ron Machtley, who served from 1989-1995. The race was a close race, with Amo claiming more than 32% of the vote in the September primary, according to a CNN count of absentee ballots. The winner will be sworn in on January 3, the first full day of the 115th Congress, when the new Congress will convene in Washington, D.C., for a lame-duck session.

text: A team of researchers documented fluorescence in cats as well as a slate of 124 other mammalian species. The technical term for this glow is a superpower biofluorescence. Biofluorescence occurs when animals take in ultraviolet light and emit the energy in any number of colors of the electromagnetic spectrum. Some of the biofluorescent mammals included in the research were the bilby, six-banded armadillo, leopard, red fox, dwarf spinner dolphin, polar bear, and the domestic cat. In some animals, like the cat, only some of the creature’s fur appeared to glow. The researchers wanted to know if fluorescence was more typical in nocturnal species than diurnal ones. But they warned nature lovers not to shine a UV light to spot glowing mammals at night. “Remember that UV light can damage their eyesight, and you should take a red light to do your spotlighting instead,” said Kenny Travouillon, the curator of mammalogy, in a museum release.
label: SAFE

text: A gift shop in Hawaii was selling dead baby sharks as souvenirs. The group Ocean Defender called for public complaints and boycotts. Nani Aloha Street Store in Waikiki has capitulated. But the group is still looking to go after the manufacturers of the jars. "We are very very confident that we will stop this sale of bottled baby sharks very soon," the group said on its Facebook page."I was horrified," Ocean Defender's founder, Oriana Kalama, said. "I was infuriated at the fact that they had used our cultural traditions, they had using our aumakua, as a way to make more money" The baby sharks appear to be Atlantic Sharpnose sharks, which are not endangered and not native to Hawaiian waters. It is not clear if the store was violating state laws that prohibit possession of shark fins. "It is completely unnecessary and promotes thoughtlessness and arrogance and stupidity," the Facebook page said of the sale. The store's website now features a letter apologizing to customers and noting that they have stopped selling "the product of issue" But the war isn't over for Ocean Defender. Several Facebook commenters noted that they'd seen the same jars sold in other parts of Hawaii, in California, and on EBay. "In Hawaiian mythology, the shark is believed to be an 'Aumkua, or ancestral guardian who watches over and protects a person and their family," the store's description says. The shark is not endangered or native to Hawaii.
label: SENSITIVE

text: NEW: Georgia Senate Democrats release their own map Wednesday. NEW: The map would pair three sets of Democratic incumbents, meaning Democrats would lose three of those members. A federal judge ordered Georgia to draw Black majorities in the additional districts. The state has pledged to appeal the judge's order, and it could revert to current lines in 2024, if it's not complied with his order.. Georgia lawmakers are in a special session to draw new districts after the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the Voting Rights Act in a ruling last year. The ruling came after a trial in which plaintiffs argued that opportunities for Black voters hadn't increased even though their share of the population rose in the state over the previous decade. The House map would create five more majority-Black districts that Democrats would be likely to win in the next election.. The Senate map would convert two Republican districts held by Sens. Marty Harbin and Brian Strickland of McDonough into majority- black districts. Only one Macon-area district would have a current incumbent, Republican Ken Vance.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Mineralys Therapeutics, Inc. (Nasdaq: MLYS) is a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company focused on developing medicines to target hypertension, chronic kidney disease (CKD) and other diseases driven by abnormally elevated aldosterone. Mineralys presented data from the Target-HTN Phase 2 trial that further defines an endotype-specific targeted approach for treating uncontrolled or resistant hypertension with lorundrostat. The data were presented in a poster at the American Heart Association (AHA) Scientific Sessions 2023, which is being held in Philadelphia from November 11th–13th. New analysis of serum leptin levels among subjects in the trial showed that increased BMI was correlated with increased leptin circulation. This is consistent with emerging evidence of a leptin-driven, positive feedback loop between obesity, ald testosterone and hypertension. The Company’s ongoing pivotal development program for lor Lundrostat to treat uncontrolled orresistant hypertension is currently enrolling subjects.

His message resonated with clarity and urgency: AI mirrors our collective values and decisions. It's a tool, not a tyrant, shaped by our collective will and priorities. At this pivotal moment, our choices in harnessing AI and technology will decisively shape our environmental legacy. text: Stanford University neurobiologist Robert Sapolsky is the latest to weigh in on the question of free will. He says there's simply too much variability at play to think of our behavior as predetermined. Even those who believe biology limits our choices are wary of how openly we should embrace that. But if we want to live in a just society, we have to believe that we can, one author says. "Losing all belief in free will and moral responsibility would likely be catastrophic," says Saul Smilansky, a philosopher at the University of Haifa in Israel. "Those who push the idea that we are nothing but deterministicbiochemical puppetsare responsible for enhancing psychological suffering and hopelessness in this world," says Peter U. Tse, a Dartmouth neuroscientist and author of the 2013 book"The Neural Basis of Free Will" "A person can be both brilliant and utterly wrong," says Tse. "If someone could prove to you that free will was an illusion, how would it affect you and society?" asks Ted Chiang, author of "What's expected of us"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Ecuador's firebrand leftist President Rafael Correa lambasted US oil giant Chevron as an enemy for allegedly besmirching his country. Last year an Ecuadoran court ordered Chevron to pay $19 billion dollars for polluting the rain forest. Correa says the company has spent $400 million and hired an army of hundreds of lawyers to discredit the government and get the ruling overturned on appeal in the country's highest court. Chevron has never worked directly in Ecuador but inherited the pollution lawsuit when it acquired Texaco in 2001. Chevron operated in Ecuador from 1964 to 1990 and after leaving it was sued by indigenous groups in pollution-related legal proceedings that have dragged on for nearly 20 years. The plan to have rich countries pay $3.6 billion into a trust fund for Ecuador in exchange for its not drilling in the Amazon was abandoned this week because so little money had been contributed, Correa said. The case is still alive and Correa is strong on protecting the environment and six years ago came up with a novel plan: have rich nations pay $2 billion into the trust fund in return for Ecuador not drilling for oil in the rainforest. But this week Correa finally abandoned the plan because so much money had not been contributed. It is not clear if Chevron will pay the $2.2 billion in back taxes as promised. The company has not commented on the report. The report is based on interviews with more than 100 people who worked for Chevron in Ecuador over the course of several years.
label: SENSITIVE

text: In 1992, Emily Harvey, a New York gallerist known for her support of the international avant-garde community, conceived of The Cast Iron Court Corporation Group Show. The exhibit was to be held in her SoHo building, 537 Broadway/110 Mercer Street, the last of George Maciunas's 16 Fluxhouses. Four decades after its transformation into an artist coop, on April 11, a version of Harvey's exhibit finally took place in the work of Columbia University Master's candidate Agustin Schang, with the design assistance of Laura Escobar and the deep knowledge of Kevin Harrison, the building's super for 20 years. Although Schang (who is 36) was trained as an architect in his native Buenos Aires, he has never worked in a firm. Instead, he was drawn to cultural events, serving first as a technical coordinator for the Festival Internacional de Teatro de Buenos Aires (FIBA), and later as a member of the production team for the Buenos Aires Festival. By 2013, Schang was restless. He had spent eight years setting up venues for major festivals in Argentina but he knew that "he needed to do something else." Back in New York City, he heard about the new M.S. Program in Critical, Curatorial and Conceptual Practices in Architecture at Columbia University (GSAPP) and was accepted, and he moved, like a mouse in the attic, into a pied-a-terrere.
label: SAFE

text: Los Angeles Clippers guard Chris Paul took umbrage at a reporter who asked if his team could win its next playoff game against the Utah Jazz. Paul, already smarting from the Clippers’ loss at home to the Jazz to give Utah a 3 to 2 lead, went off on the guy in the postgame presser. A sneering and dismissive Paul replied, “What you want me to say? No, it’s over?” Check out the full exchange, posted by Sports Illustrated, below. And pro tip for journalists: Don’t ask athletes if they think they will win. The question should have been rephrased from the get-go, the reporter should have said. The reporter should also have said, "Will the Clippers be back here Sunday playing a Game 7?’ “The question should be, ‘What do you think we’re going to do Sunday?‘” Paul responded. “I’m not sure,” the reporter said. � “We’ll see.” “No,’ Paul replied. ”What do we do Sunday?" “Nothing.’“”“Nothing,“ Paul said, ”because we just played a game, and it was a loss.“ “It’d be a waste of time if we were going to play a game Sunday, and we just lost. ”
label: SENSITIVE

text: French cheesemakers say climate change is affecting their ability to make quality cheeses. Some are experimenting to see how they can produce the same quality product and still meet the traditional rules, despite changes in the environment. Frenchcheese is only the latest beloved food product threatened by climate change, which is makingglobal food systemsmore vulnerable. In Alaska, the snow crab season has been cancelled for the second year in a row after billions of crabs seemingly disappeared. In Georgia, up to 90% of the state's peach crop was lost due to unpredictable weather patterns. In Michigan, iconictart cherries have faced similar problems, and in Alaska, billions of snow crab have disappeared due to a marine heatwave in 2018 and 2019 that increased "their caloric needs considerably," leading to a mass starvation event. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says the collapse was likely due to the heatwave and the increased caloric needs of the crabs, which led to their mass starvation. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is working with cheese associations to address the problem.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with the Prime Minister of Japan, Kishida Fumio, on the margins of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Leaders' Summit in San Francisco, United States of America. The leaders reaffirmed the strength of Canada and Japan's strategic partnership, and the two countries' shared commitment to a free, open, and inclusive Indo-Pacific region. They highlighted growing bilateral trade, investment, and innovation ties, as well as the importance of building resilient supply chains. Prime Minister Trudeau commended Japan's leadership and coordination efforts in upholding the rules-based international order throughout its G7 Presidency. The prime ministers agreed to stay in close contact and looked forward to seeing each other again. They reiterated their unwavering support for Ukraine in the face of Russia's illegal and unjustifiable aggression and discussed next steps in providing assistance. They also highlighted ongoing co-operation in the areas of battery supply chains and industrial science and technology through the implementation of memorandums of co- cooperation signed by Canada and Japanese in September.

text: "Big Tree Madness" has pitted 16 of the country's tallest, biggest trees against one another for the title of "Ultimate Tree" The trees come in all shapes and sizes and can be found in national forests, parks and even backyards. Missouri's "Big Sassy Bassy" (a White Basswood) and Hawaii's "Coco" ( a Coconut Palm) are the final contenders. Vote now at American Forests Facebook page (the winner will be announced on April 9th) and decide which tree you'd rather hug. The contest is a tight one. At 103 feet tall, its circumference is the equivalent of half a football field. At 112 feet tall and with a 13.5" circumference, the Coconut Palm looks to be the early favorite. With more than 68,000 Facebook likes, they seem to be succeeding with their Facebook campaign, which has been around since 1940. The winner is set to be announced April 9, and the winner is expected to be revealed on April 10th, according to a spokesperson for the nonprofit Americanforests. The organization works to promote "the importance of planting and caring for trees and forests" with a "Big Tree" program that's been around for a while. The competition is sponsored by the nonprofit conservation organization, AmericanForests, and is open to the general public. It's also open to businesses and non-profit organizations that want to raise awareness about the importance of trees and forest care. The prize is $1,000.
label: SAFE

text: In 2022, global average concentrations of carbon dioxide were a full 50% above the pre-industrial era for the first time. Methane concentrations in the atmosphere also increased, and levels of nitrous oxide, another greenhouse gas, saw the highest year-on-year increase on record between 2021 and 2022. The warning comes weeks before world leaders are due to gather in Dubai for the annual U.N. climate conference COP28. A separate UN report published on Tuesday said that governments were making insufficient progress in slashing greenhouse gas emissions to avert the worst impacts of global warming. The Indian economy likely expected 6.7% in the July-September quarter, according to a median forecast of 10 economists polled by ET, boosted by a strong performance by the services sector. Telecom operators, chip makers, network providers and handset makers have strongly opposed any hurried decision on a proposed idea to beam TV content directly to mobile phones without a cellular data connection. text: The number of international students in the U.S. grew by 12% in the 2022-23 academic year. More than 1 million students came from abroad, the most since the 2019-20 school year. The surge nearly brings international numbers back to their pre-pandemic highs. China still accounted for the most foreign students with 290,000, but its numbers decreased for a third consecutive year."The United States. remains the destination of choice for international students wishing to study abroad, as it has been for more than a century," says Institute of International Education CEO Allan E. Goodman, CEO of the Institute of international Education.. The rebound appears to be continuing, with an 8% increase in international enrollment this fall, according to a smaller survey meant to give a snapshot of recent trends, the State Department says. The study finds that math and computer science programs attracted more students than any other subject and saw a 20% boost in enrollment over the previous year. It reverses a trend from the previous decade, which saw undergraduates come in larger numbers.
label: SAFE

text: Gujarat was hit by heavy rainfall accompanied by thunderstorms and hailstorms on Sunday and Monday. Some places received up to 144mm (5.7 inches) of rain in the 24 hours ending Monday morning. The rains caused damage to houses and loss of cattle across the state. At least 40 animals were also killed in the rain-related incidents in the western Indian state, government officials say. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast rainfall to continue in parts of the state on Monday. The state is not unfamiliar with rain- related calamities, but such big rainstorms are not expected in the state during winter months, and fierce downpours caught many off guard, they say. In August 2020, 14 people died in theState over just two days in various incidents related to heavy rains and flooding. A year previously, in August 2019, 31 people died  in the State in rain-based incidents, according to state government data, and scientists warn that rising global temperatures are unleashing extreme weather events.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Beatles returned to the top of global music charts with the record-breaking track ‘Now and Then’ ‘Beatlemania has returned this week,’ Official Charts Company Chief Executive Officer Martin Talbot said. Billed as the last Beatles song, ‘ now and then’ features the voice of the late John Lennon. It also features parts recorded by surviving members Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr as well as the late George Harrison. The song is addictive, the video is just as good. You will cry. It’s almost likeSachin Tendulkarcoming back at 80 and hitting a masterful century against the best bowling attack of the world, in a packed stadium, or Pele coming back after 50 years and winning the FIFA World Cup. If this were to happen, we all would stand up and bow our heads in reverence. The Beatles is not just about music. It is and was about bonds — friendships, love, yearning, hope. It was about telling stories in a way that made the group the soundtrack of our lives.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Sampha Lahai Sisay's music is known for its sheer vulnerability in tackling the human experience. On his debut album,Process, we met a son mourning the loss of his parents while navigating the relationship with his partner and future mother of his first child. On a transcendental follow up,LAHAI,we now meet Sampha as a father and a companion, asking us to revel in the magic of our existence. In this Tiny Desk concert, Sampha performs three songs fromLAHAi — "Spirit 2.0," "Only" and "Dancing Circles" — expertly rearranging each to sound exactly like its recorded version. Concluding the set with "Without," Sampha and his band gather in a drum circle, creating a cacophony of percussive rhythms, building the song from the bottom up. The performance ends with Sampha singing solo at the piano, except this time with his Partner and children sitting criss-cross applesauce in front of the Desk.

text: Residents of Paradise, California, have received annual premiums that near or exceed $10,000. Seven of the 12 top home-insurers in California have paused or restricted new business. California's Insurance Commissioner Ricardo Lara is trying to reform the system. The wildfire that ripped through Paradise and surrounding areas, killing 85, sounded an alarm to national home insurers about the costs of wildfires fueled by climate change."I gotta have money to buy food ... and pay taxes," says a retired drywall contractor who has lived in the same house since 1979. "I guess I’d rather do that and have a place to live, unless it burns down," he says of forgoing insurance. "It’s a beautiful home, but it really makes you think about staying in the state,” says Gene Robinson, 61, a retiree who lives in the town with his wife and their two children. "This is so crazy to me. How is this the biggest thing we’re dealing with?"

text: Community groups sued Clark County to force it to deal with dirty stormwater pollution. Stormwater pollution is the leading cause of murky, unhealthy rivers in Washington State. Clark County agreed to comply with the Clean Water Act and pay a penalty of $3 million to an independent board dedicated to salmon recovery. This stands out as one of the largest penalties in a Cleanwater Act citizen suit in Washington state history. The settlement was reached in a high rise in Seattle on December 17, 2013. It was a resounding victory for communities that rely on eating healthy Columbia River fish and swimming in clean water, says Columbia Riverkeeper's Mark Riskadahl. The County saw the light and realized that redemption (in form of complying with the law and restoring rivers) was the answer. This holiday season share the story of Clark County with your friends and family on CNN iReport and CNN.com/Heroes of the Year: Share your stories of triumph and redemption with CNN iReporters on Twitter and @cnnireport and @CNNOpinion. text: A number of extraordinary buildings met their untimely demise, making way for the city we know today. The original McKim, Mead, and White–designed Penn Station, erected in 1910, was demolished in 1963 to an outcry of public criticism. The Waldorf-Astoria hotel occupied two separate German Renaissance structures on Manhattan’s Fifth Avenue that were owned by two feuding Astor relatives. Upon its demolition in 1966, the Singer tower was the tallest edifice to be intentionally destroyed.. The Hippodrome was the brainchild of Coney Island developers Frederic Thompson and Elmer Dundy. The Biltmore hotel opened in 1913 as part of the Terminal City Development, which also included the Roosevelt Hotel (still in operation today) and the Commodore Hotel. The New York Tribune Building was built in 1875 by architect Richard Morris Hunt. The brick-and-stone building, famous for its protruding clock tower, was razed in 1966. The Victory Arch stood just north of the Flatiron Building at the intersection of 24th Street and 5th Avenue, whose original structure still stands today. In 1981, the building was stripped to its skeleton in 1981 and rebuilt as Bank of America Plaza. The Brokaw mansion was the centerpiece of a collection of nearby homes owned by wealthy textile merchant Isaac Vailbrokaw. The home was demolished by the city in 1966 to a scathing New York Times editorial titled “Rape of the Brokaws Mansion”
label: SENSITIVE

text: Laura Nuttall was diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme at the age of 19. She was given just a year to live and made headlines after ticking off a bucket list of ambitions before her death in May. Her sister Gracie put together a video to raise awareness of brain cancer among young people. The video has gone viral with more than 12 million views in little over 24 hours. Gracie said she was "shocked" at how the video had exploded since she posted it on Tuesday. The girls' mother said she is writing a book in her daughter's memory. Mrs Nuttall, who is continuing Laura's campaign work, will also soon officially launch the Be More Laura Foundation. She said Laura herself would have been moved by it and it was a good way of getting the message out about brain cancer. "I said in the caption I was sharing this because Laura will haunt me if I don't keep shouting about this awful disease which she would have found funny," she said.

text: Oceans Futures is a first-of-its-kind initiative that projects seascapes surrounding the Arctic Ocean and within the Gulf of Guinea, Eastern Mediterranean, Eastern Tropical Pacific, and Central Pacific. The analysis, based on global climate and fisheries models, highlights 20 regions of the world that will likely see conflict, food insecurity, or geo-political tensions over fisheries rise by 2030. The early warning enables the international community to take bold, collaborative action on conservation and conflict prevention. “We have a unique opportunity to predict and prevent future fish wars that will have devastating impacts on people and nature,” said Johan Bergenas, Senior Vice President for Oceans at World Wildlife Fund-US. ‘Climate change and national security are irrevocably linked; this has never been clearer than with depleting fish stocks around the globe due to illegal fishing and overfishing,’ said Sherri Goodman, Secretary General, International Military Council on Climate & Security and Senior Fellow, Woodrow Wilson International Center.

text: $2.4 million in grants to restore, improve and conserve sagebrush, mesic wet meadow and big game migratory corridor habitats in Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, Utah and Wyoming. The grants will generate $3.7 million in matching contributions for a total conservation impact of $6.1 million. Today’s grants were awarded through theRocky Mountain Rangelands Program, a partnership including NFWF, Capri, Cargill, Nestlé, Taco Bell, the USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. The projects supported by the eight grants announced today address program priorities, including: 1) improving management and restoration of sagebrush rangelands to benefit sagebrush-obligate and other associated species; 2) securing important ungulate migrations across the landscape with specific focus on transportation conflicts, winter range and stopover sites; and 3) restoring habitat and expanding occupancy of wetland birds and native fish.
label: SAFE

text: New international research led by the University of St Andrews reveals historical high latitude volcanic eruptions caused dramatic, but short-lived climate cooling. Researchers studied sulfur isotopes in ice cores from Greenland and Antarctica. The isotopes provided a fingerprint of the fraction of the sulfate that reached the stratosphere. The results also show that the amount of sulfate injected into the. stratosphere by these eruption events may have been around half that previously estimated, suggesting. that summer temperatures may be highly sensitive to high latitude. volcanic eruption. The sensitivity of temperature to high-latitude eruptions highlights the role of climate feedbacks, such as sea ice extent and ocean heat content, in amplifying changes in global climate. "High latitudes feel these amplified climate changes particularly strongly, which is concerning given how rapidly these regions are changing today," said Dr. Burke. The paper is titled "High sensitivity ofsummer temperaturesto stratospheric sulfur loading from volcanoes in the Northern Hemisphere" and published in theProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS)
label: SENSITIVE

text: NASA and SpaceX have called off Thursday’s launch of the Psyche asteroid mission. Officials blamed the delayon poor weather conditionsat the Kennedy Space Center launch site in Florida. The postponement didn’t come as a big surprise as NASA had said a day earlier that the weather outlook for Thursday suggested there was only a 20% chance of acceptable weather conditions for launch. Live launch coverage will start at 9:15 a.m. ET on various NASA channels, includingYouTubeandNASA Live. The Psyche mission is the first to explore an asteroid with a surface that scientists believe holds large amounts of metal rather than the usual rock and ice. The spacecraft will travel around 2.2 billion miles to a point between Mars and Jupiter in a journey to the asteroid that will take about six years. When it has the celestial body in its sights, the spacecraft will deploy an array of science instruments to examine the 170-mile-wide asteroid in the hope of gaining insight into the early stages of the solar system.
label: SAFE

text: OpenAI’s ChatGPT has extended the availability of its new voice feature to all free users. Users can tap the headset icon in the mobile application to interact verbally with the artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot. The voice interaction feature was introduced in September but had been restricted to paid subscribers. The OpenAI-Sam Altman saga last Saturday, OpenAI's board abruptly dismissed Altman via a video call citing that he was not ‘consistently candid’ in his communications with the board. Subsequently, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella roped in Altman and former OpenAI president Greg Brockman, who had quit to protest Altman's ouster, to lead a new advanced AI research team. The company collaborated with professional voice actors to create each voice and used Whisper, its open-source speech recognition system, to transcribe spoken words into text. In the video on X, ChatG PT showcased a person inquiring, “It's been a long night for the team, and we’re hungry. How many 16-inch pizzas should I order for 778 people?” The slightly tongue-in-cheek message alludes to the internal turmoil at OpenAI, which has a similar number of employees.

text: Banksy offered to send free prints to Brits who didn't vote for Conservative Party. He said he would send them the prints if they sent him a photo of their ballot paper. Local police confirmed in an issued statement that they were “investigating the offer.” It is a criminal offense under the Representation of People Act 1983 for any voter to accept or agree to accept a gift or similar in return for voting or refraining from voting, the police said. The artist announced late Monday that he would scrap the giveaway in light of the police investigation and a warning from the U.K. Electoral Commission. The Electoral Commission has also issued a warning against people against taking selfies in polling stations. The U.S. has strict electoral coverage guidelines and the Electoral commission has also warned against people taking selfies at polling stations in order to ensure the integrity of the election. The election will be held on Thursday, June 7, with the result to be announced on June 14. The winner will be the winner of the right to be a member of the British Parliament for the next five years, the Electoral Commission said in a statement on Monday. The current parliament is expected to be re-elected on June 21, the commission said. It is the first time the Conservative Party has lost the majority of seats in a general election since the 1970s, it added. The Conservative Party won a majority of votes in the general election in 2010, but lost the seat of the European Parliament in 2012.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Scientists say it's essential to understand the biology behind some of these toxic interactions. Becoming aware of our ingrained impulses can help us learn to diffuse combustible situations. Nelson Mandela and U.S. Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm have changed history. Conflict deepens and escalates quickly, Tim Phillips says, when we feel it threatening things we hold dearest —our sacred values — our social identity, or our people. When fanned or exploited, such sentiments can override our sense of morality, and morph into hate anddehumanization, which make atrocities possible, he says.. Phillips says it means saying to your opponent, for example: "I understand how important this is important to you; I understand this is core to your identity and your community, I respect your opponent's humanity back to them" It's effective to reduce toxic polarization because in the heat of the argument, people tend to demonize one another. So, Phillips says people emotionally disarm in a disagreement by recognizing their humanity.
label: SENSITIVE

Sports medicine experts say the 4- 6 weeks timeline is reasonable for this type of injury. The Lions are currently in the middle of a three-game winning streak. Department of Health and Human Services) The investigation into the case is continuing and there is no indication of any further action to be taken against the athlete, who has been suspended from the sport for two years. The USADA is investigating the case and no further action has been taken by the D.C., Department of health and human Services (DHHS) or the US Tennis Association (TSA) The case has been referred to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) for further action. IOC: The investigation of Sarah Chen is ongoing, and no action is being taken against Ms. Chen, who is currently on leave from the T.I.A. and the USTSA has no further comment on the case. text: Scientists have made a list of Earth's most "irreplaceable" places. More than 2,300 unique habitats are key to the survival of rare wildlife. Study offers an irreplaceability score for 2,178 protected areas and 192 proposed sites. Many of the places already have UNESCO World Heritage protection, but half of the total land they cover does not."These exceptional places would all be strong candidates for World Heritage status," says lead author Soizic Le Saout. "Such recognition would ensure effective protection of the unique biodiversity in these areas," he says. "Given limited conservation budgets, that is not always the case, so governments should pay particular attention to the management effectiveness of highly irreplaceable protected areas," says the study's lead author, Simon Stuart of the International Union for Conservation of Nature's Species Survival Commission."Protected areas can only fulfill their role in reducing biodiversity loss if they are effectively managed," says Simon Stuart, chair of the IUCN's species Survival Commission, in a press release about the study. "The most irreplaceables site on Earth for threatened species" is Colombia's Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta Natural National Park, according to the study, which is home to more than 600 species of bird, amphibian and mammal, half of which are threatened. "These exceptional Places would all are strong candidates to be World Heritage Status," says study's author, who says they would be "given the rigorous standards required" of World Heritage recognition.
label: SAFE

text: A Falcon 9 with an uncrewed cargo Dragon on the CRS-29 mission blasted off at 8:28 p.m. Eastern time from Kennedy Space Center's Launch Pad 39-A. It was the second flight for the rocket's first-stage booster having back in August launched Crew-7, the crew of which are still on the ISS. Its recovery landing came not at seas, but back at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station Landing Zone 1, bringing the signature double sonic boom across parts of the Space Coast and Central Florida. Among the 6,500 pounds of science and supplies headed to the International Space Station are major experiments to pave the way for deep-space communications NASA will need for its future crewed missions to Mars.Dragon will spend about one month attached to the ISS before returning with about 3,800 pounds of cargo with a splashdown landing off the coast of Florida. It's slated to arrive around 5:20 a.m., Saturday docking autonomously to the space-facing port of the ISS Harmony module.
label: SAFE

text: The song has topped the charts in the UK, making the band the act with the longest ever gap between their first and last number ones. SirPaul McCartneytold the BBC: “It’s blown my socks off!” And the BBC reports that the tune is also this century's fastest selling single on vinyl. The song emerged from a demo written byJohn Lennonback in 1978, two years before his murder in New York. His widow Yoko Ono later gave the tape to McCartney, but audio technology wasn’t adequate then to separate Lennon”s voice from the background noise, so the song was discarded from the surviving Beatles’ 1990s collaboration. Following the success of Peter Jackson's documentary about the Fab FourGet Back, McCartney picked the project up again. McCartney recorded additional vocals, Starr added drums and the guitar sounds ofGeorge Harrison, who died in 2001, were also added, making it an authentic Beatles song with all four contributing. While it has been billed as the very last Beatles song, Peter Jackson gave a titillating hint that there could be more music in the vault.
label: SENSITIVE

text: More than 21 firefighters are battling the flames, supported by air tankers dropping fire retardant. Weather forecasters predict shifting winds that could help containment efforts in the coming days. The Red Cross has opened cooling centers for evacuees, and local veterinary clinics are providing temporary shelter for pets. The fire has burned more than 1,000 acres in Northern California, and is threatening more than 2,000 homes. It is the largest fire in the state's history, and the largest in the Santa Barbara County area, which is home to more than 8,000 people. The blaze has been burning since Monday, and authorities have ordered mandatory evacuations in parts of the town of Redding, north of San Francisco. The cause of the fire has not been determined, but authorities are concerned about the spread of the blaze, which has burned at least 1,500 acres. The U.S. National Guard has been called in to help with firefighting efforts, and has been dispatched to the area. It's not clear if the fire will be contained by the end of the week, though forecasters say it could be contained in the next two days or so. The wildfire is burning in the Mendocino National Forest, which includes Redding and parts of Lake Tahoe. The National Weather Service has issued a red flag warning for the area, warning that winds could gust as high as 50 mph could cause the fire to spread. It has also been reported in the San Francisco Bay area.
label: SENSITIVE

text: All The Only Onesis unearths the little known and often neglected history of trans youth in America. For $125 the federal government will sell you a wild horse. Bright Lit Place heads into the swamp to meet its first inhabitants, the scientists who study it and the warring sides struggling to find a way out of the muck. For Beginnersis an audio guide to the Marfa you may not know: where you can feel a stranger in your own hometown while also feeling like anyone else ... ... or anyone else at all. The Broadside asks why it matters to explore the nuances of our American home — and asks why we deserve a closer look at how we make our own home our home.. The NPR Oneteam is here to help with podcast recommendations from across public media. The podcast episode descriptions below are from podcast webpages and have been edited for brevity and clarity. text: Betsy DeVos donated the maximum allowable political contributions to Michigan Senate candidate Mike Rogers. Rogers, a former congressman, is running to succeed Democratic Sen. Debbie Stabenow. The Federal Election Commission allows individuals to contribute up to $3,300 per election, an increase from the $2,900 that was permitted during the 2022 election cycle. Rogers received the maximum contributions from Betsy DeVos' husband, former Amway chief executive Richard "Dick" DeVos Jr. The contributions from DeVos family members totaled $46,200, which represented roughly 6.97% of the total itemized contributions that Rogers received in the third quarter of 2023. The Democratic candidates currently in the Senate race include three-term Rep. Elissa Slotkin, actor Hill Harper, businessman Nasser Beydoun, former state Rep. Leslie Love, Michigan State Board of Education president Pamela Pugh, and attorney Zack Burns. The GOP lost their majorities in both houses of the state legislature last year, with GOP nominee Tudor Dixon losing to Democratic Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.

text: Switzerland is bidding for the 2030 or 2034 Winter Games. The country's officials had pledged to keep thegames' budgetto 1.5 billion Swiss francs, or $1.8 billion. If Switzerland manages to stick to the budget, it will be the cheapest Winter Olympics ever. The last edition of the Winter Olympics in Beijing had an official price tag of $3.9 billion. The 2018 Winter Gamesin Pyeongchang, South Korea, cost about $15 billion. It takes a massive investment to host the Olympics, and the host population often reapsfew financial benefitsfrom the event. In fact, Swiss citizens have already rejected at least three previous bids for the Winter Games in recent years.. Even though the International Olympic Committee is based in Switzerland, it has never hosted the Summer Games. It has hosted the Winter games twice — in 1928 and 1948. It is one of the world's richest countries and has a population of about 1.2 million people.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Ladykiller was released theatrically even when “30 pages of the 117 page screenplay were never shot” The rise of the OTT market has resulted in a section of the producers becoming complacent, knowing that a certain chunk of money will come irrespective of what happens at the box office. Bollywood films post the re-opening of cinema halls have been operating with an8-week window for OTT— which means a Hindi film can only be available for streaming after it has completed 8 weeks of its theatrical release. According to a trade source, some Hindi film producers today have blindly started to operate on “the lowest of risk” as a bulk of their money is pocketed through OTT, satellite and music rights. If a film is delayed and the makers miss the date, then there is a catch. The OTT players are now wishing that some of these films do get delayed so that they can back out of the deal and save some money and save time.

The Davis Museum at Wellesley College in Massachusetts has announced that it will be de-installing or shrouding all artwork by immigrants, as well as any art given to the museum by immigrants. Police responding to the scene reported signs of intoxication. No serious injuries were reported, but Hassan faces criminal charges. The Panthers released a statement saying they take the matter seriously. Hassan could face league suspension in addition to legal consequences, according to reports. The incident occurred in the early hours of the morning in the city of Charlotte, North Carolina, near the city's downtown sports arena, the Panthers say. The team says it is investigating the incident and will make a further announcement when it has more information to share. The game between the Panthers and the Carolina Panthers is scheduled for Sunday, September 14. The match will be played in Charlotte at the Panthers' home field, Bank of America Stadium, in front of a crowd of more than 20,000 fans, including several members of the team's coaching staff and fans from other professional teams, including the New York Knicks and New York Rangers. text: The Russia-Ukraine conflict, geopolitical tension in the Middle East, and rising interest rates have negatively affected financial markets. As October’s harsh investment climate subsides, investors should prepare for possible additional volatility in November. The U.S. stock market indices rallied nearly 2% intraday amid positive quarterly financial results and expectations that the Federal Reserve has concluded its interest rate hike campaign. The S&P 500 rallied by 79.92 points or 1.89%, reaching 4,317.78. The Fed kept the interest rates steady within the 5.25%-5.50% range, as predicted. Chair Jerome Powell has not ruled out further monetary tightening measures. Depending on inflation trends, there is potential for interest rate cuts to be introduced during the second quarter of 2024 or in subsequent months. If the Fed manages to usher the economy towards a “soft landing,” implementing rate cuts while skirting a recession, this could potentially trigger a stock rally. However, should economic growth maintain its current momentum and inflation revive in the ensuing months, investors could face an unforeseen disenchantment.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Pikas living in rockslides near sea level in Oregon survive hot temperatures by eating more moss than any other mammal. Researchers observed 220 hours of pika behavior and were surprised to find that the animals were eating so much moss. Pikas are very sensitive to heat, and the tiny critters can die if they spend more than two hours above 78 degrees Fahrenheit. Living at a lower elevation with warmer temperatures gives the animals access to what the biologists describe as a "year-round salad bar""Mosses are 80 percent fiber. It's a bit like eating paper," said Denise Dearing, senior author of the study. "To our knowledge, this study represents the highest degree of voluntary moss consumption reported for a mammalian herbivore in the wild," said Jo Varner, a biology doctoral student at the University of Utah. "Few herbivores consume moss because it's so nutritionally deficient. The pikas in our study actually set a new record for moss in a mammal's diet: 60 percent," said Dearing. "Some fiber is good, but this is almost all fiber," said the study's senior author. "It's the bit of paper that you eat when you're trying to survive in the winter," Dearing said of the moss-eating pik as a source of fiber for the animals. The study was published in the February 2014 issue of the Journal of Mammalogy, which is published by the American Museum of Natural History and Science.
label: SAFE

text: Institutional investors have around twenty trillion assets under management. Traditional investments are typically liquid so when selloffs occur due to fear, values will fall no matter the intrinsic strength of the assets. Alternative investments are different. Often illiquid to some extent, institutions are finding safe haven in the place where behavior from other investors doesn’t burn the wallet. Private Equity is equity not on public exchanges the way corporation’s stocks are. With investments in private credit, an investor can hedge against a cooling real estate market, as well the public credit markets all in one go. The Macro of it is that the Federal Reserve will keep rates as is, but of course they will eventually need to be lowered. The Federal Reserve has shown the power of the market and the influence they have over economic behavior can see them drop or at least keep them at least at least static for at least a few years. This doesn't even take into account predictions for more opportunistic real estate ventures and something we reviewed in a previous article.
label: SAFE

text: The New England Patriots visited the White House on Wednesday to celebrate their Super Bowl win alongside President Donald Trump. The team's full roster includes 68 players, which means half of the squad skipped the celebration. The New York Times pointed out the stark difference between photographs of the event this year, and those from 2015, the last time the Patriots won the Super Bowl. The Patriots strongly refuted a Times tweet showing the 2015 and 2017 photographs, saying the comparisons “lack context.” The Times’ sports editor Jason Stallman apologized for the paper’s tweet, which he called “terrible” ”Only during the Trump presidency does the media care ... this much about who doesn’t attend,” Patriots spokesman Stacey James told HuffPost. Wednesday was the fifth time the team has gone to the White house, James said, and the number of players attending has ranged from about 27 to 50. Trump responded to the controversy on Thursday with a jab at the Times, which has been calling me wrong for two years, just got caught in a lie, and just got in a big lie about the Patriots visit to W.H., which has just got bigger than I ever thought it would be. He called the Patriots “the greatest Super Bowl comeback of all time,’’ and said he was “thrilled’ to be with them’ The president also called out several players by name, including wide receiver Danny Amendola, who later thanked the president for the “shout out”
label: SENSITIVE

text: Forests where they occur naturally could capture 226 gigatons of planet-warming carbon. That's about one-third of the amount that humans have released since the beginning of the Industrial Era. But major caveats remain: If we protect all current forests, where will people get timber, rubber and palm oil? Would forests be able to store carbon quickly enough? And how much forest carbon would be lost to fire, drought and pests as climate change intensifies? The study’s senior author is Thomas Crowther, the senior author of a polarizing study on forest carbon in 2019. It drew scientific backlash but also inspired an effort by the World Economic Forum to grow and conserve 1 trillion trees. The new conclusions were similar to those in a separate study published last year, but the new study gets there very differently, Crowther says. It excludes urban areas, croplands and pastures, but includes rangelands, where animals may graze at lower densities. The study is published in the journal Nature.
label: SENSITIVE

text: All the candidates can agree that the climate is changing and that extreme weather disasters are a problem. But not all are on the same page about humans being the driving force. The two candidates most upfront about climate change, Haley and Christie, primarily want to confront other countries like China and India about their role in reducing emissions. None of the GOP candidates offered plans to cut planet heating emissions–what scientists say is the lynchpin to preventing global temperature increases. The issue is not a driving force at the macro level of American elections. But it's an issue that is top of mind for young votersacross party affiliations. People of color, who are often most affected by the impacts of climate change,. and women also consistently say the issue should be a priority. The U.S. is by far thelargest historical contributorto climate change. Still, many within the GOP seeany acknowledgment by their presidential candidates as progress in a partythat, for the last decade, has dug deeper into rejecting widely accepted science about the warming planet.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A flock of tree swallows enveloped the dusk sky overhead, swooping and swarming in unison. The iridescent blue-feathered birds with white bellies roost on Goose Island every year during the late summer and early fall months. As many as 300,000 birds flock at a time and can settle in under two minutes -- a spectacle that often causes the Connecticut Audubon Society's annual boat tours to sell out. The birds are abundant across their field and wetland breeding grounds in North America and form massive flocks for migrating, molting and roosting. They can be found in the wild across the U.S. and around the world, including Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Australia and the United Arab Emirates, where they are also known as "nestlings" and "nesting birds" The birds can also be seen in their natural habitat of the Great Lakes region of North America, such as the United States, Canada, and the Caribbean, which is home to more than 100 million of them. The Connecticut River is a popular destination for bird watchers, especially during the summer and fall months, when the birds migrate and molt. For more information on the Connecticut River, go to www.ctgov.org/ct river and look for the "Connecticut River Boat Tour" for information on how to get there and how to watch the river at the same time. The tour also offers a guided tour of Goose Island, where the birds roost.
label: SAFE

Brown hopes the memoir will help reduce stigma and encourage others to seek help. Mental health advocates praise the honest portrayal of the author's experiences. The memoir includes resources for readers who may be struggling. Joshua Brown is partnering with mental health organizations for educational discussions. text: The company that owns the tank that leaked thousands of gallons of hazardous chemicals should have known that there was the potential for an incident. Freedom Industries told state officials nearly a year ago that it was keeping thousands of pounds of 4-methylcyclohexane methanol in the company's storage facility. The disclosure was included in paperwork that Freedom Industries had filed under the federal Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act. Despite the storage facility's proximity to the water supply, it does not appear that the company, state or local officials had any emergency response plan in place. If you're a West Virginian whose water supply has been affected, we want to hear from you. What impact has the chemical spill had on you? How are you coping without using tap water? How well do you feel the situation has been handled? Email us here with your stories, photographs, or anything else you want to share. Please include your name, and a phone number if you're willing to speak with a reporter. The state Department of Environmental Protection had not inspected the Freedom Industries site in more than 20 years. West Virginia American Water President Jeff McIntyre told reporters on Friday that his company didn't know much about the chemical's possible dangers, wasn't aware of an effective treatment process, and wasn't even sure exactly how much 4- methylcyclo hexanemethanol is too much. The chemical is used to wash coal after it is mined from the ground. It's unclear how much of the chemical is in the Elk River water supply.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The 15th annual Mirchi Music Awards celebrated the finest talents in the Bollywood music industry. The prestigious awards ceremony witnessed Ranbir Kapoor’s fantasy film ‘Brahmastra’ achieving a remarkable clean sweep. ‘Laal Singh Chaddha’ earned the coveted title of Album of the Year. The event also recognised Kishore Sharma with the Outstanding Contribution - Special Jury Award. The Golden Era Album of The Year 1962 went to "Anpadh" and "Sahib Bibi Aur Ghulam." The Song Producer - Programming & Arranging award was presented to Himonshu Parikh and DJ Phukan for the same song. The Upcoming Artist awards featured emerging talents: Hardik Bhardwaj for "Meri Sazaa" from "Vadh" and Sireesha Bhagavatula for "Ghodey Pe Sawar" from “Qala’. The Song Engineer - Recording & Mixing accolade was shared by Aaroh Velankar, Aniruddh Anantha, Ashwin Kulkarni, Harjot Kaur, Himanshu Shirlekar, Pranav Gupta, Sukanto Singha, and Shadab Rayeen.

text: Linac Coherent Light Source, the world's brightest X-ray laser, is undergoing a major upgrade. Construction is underway at Stanford University to build an even brighter laser that will work in parallel with the existing LCLS. The $1 billion project is described in a stunning new video that was posted to YouTube on Monday. It will include a superconducting accelerator to propel electrons through a series of cavities, resulting in an almost continuous laser beam with pulses that are 10,000 times brighter, on average, than those of the existing laser. The new laser is scheduled to begin operations in the early 2020s, while the existing one will continue to operate for the next few years. a six-month recess scheduled in 2017 for construction, and a yearlong shutdown extending from 2018 into 2019, is scheduled for the project's completion in 2019. In the meantime, the existing Laser will continue operating, except for a year-long recess scheduled for 2017 and 2018, according to the lab's website. The laser can generate beams of extremely bright X-rays by using the energy of electrons accelerated to nearly the speed of light. It is capable of creating up to 1 millionX-ray flashes per second. It uses a copper accelerator that operates at room temperature and allows for the generation of 120 X-Ray pulses per second, meanwhile, LclS uses a room temperature accelerator that allows for an average of 120 pulses a second. The project is expected to be completed by the late 2020s.
label: SAFE

text: Investors pull about $956 million from crypto exchange Binance over the past 24 hours, market data showed. Binance chief Changpeng Zhao stepped down and faced prison time after pleading guilty on Tuesday to settle a years-long U.S. illicit finance probe. Zhao has been replaced by Richard Teng, a senior Binance executive who joined in 2021, the company said. It remained unclear on Wednesday how much jail time, if any, Zhao would ultimately serve, and how much influence he - as Binance's founder and major shareholder - could continue to exert on Binance under the terms of the settlement. Some analysts also noted that the deal was unlikely to end the exchange's legal woes, with Securities and Exchange Commission charges alleging Binance broke securities laws still unresolved. The deal raises questions over the future of the world's largest crypto exchange and marks another blow for an industry beset by scandals, experts say.. The company has worked hard to make Binance "safer and even more secure," Binance said on Tuesday.

There are people I don’t show that side of me.“Producers are always in the background. But for a long time, I have always tried to make my efforts to put myself out there. I grant interviews and create contents. The platform of this reality show on MTV Base is a wonderful plus,” he said. Rexxie added that fans would learn new things about him from watching the show. Though many producers were transitioning to singers, Rexie admitted that he wasn't sure if he had the confidence to sing yet.

text: India's wheat planting is expected to remain stagnant despite a rally in prices to near record highs. Lower soil moisture prompts farmers in some areas to switch to less water-intensive crops. Limited planting area, along with the threat of higher-than-normal first-quarter temperatures curbing yields, could compel the world's second-biggest wheat producer to maintain its export ban or even force it to resort to imports. Farmers in the country had planted wheat on 8.6 million hectares as of Nov. 17, down nearly 5.5% from a year earlier, according to data compiled by the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers' Welfare. In neighbouring Maharashtra state, farmer Avinash Phalke earlier this month planted sorghum on three acres instead of wheat. "Our well has nearly dried up, leaving us no option but to plant a crop that requires less water," he said. El Nino conditions will continue through the northern hemisphere during the April-June period, a U.S. government weather forecaster said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Lucas Museum of Narrative Art will be built in Los Angeles at a cost of $1 billion. The museum will house 10,000 paintings along with book and magazine illustrations. The collection includes works by Edgar Degas, Winslow Homer and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. It will be housed in what’s been described by various press outlets as a “futuristic-looking” museum. The Lucas Museum will be a barrier free museum where artificial divisions between ‘high’ and ‘popular’ art are absent, according to the museum's website. It's not surprising that a Hollywood icon like George Lucas would want to open a museum dedicated to both “high” and “popular” art. After all, famous cultural critic Camille Paglia once dubbed him “the greatest artist of our time.” The museum is set to open in Exposition Park, a popular spot for art institutions in the coastal city of Los Angeles, in the fall of 2015. It is expected to be open for about a year and a half before moving to a permanent location. It has not yet been announced where the museum will be located, but it will be near the Los Angeles International Airport, which is a popular destination for tourists and tourists to the city's beaches and parks. It won't be the first museum of its kind, with an unprecedented collection that features fine art and popular art from illustration to comics, an insider's perspective on the cinematic creative process and the boundless potential of the digital medium.
label: SAFE

text: Artist Shing Yin Khor painted the Statue of Liberty in protest of President Donald Trump's travel ban. Shing: "I can't stop my work from arcing in a political direction when my actual identity as a human being is something the Trump administration wants to unconstitutionally deny basic rights to” Shing raised $2,000 for the ACLU by painting 40 pictures of Lady Liberty over the course of 13 hours. For many Americans, life under Trump has not been business as usual. An executive order against people of one religion along with the dread of other restrictive orders that may come have led some people to question their daily habits and responsibilities, reevaluating whether their life choices are still valid, effective, enough. What will you stand up for? Tell us with #LoveTakesAction. The Huffington Post is telling stories of how people are standing up to hate and supporting those most threatened. For more stories from the series, visit the Huffington Post’s #LovetakesAction page and follow us on Twitter at @HuffingtonPost and @jennifer_newton or on Facebook at Facebook.com/JenniferNewton and @Jill_Newton. The series also airs on PBS stations in the U.S. and on CNN in the UK and Europe, and on PBS International in the Middle East and in the United Arab Emirates in the European Union and the United States in the Latin America and the Middle Eastern and South America.

text: Iwobi was handed his second league start for Fulham in the Cottagers 1-0 loss at home to Manchester United. The 25-year-old made an assist for Neal Maupay to open the scoring in the first half, heading home his first goal since returning to the club in the summer transfer window. The goal ended a run of 45 Premier League appearances without a goal – his last strike had come for Everton, also against West Ham, in September 2022. He also has a pass accuracy of 91 per cent, a total of four dribbles and was rated 7.17 by the statistics websites.

text: Karen Ng has danced on Good Morning America, New York Live with Ben Aaron, ABC Live, and showcased her choreography at B.B. Kings, Times Square Arts Center, and the NYC Dance Parade. She has also produced and performed her own projects with Triple8Funk Dance Company, Soul in Motion, All Aboard Burlesque, and has brought Byron Cox (House Dance Project) and Waack It Out with Jayshri Nand to Auckland. In New Zealand, most of the people who came to hip-hop classes were Islanders and Asians. Here, it's different. Race definitely matters for casting or auditions. It's part of the industry, so you either roll with it or don't partake in it. If I'm a dancer's piece, you're not supposed to challenge the choreographer's vision. I enjoy putting different elements of what I enjoy into someone else's piece because it's great. The fact that dance videos are so popular online says a lot that dance choreographers are making more value in making their work visible. It really really really great thing that dancers can take things into their own hands, using their own platform, using social media to make their work more visible. I feel so at home in New York that I always miss it when I leave. There's nowhere else where I feel I can be me. I always loved to dance and sing, so they put me in ballet school because that was the only thing available in the 80's.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The bed should always be the main consideration when designing a guest bedroom. The most soothing colors to consider for a bedroom are shades of green or blue. A mirror is stylish and practical and serves as a stylish floor floor. New bedside lamps are not only affordable but add a fun accent – for a more modern room, consider a pendant from the ceiling or wall mounting a cool sconce over your nightstand. The bedside table is another factor to consider to create a welcoming and comfortable guest bedroom, says Christopher Grubb, interior designer and founder of Arch-Interiors Design Group. The guest bedroom should be a sanctuary, a place of repose and rest, and a place that makes people happy at the start and end of every day, says Grubb. The bedroom should also provide privacy and practicality, says Eril Serbetci, co-founder and designer at Darling Spring, and provide a place for guests to assess their looks as they get dressed for the day..
label: SAFE

text: Sing for Hope has placed 336 artist-designed pianos in NYC parks and public spaces over the past 5 years. Of the 336 pianos, 3 have been vandalized, but each one has been repaired. The pianos will go to under-resourced public schools, where they will benefit an estimated 15,000 students. A simple public piano is able to catalyze positive change on levels both communal and individual, says Sing for Hope's founder, Rob Baird. The arts create possibility, possibility creates hope, and our city needs hope, says Baird. "When you bet on what is best in people, they step up," says Baird, "and we know it's vital to our shared survival. Less than one percent of our instruments is a victim of urban vandalism. It is an urban miracle. Part of the urban reality of the Sing for hope Pianos is how it is a miracle how it rarely falls to the ground. It can feel risky, but it can feel vital, but we know we're in a shared, hospitable terrain, and that they'll bear fruit, flower, bear fruit," Baird says. "It's a bet on the best of what makes us human, on our capacity for creativity and empathy," he adds. "The arts create possibilities, and the city needs possibilities," Baird adds. 'It's an urban reality that the urban survival is a shared survival, and it's a vital part of the shared survival,' he says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: More than 16 firefighters are battling the flames, supported by air tankers dropping fire retardant. Weather forecasters predict shifting winds that could help containment efforts in the coming days. The Red Cross has opened cooling centers for evacuees, and local veterinary clinics are providing temporary shelter for pets. The wildfire is threatening residential areas in the Georgia city of Kennesaw and its surrounding areas. The fire has burned more than 1,000 acres so far, officials say. The cause of the fire is under investigation, the Georgia Department of Forestry and Natural Resources says. The blaze is not under control yet, but it is expected to burn for at least a few more days, the department says. It has forced the evacuation of more than 2,000 people in the city and surrounding areas, including Kennesawedo County, Georgia, and the town of Kennedo, South Carolina, where the fire broke out in the early morning hours of Sunday. It is burning in a rural area near the town's airport, which has a population of just over 1,500 people, authorities say. text: Social-media managers Braelyn, 31, and Spencer Stone, 27, moved to Mérida, Mexico, in 2022. They were unable to afford life in Houston, Texas. The crime rate in Mexico is crazy low. Gun laws are stricter, and you don't hear of people shooting up schools or stores. They are saving a little over $2,000 each month — depending on how much they want to splurge, they say. They've paid off about $5,000 of their debt so far, but they still have a long way to go in terms of paying off all of their bills in the U.S. and paying off their student loans. They say the biggest con is not having your community — I'm literally an extrovert because I need to meet more people in the US to meet my friends and family in Mexico. The as-told-to essay is based on a conversation they had with CNN.com's John Sutter in Houston.

text: SpaceX is meeting before the U.S. Subcommittee on Space and Science on Wednesday. Company officials will urge that the FAA double the staff in charge of issuing space launch licenses. SpaceX also suggested that parties applying for licenses with the FAA should be given the option to help pay for independent third-party technical support during upcoming surge times. So far this year, SpaceX has launched more than 70 rockets, with plans to increase its rate by about 50 percent for 2024. The company plans to use its Starship rocket to launch its next generation Starlink satellites, as well as land astronauts on the Moon as part of NASA’s Artemis program. And of course, SpaceX founder Elon Musk wants to use the megarocket to transport thousands of colonists to Mars. The FAA closed its investigation into the inaugural launch of Starship and gave SpaceX a list of 63 corrective actions to implement before it can fly its megarockets again. The rocket was destacked later the same day, but SpaceX has been eager to see Starship launch again.
label: SAFE
