text: The Sea Guardian-3 joint maritime exercise kicked off with an opening ceremony at the Karachi Naval Dockyard on Saturday. Participating forces from the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) Navy include the Type 052D guided missile destroyer Zibo. Pakistani media reports that a conventional attack submarine and a submarine support ship along with a marines corps detachment from the PLA Navy are also involved. The nine-day exercise in the waters and airspace of the northern Arabian Sea will organize training courses including formation maneuvering, VBSS (visit, board, search and seizure), helicopter cross-deck landing, joint search and rescue, joint anti-submarine and main gun shooting, plus professional exchanges and mutual visits. It is the third and the largest edition of the Sea Guardian exercises, CCTV said. The first edition was held in 2020 in the northern Saudi Arabian Sea waters, and the second edition in 2022 in waters off Shanghai. The exercises serve the objectives of fostering interoperability and sharing professional experiences to deal with contemporary traditional and non-traditional security threats.

The United States Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) currently is considering as many as 10 applications to launch similar spot-based ETFs in the US. text: The Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Chicago Cubs 11-1 to clinch the National League Championship series 4-1. Los Angeles outfielder Enrique Hernandez struck three home runs, including a grand slam in the third inning, and drove in seven runs at Wrigley Field in Chicago. The Dodgers will meet either the New York Yankees or Houston Astros in the World Series, which starts in Los Angeles on Tuesday. The Yankees lead the Astros 3-2 in the best-of-seven American League Championship Series ahead of Game Six in Houston on Friday and, if needed, Game Seven on Saturday. “It’s been a long time coming for this team. I never thought in a million years I’d get to play a World Series," Dodgers starting pitcher Clayton Kershaw said after the game. The Cubs’ season concluded with barely a whimper, 12 months after they ended a century-long drought by beating the Cleveland Indians in the seventh game of the World series. The Dodger bullpen pitched three scoreless innings, extending their streak to 23 consecutive scoreless hours in the postseason. The World Series starts on Tuesday night in New York, with the winner going on to face either the Yankees or Astros in a repeat of last year's final, which the Yankees won 3-1 in the final game of last season's World Series in New England. The series will be the first since 1988, when the Dodgers moved from Brooklyn to Los Angeles and went on to win the title for the fifth time.
label: SAFE

text: Lindsey Vonn says she would turn down an invitation to the White House after the Olympics. The skier says she hopes to represent the people of the United States, not the president. Athletes from the New England Patriots and the Golden State Warriors also refused to visit the White house this year after winning championships. After Steph Curry’s comments, President Trump withdrew his White House invitation to his team: Going to the. White House is considered a great honor for a championship team.Stephen Curry is hesitating,therefore invitation is withdrawn! Maybe Trump will say he didn’t want Vonn at the White. House anyway. The 33-year-old skier added: “I want to represent our country well. I don't think that there are a lot of people currently in our government that do that.’“By not going, hopefully it will inspire some change for what we tolerate in this country and what we stand for, what is accepted,” the Warriors’ Steph Curry told reporters at the time. “Absolutely not,’ she said, smiling and shaking her head. ‘I take the Olympics very seriously and what they mean and what They represent, what walking under our flag means in the opening ceremony.” “The president is not the only one who has the power to make or break the Olympics," Vonn said. "The president has to be the one who makes or breaks the Olympics, not me."

text: 40 workers trapped after under-construction tunnel collapses in northern India. Officials hope to extricate them in the next 24 hours. The collapsed portion of the 4.5-kilometer (2.7-mile) tunnel is about 200 meters (500 feet) from the entrance, officials say. to be pushed through an opening of excavated debris with the help of hydraulic jacks to safely pull out the stranded workers, authorities say. The workers have been supplied with water and dryfood through a pipeline, a government official said, adding all the workers are alive and well. text: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) signed agreements with oblasts to support daily school meals for more than 60,000 children in 420 schools across the country. During the 2023-2024 academic year, WFP will fund 30% of the daily hot meals for children in schools in Kyiv, Lviv, Zakarpattia, Ternopil, Khmelnytskyi, Chernihiv, Chernivtsi, Cherkasy, Mykolaiv, Odesa, and Poltava. Schools will utilize the funds received through the programme to improve the quality of the meals or to reduce the fee paid by parents to the canteen. WFP operates within the framework of the Government's School Nutrition Reform, in close coordination with the Ministry of Education and Science, oblast and hromada authorities and the schools. France hosted the first global summit of the School Meals Coalition, which strives to ensure every child receives school meals by 2030.

text: Professional athlete Nadia Hassan was arrested early this morning on suspicion of driving under the influence after crashing a vehicle into a parked car. She could also face a possible suspension from the NBA and/or the NBA Players Association. She was released on a $100,000 bail bond and will appear in court on November 14. She is currently being represented by attorney Michael Cevallos, who is also representing the NBA players' union, the Players Association and the National Basketball Players Association (PBA) The Wolves are currently in the middle of a season-opener against the New York Knicks. text: At least 29 people have been killed and more than 300,000 have fled their homes. The phenomenon has sparked turmoil in neighbouring states Kenya and Ethiopia. Scientists say climate change is causing more intense and more frequent extreme weather events, with the Horn of Africa especially vulnerable. “This cycle of flooding and drought is going to continue. And we’re going to see more and more of this unless we do something on a global scale,” Christophe Hodder, a climate security advisor at the United Nations Environment Programme told Al Jazeera. In Kenya, torrential downpours over the weekendkilledat least 15 people, while destroying 97 hectares (240 acres) of farmland and wiping out more than 1,000 livestock animals, the Kenya Red Cross Society reported Sunday. The flooding in Somalia is part of a regional deluge linked to ongoing weather patterns known as El Nino and the Indian Ocean Dipole — which impact ocean surface temperatures and cause extreme rainfall, experts say. In Ethiopia, thousands are also reportedly displaced in the Somali region of Ethiopia due to ongoing flooding.
label: SENSITIVE

The two organisations will aim to bridge the gap between laboratory discoveries and clinical applications to accelerate the development of new treatments and therapies. Overall LifeArc is investing up to £100m to tackle neurodegnerative conditions and is committed to spending £1.3 billion by 2030 in areas of high unmet medical need. The projects receiving the funding are: A joint committee between UK DRI and LifeArc agreed the projects andDr Kay Penicud, UK D RI Director of Innovation & Business, said“It is fantastic to see such a breadth of high-quality translational research from across many of our Centres in these projects”

text: The National Invasive Species Council has been working to combat their spread since 1999. Many of these plants and animals are almost exclusively the byproduct of human will. One man's dream to populate America with every bird mentioned in the works of Shakespeare has led to million-member swarms of starlings that rain poop over less-than-pleased neighborhoods. Australia's efforts to control pests by introducing cane toads onto the continent has resulted in populations numbering into the billions -- none of which actually eat the bugs they were supposed to. But remember, it's not always their fault they're around. It's ours. Back to Mail Online home. back to the page you came from. Back To the pageyou came from, Back to thepage you camefrom. text: Bill Moyers: Baseball has changed a lot in the last five years. He says it's not organic; it's been imposed by data. Moyers says we live a data-driven life at the expense of a more human-driven one. The more explanatory our data, the better, he says, but there is still a long way to go. The game is not so much a lie as a lie, Moyers writes, even if it is statistics-based. It's time for a new era in baseball, and in American politics, too, he writes. The era of the sabermetrics is over, Moyer says, and it's time to get back to playing the game the way it used to be: instinctive, instinctive and instinctive. It’s time for the game to be a little more like baseball, with a little less guesswork, intuition and talent, he adds. The time for baseball to be more like the game it once was is over; it is time to start playing it the way baseball used to play. The world is changing, and the game is changing with it, Moyering says. The future is data-based, and we need to get used to it, or we’ll be stuck with it for the rest of our lives, he argues. The real villain is not statistics, but the way we think about them, and how we use them, as a general rule of thumb, the more explanatory they are.
label: SAFE

text: Emergency responders are working around the clock to ensure resident safety. Evacuation shelters are stocked with food, water, and medical supplies. Local hospitals have implemented emergency protocols and are prepared to treat storm-related injuries. Community volunteers are helping elderly and disabled residents evacuate safely. The storm has strengthened to Category 3 with maximum sustained winds of 160 mph. It is expected to strengthen to a Category 4 hurricane by Friday night or Saturday morning. The National Weather Service has issued a tropical storm warning for parts of the eastern seaboard of the U.S., including New Jersey, New York, Delaware, and Maryland. It has also issued a hurricane warning for portions of the East Coast, including New York City, Long Island, Boston, Philadelphia, and San Francisco. The hurricane warning is in effect for the New Jersey coast and the New York and New Jersey Outer Banks, as well as parts of Long Island and the southern New England coast. It could make landfall as a Category 5 hurricane by Saturday night or Sunday morning, with winds of up to 100 mph and sustained winds up to 160 mph in some areas. It's expected to make landfall in the Florida Keys on Sunday night or Monday morning, and then move north-northwest to the east coast of the Florida peninsula and then north-northeast to New Jersey and New England. It may make a turn toward the east side of the coast on Sunday. It will make landfall on Monday morning or Tuesday morning, possibly in New Jersey or New Jersey.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Ruth Appelhof, Executive Director of Guild Hall, will receive the Arthamptons Lifetime Achievement Award on July 5. Over eggs Benedict at the Maidstone in East Hampton, we talked about her accomplishments at Guild Hall over her 16-year tenure. "This year is going to be a banner year. We have Alec Baldwin at one end of our season and Roy Lichtenstein at the other. To have those bookends really says something about what a great place Guild Hall is," she said. "I like to say there is a round table discussion about once a month with all the programmers, fundraisers, marketing people, and support staff. I like to think that many of those ideas came from me originally, but maybe not. The Roy decision came about 15 years ago when I first got here. I thought, who was the absolute greatest artist that Guild Hall could ever exhibit from this area? It had to be somebody contemporary, who appealed to a wide audience, who made art considered above and beyond what you would consider of value," she says. "We all think we know his work so well from the cartoon series. This is way beyond that, and because it is "Between Sea and Sky," it relates to the Hamptons. We support the local talent and thankfully it's great," she adds. "How about a great show with Barbara Kruger? That was a great job here; I had not realized that Motherwell was outside the circle of artists here"
label: SAFE

text: John Nation set up the "Aerosol Art Project" at a youth center in Bristol, England, in 1984. He wanted to give teenagers a safe place to spray-paint without fear of arrest and prosecution. It spawned an entire generation of influential and genre-defining artists, including Banksy. But it also almost ended up costing him his job, his reputation and his liberty, as the British Police carried out raids on the center and his home in 1988 and 1989. Nation, now 54, told HuffPost: "I was running an aerosol art project, not an art project for graffiti artists’ safety and security’s sake’’ “It was like an Aladdin's Cave for them,” he said. “There was never any bad vibes or competition, none of that element. It was all about being a crew and a togetherness and I still think that's true to the guys who paint now.” “We helped kids deal with the nitty gritty of life [...] providing sexual health awareness, talking about drugs, that kind of thing,’ he told HuffPost. ‘It helped break down some barriers. Lots of these guys listened to hip hop, reggae and black-inspired music, but they were in a predominantly white area. Being involved in graffiti opened their eyes and helped to lower their prejudices’ The project was eventually shut down by the Avon County Council authority in 1988, but not before it inspired other authorities to launch similar initiatives.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A cast of senior actors starred in an adaptation of the 1977 bittersweet romcom "Annie Hall" New York-based artists Ellie Sachs and Matt Starr conceived of the project, dreaming up the possibility of creating a movie with an elderly cast on their first date. Sachs and Starr had already developed a ritual of reenacting classic films with his grandmother Maxine, who has Alzheimer’s. They invited those in the class to vote on which one they’d like to appear in, and the class selected “annie Hall” The film follows the romance between Alvy Singer, an overanxious comedian, and Annie Hall, a breezy and capricious nightclub singer. It tells a story in a nonlinear fashion. It comes down to the question of: What do we remember and why do we remembers it? It’S a beautiful comparison to what some of our students might be experiencing. Many of the actors are dealing, in various ways, with the reality of their minds changing and memories fading. The actors don’t have cell phones, so they have to call them at 7 in the morning or 8 at night. The communication was difficult, but most were logistical rather than personal. “We had a 94-year-old in 94-degree heat, and I took it upon myself to have one of those water bottles spray him,” Starr said of one of the challenges of filming in New York summer heat, which can be brutal for people of any age.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Fossil fuels make up about 80% of the North American energy mix and this will drop sharply to about 40% by 2050. Coal demand in North America (including Canada) peaked in 2000. Any policies that extend the life of fossil fuels as a domestic power source will only add to household energy bills. Moving to a more electrified and less carbon intensive energy system will impact employment patterns, particularly in those states which have a history of fossil fuel extraction. For households, it is important those with a low income are not left behind. The upfront costs of devices such as heat pumps, which are at the heart of the residential energy transition, can dissuade low-income households from investing in these. These households are then at risk of missing out on the reduction in their energy bill in the long run, which is a form of the phenomenon dubbed ‘the poverty tax’ in popular parlance. We forecast that 12 trillion dollars will be spent on renewables and the grid between now and 2050.
label: SENSITIVE

The company, which obtained the regulator’s in-principle approval for its payment aggregator licence last year, plans to launch its own payment gateway. Backed by the likes of Matrix Partners, Epiq Capital and Falcon Edge, Mswipe provides card machines and payment acceptance infrastructure to merchants. It has also expanded into providing loans to its merchants base.

text: Dorothea Lasky was my very first poetry professor at Columbia, where I'm studying for my MFA. A month into our time together, I told Dottie I wasn't writing frequently enough, that I felt tense and was overthinking when I went to write. Her response was to send me a text message every night for the entire month of October, 2013. Every night I turned somersaults, guzzled a rainbow of different fruit juices, plunged into scalding baths--all the while jotting down phrases on a big yellow legal pad. The end of every ritual culminated in a poem. As time passed, a sense of the spiritual and sacred suffused my apartment and all of its contents. It had all become part of my poetry--the thing that mattered most to me in the world. The night after I completed the Ninth Universe, I wrote a Tenth. More Universes followed and eventually, with her earlier prompts, they formed the bedrock of my first chapbook, AEONS, winner of the 2014 Poetry Society of America Chapbook competition. It's a rare thing for a book of poems to be born in a single classroom. I wanted her to discuss her educational philosophy, which is idiosyncratic in the extreme. Do you think you need to learn all about someone before you can help them make art? What is the link between intimacy and teaching--teaching poetry or anything else? And how would you have taught me if we didn't have so much in common?
label: SAFE

text: Donald Trump's plan to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border has been slammed as racist and xenophobic. Wildlife scientists say the wall could trigger major environmental problems, damaging delicate ecosystems. The ability to roam freely is critically important because it helps animals find food and water as well as mates. A wall could reduce the number of animals along the border and make them less genetically diverse and more vulnerable to disease and drought, they say. It could affect 111 endangered species and 108 migratory bird species, some of which are endangered, the Fish and Wildlife Service has estimated. The wall would cost untold billions to build, and it's not clear if the political fallout would be enough to persuade Trump to drop his plan, or if it could harm our national symbol, too. The Wall, by the way, is not currently being funded by the federal government, according to a report by the Center for American Progress, a think tank that focuses on free-market capitalism and free-enterprise economics. It's unclear whether the wall will ever be built, but it's a good idea to keep an eye on the future of the country, the group said in a report last month. It also said that the wall would have a negative impact on the economy, which is already suffering from low unemployment and stagnant wages. The report also said it would have an negative effect on the environment, including the environment and wildlife, because it would disrupt a large portion of the border's habitat. It was the first report of its kind.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The two solid rocket motors were transported by truck in early October from Mojave Air and Space Port to the science center in South Los Angeles. The placement will be completed using two cranes—a small one that will lift the rockets from a horizontal position to a vertical one. Once the boosters are installed, the final piece to complete the solidrocketboosters are the tips. The museum must assemble scaffolding for that installation to take place. The full assembly of the boosters will set the stage for installation of the orange external tank, which will occur no earlier than early January. The $400-million Samuel Oschin Air andspace Center will rise 20 stories tall. It'll be the only space shuttle exhibit nationwide to depict the spacecraft as if it were at the launchpad, ready for takeoff. It will be one of only three museums in the U.S. to permanently feature a trio of surviving shuttles that have seen spaceflight. The rest of the museum will then be built around it.
label: SAFE

text: Scientists in the UK and South Korea have proposed a new way of compressing light to increase its intensity. This could revolutionize the next generation of lasers to enable their powers to increase by more than one million times from what is achievable now. The results of this research are expected to be applicable in various fields, including advanced theoretical physics and astrophysics. It can also be used in laser fusion research to help address the energy issues facing humanity. The new method ofcompressinglaser pulsesin plasma ispublished in the journal Nature Photonics. The highest power lasers in the world have a peak power of around 10 petawatts. The sun produces 4x1026W of power or 400,000 zettawatts. For example, 173 petawatts (173 × 1015W) of sunshine reaches the Earth's upper atmosphere, and about one third of this reaches the planet's surface. The current intensity frontier in physics is 1029W/cm2, which is known as the Schwinger limit.
label: SAFE

text: The online pre-sale campaign of the dolls stitched by internally displaced women in the ethnic strife-hit Manipur exceeded expectations. ‘Stitching Hope’ equips displaced persons with skills in the Japanese craft art of amigurumi. The Kickstarter campaign’s success, doubling its initial goal, is attributed to a blend of compassion and the therapeutic aspect of crafting dolling. As the campaign transitions to the production phase, resilient women artisans are not merely crafting dolls; they are shaping a narrative of hope and reclaiming control over their lives. The promise of delivering dolls with augmented reality ensures these tangible symbols of shared stories and collective empowerment reach homes globally. The augmented reality experience breathes life into the dolls, turning each into a storyteller sharing tales of Manipur’S courage and indomitable spirit. This technological innovation becomes a bridge connecting disparate worlds, sharing the story of Manipuri with children globally. Read More News on 1 million heroes manipur news manipur kukii.

text: More than 150 startups are chasing an ambitious goal: meat that doesn’t require raising and killing animals that is affordable and tastes and feels like the meat we eat now. Producing meat this way could dramatically reduce the impact of meat on the environment because it would reduce the need for land for the animals and for feed. Wide adoption of meat from cells is nowhere near assured, however. This meat is expensive to make. There are scientific challenges, such as learning how to mimic the complex structure of steak. Government regulation is another obstacle. Only Singapore and the U.S. allow sales of cultivated meat. A majority of those who said they wouldn't said “it just sounds weird.” Even Nahmias’ 10-year-old son Oren says he will only eat traditional meat. The Protein Problem is an AP series that examines the question: Can we feed this growing world without starving the planet? To see the full project, visit www.apnews.com/features/2023/the-protein-problem/index.html.

text: U.S. seeks to work with China on global challenges from climate change to debt distress, says Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen. But Washington will not compromise on protecting its national security interests and advancing human rights, Yellen added. Her remarks outlining Washington's approach to US-China ties come ahead of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meetings this month in San Francisco. President Joe Biden isexpected to meet Chinese leader Xi Jinpingfor the first time since they conferred in Bali last year. "We know the US- China relationship is among the most consequential in the world," Yellen told an event in Washington on Thursday. " we need to get it right." She said the United States is working to collaborate on international issues including climate change and debt difficulties in low-income countries. She stressed that US national security actions would be "narrowly targeted", citing recentoutbound investment restrictionsthat Washington insisted were not aimed at curbing China's growth, but at preserving national interests.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The impacts of climate change could shave up to seven percent off Kenya's economic output by 2050. The East African economic powerhouse is extremely vulnerable to climate disasters. The number of poor people in Kenya could increase by 1.1 million by 2050 if there is "inaction against climate change" Kenya's government has limited room for manoeuvre, with its coffers depleted as it struggles to contain skyrocketing inflation and a plunging currency. The country's public debt stood at more than 10.1 trillion shillings ($66 billion) at the end of June, according to Treasury figures, equivalent to around two-thirds of GDP. The agriculture sector, which is the top contributor to Kenya's economy, representing around 21 percent of GDP in 2022, has already come under pressure from drought and torrential rains. the World Bank said that the country of 53 million people will need $62 billion by 2030 to adapt its economy to climate challenges. It will require both domestic resources and expanding climate-compatible private investment in existing areas.
label: SENSITIVE

text: 11 House Republicans signed a letter expressing support for the National Endowment for the Arts. The letter was sent to the chairman and top-ranking Democrat of the House subcommittee with jurisdiction over appropriation of funds for the NEA and NEH. The endowments may be favorite targets of small-government, budget-cutting hardliners, but they’ve nonetheless enjoyed support from a healthy number of Republican lawmakers over the years. Several GOP lawmakers expressed their support for them after Trump’s bold proposal that they be eliminated entirely. But even with his party controlling both the House and the Senate, Trump may struggle to achieve much of his agenda, even when his party controls both legislative bodies. The New York Times reported that the signatories included “one Republican who previously voted to defund public broadcasting,” though none of the lawmakers were named. In March, PEN America executive director Suzanne Nossel and Stephen Kidd, executive director of the National Humanities Alliance, each cited a February letter sent by Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) to the president advocating for continued support of theendowments. “We are heartened by the level of bipartisan support that members of Congress have shown for theNEH in recent years and in recent weeks,’’ Kidd told HuffPost. ‘I believe we can find a way to commit to fiscal responsibility while continuing to support the important benefits that N.E.A. and N.e.H. provide.’
label: SENSITIVE

text: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket exploded in flames at Cape Canaveral Thursday morning during a pre-launch test. Video of the incident shows a small ignition near the top of the vehicle that quickly spreads, ultimately exploding. SpaceX CEO Elon Musk tweeted afterward that the cause is unknown, though it originated during the propellant fill operation around “the upper stage oxygen tank.” SpaceX did not immediately respond to a request for comment from The Huffington Post. The company elaborated on Musk’s understanding of the event in a further tweet, adding that “all personnel were clear of the pad and there were no injuries.’“Loss of Falcon vehicle today during propellant filling operation. Originated around upper stage Oxygen tank. Cause still unknown. More soon.“ pic.twitter.com/1ogCMPCY44 — Elon Musk (@elonmusk) November 14, 2014. The cause of the explosion is not yet known, though Musk tweeted that it originated around ‘the upper stages oxygen tank’ and “more soon’ SpaceX has not yet commented on the incident, which occurred during a test for a Falcon 9 satellite. The rocket is scheduled to launch from Cape Canaveral in Florida on Friday morning, with a scheduled launch time of 6:30 a.m. ET. It is not known if there will be a rescheduled launch date for the Falcon 9 in the near future. The launchpad is located at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

text: Roxane Gay says she asked her agent to pull a book originally slated for publication with a Simon & Schuster imprint in 2018. The book, a nonfiction work entitled How to Be Heard, was to have been published by TED Books, a series by the influential idea-championing TED organization published in partnership with Simon and Schuster. Gay: "I’m not interested in doing business with a publisher willing to grant him that privilege. So be it. Milo has every right to say what he wants to say [...] he doesn’t have a right to have a book published by a major publisher but he has, in some bizarre twist of fate, been afforded that privilege" The book still appears on the landing page for TED Books on Simon &Schuster’s website, available for preorder with a publication date in March 2018. TED released a statement on Wednesday stating, “We’re disappointed that we won”t get to put this important book out into the world, but we respect and accept her decision.” As for How to be Heard, Gay told Buzzfeed that though she hasn’yet secured another publisher for the book, ‘I do hope the book is published someday.’ Our bets are on this one getting snapped up in no time. text: Patients get prescriptions from doctors when their symptoms are most severe and improve with time. Doctors and patients need independent, objective information on drug efficacy and risks. Drug bulletins are a source of truth to help patients and doctors see through the fudged misinformation, says Dick Bijl, president of the International Society Of Drug Bulletins. The multibillion dollar pharma marketing machine can turn even the most useless and harmful drugs into financial blockbusters, he says. The bar for approval is set very low, he writes. "Small statistical blips are all it takes to get a drug approved," he says, adding that patients can't detect improvements if they are less than three points. "The lack of efficacy of BPS meds supports a policy of watchful waiting instead of starting drug therapy," he writes, adding. "Use of medication for LUTS should be discouraged since it is no better than placebo, but adds to the risk of re-assurance and re-reassurance" It's not rational to prescribe drugs that do not improve functioning, he adds. "Informed patients will be much willing to take a drug that carries the risk. of side effects, while offering the very best choice at a very low cost," says Bij l. "When it is decided to start drug therapy, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors should be the best choice," he adds, referring to the alpha blockers used in the treatment of BPH. "It is less likely that a patient will have to undergo an operation to remove a tumor," says the ISDB.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Negotiators on course for a 2015 summit in Paris but not on track for limiting global warming to an agreed ceiling of 2 degrees Celsius. Delegates in Warsaw agreed that a new global deal would be made up of what they called "intended nationally determined contributions" from both rich and poor nations. "It is abundantly clear that we still have a long way to go," said Christiana Figueres, the U.N. climate chief. The two-week meeting also created a Warsaw International Mechanism to help the poor cope with loss and damage from heatwaves, droughts, floods, desertification and rising sea levels. Environmentalists walked out on Thursday, exasperated by lack of progress at the talks in Poland, which were widely criticised as lacking urgency. "We did not achieve a meaningful outcome," said Naderev Sano, a Philippines delegate who had been fasting throughout the talks to urge action in sympathy with victims of Typhoon Haiyan, which killed more than 5,000 people. "In the old system you had this firewall between commitments and actions, now there is one word for all," European Commissioner Connie Hedegaard said. "There are many ways to Paris that would be more beautiful and faster," she said. But developing nations said the rich still needed to lead, with India's Environment Minister Jayanthi Natarajan saying: "In my understanding the firewall exists and will continue to exist" Either way, U.S. climate envoy Todd Stern said there would be no coercion.
label: SENSITIVE

text: International funding for climate resilience in developing countries slumped in 2021. Public finance to developing countries fell 15 percent to around $21 billion. Overall annual funding that developing countries need to adapt to climate impacts this decade is projected to have increased to as much as $387 billion. World leaders meeting at this year's climate talks in the United Arab Emirates will face a tough reckoning over financial solidarity between rich polluters and vulnerable nations, as a failure to cut planet-heating emissions threatens the Paris deal's global warming limits. "Storms, fires, floods, drought and extreme temperatures are becoming more frequent and more ferocious, and they're on course to get far worse," says U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, in a statement. The world must urgently cut greenhouse gas emissions and increase adaptation efforts to protect vulnerable populations, says UNEP Executive Director Inger Andersen, in the foreword to the Adaptation Gap report. "Neither is happening," he says. The report stresses that every billion spent on adaptation against coastal flooding leads to a $14 billion reduction in economic damages.

text: Dali in Yunnan province has become a haven for those seeking to escape the pressure. They are drawn by the cheap rents, mild climate, stunning scenery and a history of relative tolerance. In November, searches for "Dali" on WeChat were up 7% from a year ago, having surged some 290% on one day in late July, when many Chinese were booking summer trips. Dali is an exception to the flight of youth to large cities that has occurred since China's economic modernisation, experts say. The local government has sought to attract young tech talent and in September asked digital nomads for input on policies, two community organisers told Reuters. But the town's population also includes many young people who say they are sceptical of Beijing's attempts to shape their personal lives, they say.. Many of the people interviewed by Reuters said they found an escape from the conservative social values of rural China, where several of the young people said they had found a refuge on the fringes of society.

The petition, which cited the Idaho Statesman's reporting on the decision, asks the U.S. Forest Service to prohibit aerialGunning on national forest land. The groups said they will considerlegal actionif the Forest Service does not respond to the petition. The Idaho State Department of Agriculture told the Statesman the proposals were part of an effort to include ranchers in wolf management and are still in early stages. text: Plants absorb CO2 from the air and store it as biomass. In doing so, plants slow down climate change since the CO2 they take up does not contribute to global warming. But what will happen under more advanced climatechange? How will vegetation respond to projected changes in atmospheric CO2, temperatures, and rainfall? Our study shows plants might take up more CO2than previously thought. We found climate modeling that best accounted for the processes that sustain plant life consistently predicted the strongest CO2uptake. The most complex model predicted up to 20% more than the simplest version. Our findings highlight the resilience of plants and the importance of planting trees and preserving existing vegetation to slow climate change. It is still up to us to fight climate change by cutting fossil fuel emissions. But it's essential to conserve existing biomass and restore lost vegetation to help fight the climate change, say the authors of the study. The study was published today inScience Advances, a journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Dark Hedges, a tunnel of beech trees near Armoy, County Antrim, became a popular tourist attraction after featuring in the popular HBO series. A recent report found that the majority of the trees are in a poor state. The trees were planted to line the Bregagh Road to Gracehill House, which was built in about 1775. Originally there were about 150 trees, but only 86 remain. Several have been brought down by strong winds during storms in recent years and could pose a potential risk to the public, according to the Department for Infrastructure (DfI) The department said the decision had not been made lightly and that the safety of road users was paramount. They said completion of the works was dependent on favourable weather conditions and the department said it would keep the public informed of any change. The works will start on 20 November and will be completed by the end of the month, the DfI said. They added that they would engage with landowners to implement a management strategy for the future of the remaining trees.

text: Study: People with certain personality traits are more likely to develop a social media addiction. neuroticism, conscientiousness and agreeableness were related to addiction. Two other personality traits, extraversion and openness to experience, weren’t linked with addiction. More research is needed to confirm the findings, but the findings could have implications for those who treat tech addictions, the researchers said.. The study was conducted by Binghamton University in New York state and was published in the journal Systems Science. It was presented in January at the 51st Hawaii International Conference on Systems Science, which was held in Hawaii. It’s important to note that because the study involved a few hundred college students at a single university, the findings are not yet conclusive, according to the researchers. The researchers said they hope the findings will encourage people to look at the “whole picture” of how personality traits affect tech addiction, “rather than just focusing on one personality trait” at a time. They added that users with higher levels of IT addictions may not be considered as one homogeneous group of users, as different personality traits can play different roles in users’ dispositions toward IT addiction,” the researchers wrote in their paper. The research was conducted on 300 college students, who were asked to assess their personality and gauge their level of addiction to the social media site each individual used most frequently. It's possible that people who have high levels of both agreeablness and conscientiousness make a conscious decision to use social networks more, in order to help their friendships flourish.
label: SENSITIVE

text: More than 150 countries and millions of people will engage in a crowd-sourced conservation effort from 8:30 to 9:30 p.m. local time. This year's event has a heroic partner to help spur people into action as Spider-Man became the first superhero ambassador to join with the World Wildlife Fund-backed project. If you think you're a "super hero for the planet," enter the event's Instagram contest using the hashtags #EarthHour, #SpiderMan and #YourPower. The event began in Australia in 2007 and has since grown as a day of environmental awareness to help Spur action on local priorities, including efforts to protect turtle species, combat poaching and save pandas. You can see what your country is planning for Earth Hour here, and if you thinkyou're a 'super hero' for the environment, enter the Instagram contest by using the hashtag #earthhour and #yourpower. The contest will be open until November 1. The winner will receive a $1,000 donation from the Earth Hour Blue fund, which will be used to help support country-specific environmentalism, such as turtle species protection and pandas conservation. The competition is open to people in the U.S., Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Argentina and the United Kingdom. It will also be open to the public in the UK, Canada, France, Germany, Australia and New Zealand for the first time ever on November 2.

text: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope spotted the spectacle, which is a dwarf galaxy. It "resembles a July 4th skyrocket," complete with a "brilliant blazing head and a long, star-studded tail" Kiso 5639 is also known as a "tadpole" galaxy, a reference to its elongated shape. Such galaxies are common at far-off distances, but this one is a rare, (relatively) nearby example, NASA says."It’s a stage that galaxies, including our Milky Way, must go through as they are growing up," says Debra Elmegreen, an astronomer at Vassar College, who conducted detailed imaging of the galaxy. "The current thinking is that galaxies in the early universe grow from accreting gas from the surrounding neighborhood," she says in a statement. "This is a beautiful, up-close example of what must have been common long ago," Elme green says. "It�'s a beautiful example of how galaxies grow," she adds, "and it's a great way to celebrate the Fourth of July. It's also a great reminder of how fast the universe is growing," says ElmeGreen, who says galaxies must accrete gas from their surroundings. "And the rockets' red glare, the bombs bursting in ..." Ursa Major?! Just in time for Independence Day, astronomers released an image of a dazzling "fireworks display” full of reds, whites and blues.
label: SAFE

text: Harvey, the most intense rainfall event in U.S. history, stalled over southeast Texas and dropped more than three feet of rain over thousands of square miles in a matter of days. Researchers showed that in the wake of the storm, a form of evolution called spatial sorting exerted a greater influence on the evolution of J. haematoloma, commonly known as the red-shouldered soapberry bug. With natural selection, change plays out over decades or even millennia as traits become more common or less common depending on which individuals survive and reproduce. With spatial sorting, change occurs when species move into new territory, and traits are more common based on where individuals are at the leading edge of range expansion, the researchers say."This is an understudied and underappreciated form of evolutionary change that has emerged from the invasive species literature," said Rice University evolutionary biologist Scott Egan. "It could make a huge difference in the evolution" of organisms."With the profound and rapid changes we're seeing with the environment, movement is becoming critical for species' survival," Egan said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: South Carolina fends off Southeastern Conference rival Mississippi State for the biggest prize in women's college basketball. The Gamecocks led by as many as 14 points in the second half, then survived a Bulldogs charge to claim a 67-55 victory. Forward A’ja Wilson powered the Gamecock on both offense and defense as she finished with 23 points, 10 rebounds and four blocks. Mississippi State can hold onto the distinction of being the team that ended Connecticut’s 111-game winning streak as the Bulldogs prevailed in 64-62 in overtime during a Friday semifinal. The all-SEC national championship game between Mississippi State and South Carolina was the sixth time two teams from the same conference met for the tournament title. It was the third time two SEC teams played in the championship game ― Tennessee vs. Georgia in 1996 and Auburn vs. Tennessee in 1989. game was the first time that two first-timers met in the tournament final since 2005 when Baylor defeated Michigan State. South Carolina leads Mississippi State 19-16 in the all-time series and has a 10-game win streak in the rivalry that dates to Mississippi State”s last victory over South Carolina on Feb. 11, 2010. TheGamecocks trailed by two before they went on a 19-4 run to take control of the first half. But Mississippi State battled back despite foul trouble and a scoring drought of more than four minutes in the firsthalf. The Bulldogs grabbed momentum with a 9-0 run to slice into South Carolina's 14-point lead.

text: The average car sold in March was 25.4 mpg, a new record. Fuel economy has been improving all year — it’s up 0.4 percent since January. The absolute amount of fuel consumed by American cars and trucks fell 11 percent between 2004 (when fuel use hit a peak) and the end of 2012. The rates for 2012 distance driven roughly mirror the mid-1990s, and the fuel consumed is lower than in 1984 (when the University of Michigan”s figures begin) The University of California Transportation Center says it measured this “rebound effect’ back in 2007 and discovered “that it is not large.’” But the general consensus is that only about 10 percent of the gain in fuel economy is effectively lost due to an increase in driving, says Michigan’S Michael Sivak, a professor of automotive engineering at Michigan State University and a former member of the U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Energy and Resource Economics (E&E) The Jevons Paradox: Give people Energy Star air-conditioners and they’ll just turn them on more, a New Yorker writer says. It's human nature; people travel more when it's less painful to them, he says. But most don’t even know their fuel economy. And even if they did, they�’re unlikely to take advantage of it by covering more miles. It’d be better off saying that because Americans are heavier, they're hurting fuel economy gains.
label: SAFE

text: Scientists have uncovered that violent star collisions, known as kilonovae, have the potential to pose a catastrophic threat to our planet due to the lethal release of radiation. The collision of neutron stars, each containing a mass equivalent to approximately one billion tons within a mere teaspoon, results in a particle explosion capable of annihilating our planet's ozone layer. If a neutron star merger were to occur within around 36 light-years of Earth, the resulting radiation could cause an extinction-level event. The specific distance of safety and component that is most dangerous is uncertain as many of the effects depend on properties like viewing angle to the event, the energy of the blast, the mass of material ejected, and more,” Haille Perkins, a researcher at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, said. But Perkins also assured panic is not necessary — kilonova are “rare.”“There are several other more common events like solar flares, asteroid impacts, and supernova explosions that have a better chance of being harmful,’ Perkins said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: President Donald Trump tweeted that Stephen Curry was no longer welcome to the White House. Julian Zelizer: Trump has used his bully pulpit three times to attack prominent black sports figures. He says it is not at all surprising that sports figures have become the focus of Trump's ire. Zelizers: There are few places in America where black people are more visible and their voices more audible than in the NFL and NBA, and on ESPN. The backlash is fueled by the belief that, in return for million-dollar salaries and the fragile affections of many white fans, black figures are required to sacrifice their basic humanity and their right to participate in civic society, Zelizer says. The White House called for the firing of ESPN anchor Jemele Hill, who in a series of tweets had called the president a “white supremacist’s” Trump was speaking to this very sense of grievance in his follow-up tweet: If a player wants to disrespect the American Flag and should stand for the National Anthem, he or she should not be allowed to do something else to do with his or her time. If we think sports are as far removed from the plantation as we’d like, we�’re like plantation plantation owners, he says, as if sports weren’t already deeply political as American sports weren't already as deeply political, as Zelizer writes. The president of the U.S. should demand that sports athletes “stick out from time to time to point out that sports are not an acceptable arena for any discussion of social injustice’
label: SENSITIVE

text: Peggy Whitson has now spent a total of 665 days in space, including two previous ISS missions in 2002 and 2007-2008. Her space endurance record far surpasses the previous NASA record of 534 days, which was set by astronaut Jeff Williams last year. Globally, she’s now ranked eighth for the most amount of time spent in space. The top place belongs to another Russian, Gennady Padalka, who has spent 879 days off of Earth. Back in 2008, during her second ISS mission, Whits on became the first woman to command the space station. She was named commander again on her latest mission to the ISS. “I would definitely like to go to the moon or Mars or some other destination,” she said in April, when asked if she would be able to stay in space for much longer than the 288 days she spent on the ISS this time around. "I’m not sure if I will last that long, but I’ll give it my best," she said, adding that she hopes to continue her trailblazing ways in the future. "We’d sure place our bets on you, Peggy. 638 days inspace and the view is still amazing! Soaking up some sunset time in the cupola… pic.twitter.com/grVIRo3SmX #ICYMI," NASA tweeted after her landing on Saturday night. She's now the world's oldest spacewoman and the most experienced female spacewalker.
label: SAFE

text: If we continue business as usual and keep adding carbon to the atmosphere, we will cross over into temperatures that will make life on earth impossible. Rising temperatures and changing monsoon rainfall patterns from climate change could cost India 2.8 per cent of GDP and depress the living standards of nearly half the country’s population by 2050. It is increasingly becoming clear to policymakers that economic growth, social balance, and ecological well-being cannot be seen under the same lens. Broad claims about being green are not enough anymore. As Indian companies go global, brands will need to find new ways to compete and demonstrate their sustainable credentials. Can Indian brands demonstrate their sustainability credentials? Can we not just be known for delivering the greenest, most sustainable brands? If India is to lead the 21st century, we need leadership from Indian companies that is the right thing to do. The sprint is right. Not just setting NetZero targets but building NetZero to 2030. So, let's work together to build a low carbon economy.
label: SENSITIVE

text: More than 900 people registered for the 2014 Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill & Ecosystem Science Conference. Research to date has yielded some results about the impacts of spilled BP oil and the dispersants used on it. Oiled marshes are eroding. Overhangs of oiled coastal land are falling into bays. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has designated the Barataria Bay estuary as an estuary of national significance."Oil is still out there, and it's resistant and having an effect on the coast," says Nancy Rabalais, executive director of Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium or LUMCON in Cocodrie. "Our research, looking at conditions before, during and after the spill, is still evolving," she says. "Some areas were recovering from the spill. But in August 2012, Hurricane Isaac stirred everything up, so we've had re-oiling," says Rabalaes, who leads GoMRI's Coastal Waters Consortium. "We have a good, long set of data that allows us to tell whether oil is a factor," says another researcher, Dubravko Justic, a distinguished LSU oceanography professor. "When they build more river diversions to defend the coast, they will help Louisiana officials," says Vijay John, principal investigator of the C-MED-SMED Consortium for the Molecular Engineering Systems and Dispersant Systems, which is funded by GoMRI and Tulane University. The conference was held from Jan. 26 to 29 in Mobile, Alabama.

text: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has captured a stunning image of the Milky Way. The image shows a star-forming region called Sagittarius C that lies at the heart of the galaxy. The agency estimates that there are 500,000 stars in the picture. Scientists were able to identify never-before-seen details at the Milkyway's core. the image from Webb is stunning, and the science we will get from it is even better," Samuel Crowe, the principal investigator on the project, said in the press release. "Webb has provided us with a ton of data on this extreme environment, and we are just starting to dig into it," Crowe said in an interview with CNN. "The galactic center is a crowded, tumultuous place. There are turbulent, magnetized gas clouds that are forming stars, which then impact the surrounding gas with their outflowing winds, jets, and radiation," Rubén Fedriani, who worked on theProject, said. " understanding them better is like learning the origin story of much of the universe," he added.
label: SAFE

text: The Marine Stewardship Council (MSC) has unveiled two decades of transformative progress in Australian fisheries since 2000. In Australia, 28 MSC-certified fisheries, comprising 38 species, make up 52% of the total volume of wild-caught seafood. This achievement surpasses the MSC's global goal of over a third of global marine catch (by volume) to be MSC certified or engaged by 2030. MSC Program Director of Oceania and Singapore, Anne Gabriel, calls attention to the importance of sustainable fishing practices. She urges more stakeholders to contribute and participate in MSC fishery assessments to contribute to more robust fishery performance. The report underscores a collective endeavour driving more than 116 related to bycatch, ecosystem impact, and effective management. The ocean harbours 80% of planet's biodiversity, and over the past fifty years, fishing has emerged as the primary factor affectingmarine biodiversity. Ensuring sustainable fishing is essential for meeting the protein dietary needs of a growing global population and reducing the environmental impact.

text: The Polarimeter to UNify the Corona and Heliosphere (PUNCH) mission achieved an important milestone, passing its internal system integration review. PUNCH is a NASA Small Explorer (SMEX) mission that will integrate understanding of the sun's corona, the outer atmosphere visible during total solar eclipses, with the "solar wind" that fills and defines the solar system. SwRI is also building the spacecraft and three of the five instruments for PUNCH. The first of three Wide Field Imagers has also been delivered, and the remaining two are undergoing final integration and test. The mission is scheduled to launch in 2025 into a polar orbit formation, with four small suitcase-sized satellites scheduled to follow in 2023 and 2026. The PUNCH team includes the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, which is building the Narrow Field Imager, and RAL Space in Oxfordshire, England,. which is providing detector systems for four visible-light cameras. The team developed engineering models to finalize integration processes and test procedures.

text: AI systems that power chatbots usually come with guardrails to prevent generating unsavory content. But computer scientists and hackers have repeatedly shown it is possible to “jailbreak” LLMs by prompting them in creative ways. The London event highlighted the ways that the world’s most cutting-edge AI systems are still vulnerable to abuse. It came just one week ahead of the first AI Safety Summit, organized by the U.K. government, where global policymakers will convene with AI scientists to discuss the dangers of the fast-moving technology. The event at the Royal Society was co-organized by Humane Intelligence, an AI auditing non-profit, and Meta, which sent an observer to the event. Meta has open-sourced some of its AI systems including Llama 2, meaning it is able for people to use them without oversight by the company. It has faced criticism from some AI safety advocates, who say that releasing models publicly can allow bad actors to abuse them more easily.

text: Businesses often rely on promotions, discounts and low prices to attract and retain customers. Customers now demand fast, personalized, proactive service across channels. text: More than 150 startups are chasing an ambitious goal: meat that doesn’t require raising and killing animals that is affordable and tastes and feels like the meat we eat now. Unlike traditional agriculture, this process starts with cells. Wide adoption of meat from cells is nowhere near assured, however. There are scientific challenges, such as learning how to mimic the complex structure of steak. Government regulation is another obstacle. Only Singapore and the U.S. allow sales of cultivated meat. The Protein Problem is an AP series that examines the question: Can we feed this growing world without starving the planet? To see the full project, visit https://projects.apnews.com/features/2023/the-protein-problem/index.html. The most important thing is that this field move forward and start reducing the destruction to our environment associated with current animal agriculture techniques, a biomedical engineering specialist says. text: A European space lander reached Mars on Wednesday in what scientists hope will mark a major milestone in exploration of the Red Planet. Older European and U.S. spacecraft already in orbit relayed data of the lander’s six-minute descent. But the transmission stopped, leaving questions over what state the disc-shaped 577-kg (1,272 lb) Schiaparelli probe was in. “It is clear that these are not good signs,” said Paolo Ferri, the European Space Agency's (ESA) head of mission operations. However, the primary part of the mission, bringing the landers mothership into orbit around Mars to search for signs of life, was a success, the agency said. The primary goal of the ExoMars program is to find out whether life has ever existed on Mars. of the European-Russian program that launched SchiAParelli, is to deliver a European rover to Mars in 2020 from 2018, the second part of their Exo Mars mission. It will be the first with the ability to both move across the planet's surface and drill into the ground to collect and analyze samples, ESA said on Wednesday. It is currently some 35 million miles (56 million km) away from its nearest planetary neighbor Earth, and is a notoriously difficult task that has thwarted a single previous effort by Europe, most of Russia’S probes and given NASA trouble as well. The mission is expected to cost about 1.3 billion euros ($1.4 billion)

Patel is expected to undergo physical therapy and miss approximately 2-3 months of play. The team expressed confidence in backup players stepping up during the recovery period. "How did I feel about it?" former flight attendant Meredith Shay said in aninterview on ABC'sGood Morning America."Devastated, disappointed, sad. text: Australia's football chief James Johnson believes his country can help FIFA turn their new Club World Cup into a global success. Johnson believes though that once the new tournament, with 12 elite European clubs and eight top teams from South America, has made an impact in the USA, its prestige will be transformed. "We believe that we can help build that competition, take it to a new level, like what we saw with the Women's World Cup in Australia," he said. "I'm very excited by this," Johnson told AFP in an interview on Monday ahead of this week's Soccerex conference in Miami. "There's an opportunity there. 32 teams, 64 matches, played over one month. We've got the biggest teams in the world coming together," he added.

text: Parts of Queensland Australia have been battling a rat and mouse plague for months. A surge in the native rodent population has forced the rats to move coastwards in their search for more food. Many do not survive the trip, according to experts quoted in local media. The rats have also infested the neighbouring town of Karumba in the past few weeks. Some residents worry they will have an adverse effect on tourism in the area. The surge in rat population has been caused by a combination of ideal wet weather conditions for breeding and a bountiful harvest. More wet weather is expected for Queensland, with some people believe the worst is as yet to come. The plague has reached plague conditions not seen since 2011, Australia's national science agency said in a 2021 article. Some readers may find the following image and details disturbing. It shows heaps of dead rats piled up by the water, while flies and other insects swarm around them. Another clip shows a large number of them floating in the river. "We've heard there are still more that are coming," Jemma Probert, a fishing charter owner inKarumba, told AFP.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Invasive species benefit from extreme weather almost a quarter of the time, study finds. Local species are more likely to suffer negative consequences from the disasters. Invasive species cost more than $400 billion dollars a year in damages and lost income. UN panel says invasive species are increasing at an "unprecedented rate" globally. and play a significant role in 60 percent of all documented plant or animal extinctions. and declines of biodiversity threatening the well-being of people and planet. and these two processes may combine together to pose high threats to biodiversity under continuing global change, lead author Xuan Liu told AFP. and added in Nature Ecology & Evolution, published by the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, on Monday. The study was based on hundreds of previously-published studies on responses of 187 non-native and 1,852 native animal species to extreme weather patterns in different habitats. and was published by Nature Ecology and Evolution, in which Liu is a co-author, on behalf of the University of Beijing.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Andrea Dantas plays Frida Kahlo in a one-woman show at Brooklyn's BAM Fisher. The Brazilian-born writer, actor and dancer researched Kahlo's life for eight months. “Fragmented Frida,” directed by Renee Miller, runs until Sunday, April 16, in New York, BAM. The show's message is that there is nothing a person cannot overcome, even in the face of adversity.. ‘She overcame so much, so much. Her exceptional ability to turn vulnerability into strength,’ Dant as said of Kahlo. � ‘If the American people rebelled against everything that is wrong here, this would be a very different place.’” said Kahlo of the U.S. in the 1930s, when the country was at its lowest point in terms of women’s rights, she said. ”She had such a subtlety to her and a magnetism, she was a hopeless romantic,“ DantAs said of the painter. ’She was soft, she had a great sense of humor. She was not a victim. This is a woman who, when her leg was amputated, the first thing she did was custom-make a boot for herself. She painted it red so everyone could see what was happening to her. She had an amazing zest for life.” “Even then, she always said that women matter, that the LGBTQ community matters, that art matters. There have already been countless retrospectives, essays and films devoted to the life of Ms. Ms. Kahlo, and I hope to add my own perspective to the mix with a performance revolving around one of her many accomplishments.“

text: The LPGA decided a major tournament because a snitch of a golf fan notified the tour. The slightly errant ball placement happened on the 17th hole of Saturday’s ANA Inspiration. Tiger Woods weighed in on Twitter, stating that “viewers at home should not be officials wearing stripes.” Thompson, who appeared in tears at first, regrouped to force a playoff but lost to So Yeon Ryu, Golf magazine reported. The viewer reportedly emailed the complaint during Sunday's final round of the tournament in Rancho Mirage, California. It's difficult to picture such an incident happening in other games. Imagine, for instance, if fans watching the NCAA title basketball game between North Carolina and Gonzaga were allowed a chance to decide the outcome. Click here to read the LPGa's full statement on the incident and to watch the video of Lexi Thompson's ball placement on the hole that led to her penalty on the ANAInspiration website. The penalty was for improper ball placement, an incorrect scorecard and an incorrect putt on a short putt, according to the LpgA. The tournament went on to finish with a score of 8-under-par. It was the first major tournament of the year for Thompson, a two-time winner who was two strokes in the lead at the time of the penalty. She was penalized 4 strokes for the infraction and 2 for the scorecard violation, the L PGA said.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A new theory in cognitive neuroscience suggests that consciousness comes in a series of 400-millisecond "time slices" The theory suggests that our brains first process visual information from the environment while we're in an unconscious state, and then transfer it to our conscious awareness. The brain may then piece the individual frames together into an unbroken image of the world, the new "time slice theory" suggests. "We intuitively believe that we are directly aware of things at any moment in time," Dr. Frank Scharnowski says. "This is not the case" and is "nothing scary," he says of the theory's implications for our perception and consciousness. "The brain wants to give you the best, clearest information it can, and this demands a substantial amount of time," says study co-author Dr. Michael Herzog. "There is no advantage in making you aware of its unconscious processing, because that would be immensely confusing," Herzog says of our conscious experience of the outside world."We do not experience stimuli and objects during their actual presentation, but much later when they are rendered conscious," says one of the study's authors. "Such a representation is akin to the answer to the question of how were your holidays," says another of the paper's authors, "Although this is counterintuitive, it is nothing scary" "We can see the time difference when two bars are presented with a delay of 3 milliseconds," says the other study's author. "In contrast, conscious perception is much slower and can be delayed for several hundred milliseconds"
label: SENSITIVE

text: X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X will open Friday night at New York's Metropolitan Opera. The opera's creative team says nearly four decades have passed sinceXfirst came to the stage. Malcolm X's life – and his assassination in 1965 at age 39 – still loom large in popular consciousness. But the opera stage is the ideal vehicle to convey both the drama of his public life – as well as his richly emotional, interior journey, say the creators of X: The life and times ofMalcolm X, who was assassinated in 1965, says the opera's director, Robert O'Hara. "I always say there's no reason why Malcolm X became a leader. He had a sixth-grade education," says the director of X. "There is nothing that was just kind of even-keeled throughout. He was always evolving and changing," says composer Anthony Davis, who wrote the music for the opera. "Xis still an time for both characters and the audience to breathe and metabolize their feelings," says librettist Thulani Davis.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory in California are creating an instrument that will offer specific information on how fast the universe is growing. The Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument will create a map of over 30 million galaxies. But in order for that map to be precise, astronomers will have to correct for the problems created by all the dust particles in the Milky Way galaxy that impede their deep space investigations. To help with the DESI project, Berkeley researchers created the following detailed 3D animation showing dust that spans thousands of light-years in our home galaxy. The study was published this week in The Astrophysical Journal and was published by Berkeley Lab in a report published in a journal called Astrophysics and Space Research (ASR) It can give us a much more precise gauge of distances to faraway stars in the galaxy, like a galactic GPS,” the researchers said in a statement. “The light from those distant galaxies travels for billions of years before we see it,’” said Edward F. Schlafly in the Berkeley Lab statement, “but in the last thousand years of its journey toward us, a few percent of that light is absorbed and scattered by dust in our own galaxy. We need tocorrect for that.” The 3D map (seen above) was created by using data composed of separate sky surveys from telescopes on Maui and in New Mexico, resulting in 3D dust maps “many times better than anything that previously existed”
label: SAFE

text: George Preti, an organic chemist at the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, says the amount of odor you produce is largely based on your genetics. Different regions of the body produce their own strange molecular secretions and play host to different sorts of microbes. The reason certain odors are worse than others is because microbes become ecologically adapted to the environments that they are in. Despite popular belief, Preti says, eating spicy food, onions, curry, or garlic is not going to make your body produce more potentially smelly proteins. But certain foods can still make you smell worse: if pungent foods contain fat-soluble compounds that dissolve in your body fat, they’ll often get released in your sweat. So you won’t make more odor proteins, but you may add a note of garlic to your signature perfume. But your big takeaway should be this: you’re almost certainly less smelly than you think you are. “I’ve smelled so many people who come into the lab saying that they have the worst body odor in the world,” says Preti. ‘That would be an extremely unusual case.’ Humans tune out the smells we smell all the time. So if you do produce the most smelly body odor, you probably don�’s don�t really have your worst odor. And your nose has a front row seat to producing the odor, because they are not producing it.”
label: SAFE

text: Earth is speeding to 2.5-2.9 degrees Celsius of global warming since pre-industrial times. Carbon emissions from the burning of coal, oil and gas rose 1.2% last year. To have an even money shot at keeping warming to the 1.5 degree limit, countries have to slash their emissions by 42% by the end of the decade. The chance of keeping warming at or under 1. 5 degrees is about one-in-seven or about 14%, a U.N. report says. "It's going to take a massive and urgent shift to avoid these records falling year after year," a UNEP official says of the emissions gap. "This is just like a whisper. What will be in the future will be more like a roar," another UNEP director says of this year's warming record. "We are already seeing a change, an acceleration,” a report lead author Anne Olhoff of Denmark’s climate think tank Concito says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Gift exchanges are a big part of American Christmas culture, often with a variety of creative spins on the tradition. Depending on where you grew up, you may call this gift exchange game Yankee Swap, White Elephant or Dirty Santa. Versions of this tradition were around as early as 1901, when mentions of “swap parties” appeared in American publications. According to popular legend, the term “white elephant” is related to an old practice from kings of Siam (today, Thailand). If the king was dissatisfied with one of his subjects, he would gift them a rare albino elephant. In Thai and Buddhist cultures, white elephants are not snow-colored or pinkish, but rather more ruddy-colored, and have a sacred quality. This story of the white elephant appears to be more of a myth, though the definition of � “ white elephant’s” seems to be a more accurate one.‘Yankee Swap’ is more popular in New England, though plenty of people in other parts of the country use it to describe this kind of gift exchange. The folks at Dunder Mifflin in Scranton, Pennsylvania, turned their Secret Santa gift exchange into Yankee Swap in an iconic episode of ‘The Office.’ The origin of the name seems to date back to the 19th century, when “Yankees” allegedly had a reputation as constant traders looking to make a swap. If you believe the Civil War origin story, you might be of the mindset that Yankee Swap gifts are supposed to be “useful” or of higher quality than the ones in White Elephant.
label: SAFE

text: Michael Mann: Scientists suspect recent storms like Sandy and Haiyan exhibited characteristics outside the range of natural variation. Mann: The science is hinting that this storm may not have been so catastrophic in a world without warming. He says we can take drastic action now to ensure that we prevent a future where super typhoons are a way of life.
