text: Scott Havens, who has been CEO ofBloomberg Mediafor almost two years, has been hired by theNew York Mets. The exec will oversee business operations for the team, with a portfolio including pretty much everything but baseball. The position had been vacant since Sandy Alderson transitioned to a consulting role last year. Havens had been with Bloomberg since 2015 and was installed as Justin Smith’s successor as CEO after the exec left to co-create new media outlet Semafor. Prior to Bloomberg, Havens served in exec roles at Time Inc. and The Atlantic. The Cohens bought the Mets in 2020 and has made a number of aggressive player and manager moves aimed at returning the franchise to glory. Last season, the team finished with a record of 75-87, good for fourth place in the National League East. The Mets are in the midst of a rebuild, with the team hoping to make the playoffs for the first time since 2008. The team is in the middle of a seven-game winning streak.
label: SAFE

text: At least 29 people have been killed and more than 300,000 have fled their homes. The phenomenon has sparked turmoil in neighbouring states Kenya and Ethiopia. Scientists say climate change is causing more intense and more frequent extreme weather events, with the Horn of Africa especially vulnerable. “This cycle of flooding and drought is going to continue. And we’re going to see more and more of this unless we do something on a global scale,” Christophe Hodder, a climate security advisor at the United Nations Environment Programme told Al Jazeera. In Kenya, torrential downpours over the weekendkilledat least 15 people, while destroying 97 hectares (240 acres) of farmland and wiping out more than 1,000 livestock animals, the Kenya Red Cross Society reported Sunday. The flooding in Somalia is part of a regional deluge linked to ongoing weather patterns known as El Nino and the Indian Ocean Dipole — which impact ocean surface temperatures and cause extreme rainfall, experts say. In Ethiopia, thousands are also reportedly displaced in the Somali region of Ethiopia due to ongoing flooding.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Dinesh Lad says he will be the "richest person in the world" if India lift the World Cup. The former railway worker has coached dozens of players during a 30-year career. Rohit Sharma, Shardul Thakur and Suved Parkar are among those he has coached. Lad says: "I never took money from anybody (for cricket) I never took any money from any parent""It's been an absolute honour to see the love you are giving my son," says South African fast bowler Nakhaya Ntini, whose son was coached by Lad. "You are not doing it for the sake of being a coach, you are doing it in the love of the game," says India captain Rohit, 36, who is set to lead his country in a World Cup semi-final against New Zealand at Mumbai's Wankhede Stadium on Wednesday. The 36-year-old is the only man to have scored three double-centuries in one-day internationals.
label: SAFE

text: Best of Playground Festival 19 presented six of the best short plays created during Playground's 2014-2015 season. Cratchit examines what might happen if Ebeneezer Scrooge's time with the Ghost of Christmas Present didn't follow the path originally conceived by Charles Dickens. 42nd Street Moon presented a rare revival of Frank Loesser and George Abbott's hit, Where's Charley? The musical adaptation of Brandon Thomas's 1892 hit comedy entitled Charley's Aunt was a star vehicle for Ray Bolger, whose career as a song-and-dance man included the original Broadway productions of Life Begins at 8:40 (1934) and two hit musicals by Rodgers and Hart: On Your Toes (1936), and By Jupiter (1942). Although Bolger may be best known for his performance as the Scarecrow in 1939's The Wizard of Oz, this clip from 1941's hit film, Sunny, gives a good sense of his loose-limbed charm in the role of Charley Wykeham. In the musical, the actor playing Charley is kept on the run as he undergoes quick costume changes between his naturally masculine appearance as Charley and a highly feminized version of his aunt, "Charley's aunt" Once the gimmick is established, Charley finds himself suddenly financially challenged, including gaining access to several gold-digging old goats, including Jack Chesney's financially challenged father, who is rumored to be extremely wealthy.
label: SAFE

text: We have the solution to Wordle (#868) on November 3, as well as some helpful hints to help you figure out the answer yourself. The answer to today’s Wordle is … “Ardor” is a noun that refers to intense passion, enthusiasm, or fervor for something. Some popular starting words people have had good luck with are “adieu,’ “media,” “arise,�” and “radio.” Just make sure not to pick a word with double letters, or you’re wasting precious guesses. You never want to reuse any letters from a prior round that showed up as gray — you know they aren’t in the word. The aim here is to try to figure out which vowels the mystery word contains, then layer in common consonants and close in from there. The most important guess is your first, and the trick is to load up on vowels (A, E, I, O, and U).
label: SAFE

text: The Georgia Aquarium houses over 100,000 animals, representing 500 species, in 10 million gallons of water. A unique feature of the Aquarium is the Ocean Voyager exhibit which houses four Whale Sharks, the largest fish in the ocean. The Aquarium also takes part in the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Savvy program and only purchases sustainable seafood and encourages its guests to do the same. There were also two nice displays calling attention to the ocean plastics issue. On August 5, 2013, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Fisheries, a division of the U.S. Department of Commerce, denied a permit application filed in June 2012 to import 18 beluga whales to the United States from the Utrish Marine Mammal Research Station in Russia. In an article in the Atlanta Constitution: The Great White Whale Fight, Dr. Lori Marino, a senior lecturer in neuroscience and behavioral biology who has studied the effects of dolphin captivity for more than 20 years, isn't convinced of any of the educational benefits of captive dolphins. She says the show was well done and received well by the audience, if anything but did little to educate people about dolphins and their role in the oceans or their needs in the ecosystem. The Georgia Aqu aquarium is defiantly appealing the decision. Marine mammal controversy is not new, the protestors do not think that Aquariums should be forcing whales or dolphins to be born in captivity. The protestors do the show were quite well received by our visit. Our observation on our visit was that the audience did not notice a few times when the trainers struck the dolphins to get them to perform the way they wanted.
label: SENSITIVE

text: 40 beagles born into a life of lab testing in Spain found themselves homeless and in jeopardy of being euthanized. A plea for the beagles was sent out to rescues around the world. The Beagle Freedom Project, a rescue organization located in the U.S.A. stepped forward and assumed the hefty $100,000 responsibility of shipping the Spanish 40 to America safely. Ebbie, short for Ebenezer, had suffered inside the Lab for five years. He had tumors all over his body. He could not eat or drink. Doctors could only guess that these problems and conditions were possibly caused by residual toxins still in the body, from the years of labTesting. In the United States alone, some 70,000 beagles are still being used for animal testing. Do you have a Tail of Hope? We'd love to hear it! Visit us at the Tail of Survival website or tell us your story at CNN.com/TailofSurvival. To follow the progress of these dogs and more follow The Beagles Freedom Project on Facebook and on Twitter at @BeagleFreedomProject. If you feel moved to help, you can make donations via the website or on Facebook at the BeagleFreedom Project. We’d love to see it at the tail of Survival? Visit us and tell us about your story! Visit the Tail Of Survival website at the CNN. com/T tailofsurvival website or Twitter at the @TailOfSurvival website.

text: Ice is a lifeline for billions of people who depend on it for drinking water, agricultural irrigation and hydropower generation. Under the current global warming trajectory, up to 75% of Himalayan ice could be lost this century. Scientists are expecting 0.5 metres of sea rise (1.6 feet) by 2100, potentially putting 150 million people in harm’s way. In Asia, almost 2 billion people rely on meltwater from mountain glaciers and snow for irrigation, drinking water and electricity generation. The report stresses the need for rapid emissions reductions, and identifies the COP28 climate summit as the platform for a new level of global ambition to be held in the UAE this month. The 2015 Paris Agreement committed the international community only to limit temperature rise "to well below 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels " and to "pursuing efforts" to limiting increase to 1.5 degrees. But the researchers say a tighter limit is necessary to prevent “irreversible” ice loss.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Scientists are concerned about the silencing of scientists working for the federal government. "Ideological assertions have been crowding out evidence in public and private debates and in policy," says Rush Holt, CEO of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Scientists and supporters are planning a March for Science April 22 in Washington, D.C., to protest against the Trump administration's anti-science policies. The March is scheduled to take place on April 22 at the National Mall in Washington DC, the National Museum of American History and the Smithsonian Museum of Science and Industry. It will also take place in New York City, where the American Museum of Nature and Science will be holding its annual meeting on April 14-15. It is the first time the museum has hosted a climate change conference in more than a decade, and it is expected to draw thousands of scientists and other experts from around the world. The conference will also address the effect of immigration restrictions on scientific knowledge, among other issues, and how to address their concerns in the Donald Trump administration. about 1,000 scientists are expected to speak at the AAAS conference, including some who worked for the Clinton and Obama administrations. "The role of science is to speak truth to power," says AAAS President Barbara Schaal. "It's ugly and it's getting uglier," says science adviser Neal Lane, who was science adviser in the Clinton administration, adding: “It’s getting Uglier.’“The bill is really an attempt to squelch … and intimidate climate scientists”
label: SENSITIVE

He spoke enthusiastically about competing in Europe, taking his first airplane and train rides, and visiting the Olympic museum in Lausanne, Switzerland. He has since become the first openly gay U.S. figure skater to compete at the games. The 28-year-old helped Team USA clinch a bronze medal in the figure skating team event Monday in Pyeongchang, South Korea. He will compete in the men’s single skating event Friday, and has a further shot at gold in the event on Sunday, if he wins his bronze medal on the ice in the team event. text: Wendy Suzuki, 51, is a neuroscientist at New York University. Her research focuses on understanding the effects of exercise on the brain. Aerobic exercise can boost the generation of new neurons in the hippocampus. The hippocampus is one of the primary targets of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s. Building up the hippocampus over a lifetime could potentially delay effects of diseases. Another brain area heavily affected by aerobic exercise is the prefrontal cortex. This is an area in charge of high-level cognition, executive functions, decision-making and attention. Walking, aerobic exercise and high-intensity interval training can improve your mood. But unlike memory, improvements with attention are more acute and come faster. Jogging, biking and running are all good options for getting a boost in the prefrontal Cortex. The best evidence for hippocampal neurogenesis is continuous aerobic exercise. “You have to get your heart rate up. A good 45-minute workout is the best option if you want to boost your memory,” Suzuki said. She said. ‘The thing that was really exciting and appealing is that this was the kind of research that could immediately be applied to helping people live their life better,’ she said, “but once I made the decision I knew it was the right one.” She also thought it was a particularly good decision because the results of her work could quickly lead to tangible benefits. The research is not fully known, but it seems that the. prefrontal cortex is actually relaxing during intense physical activity, enabling it to work at full speed.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The New Shepard rocket and capsule blasted off from a launch site in West Texas. The capsule, which was flying autonomously, parachuted to a nearby site and was recovered. Saturday's flight marks the third successful launch-and-land for the rocket. Blue Origin and Elon Musk's SpaceX are among a handful of companies working to develop rockets that can fly themselves back to Earth so they can be refurbished and flown again. The company expects to begin crewed test flights of the New Shepard next year and begin flying paying passengers as early as 2018."Congrats Blue team on today's (flight)!" Jeff Bezos wrote on Twitter after Saturday's test flight. "Perfect booster landing," Bezos said on his Twitter account after the launch. "Congrats blue team onToday's ( flight)!" he said on Twitter. 'I'm so proud of you," Blue Origin said on its Twitter account following the test. "We're going to fly you into space!" the company said on a statement after the flight. 'We're not going to let you down,' Blue Origin added on a Twitter post after the rocket landed. 'The mission was a success,' the company added. 'It's a big step forward for us,' Bezos said. 'This is a great step for the space industry,' he said, 'and for our industry.' 'We've got a long way to go, but we're getting closer,' he added. "I'm looking forward to the future," he said.
label: SAFE

text: Over 400,000 people in Crimea were left without power on Monday, after hurricane force winds and heavy rains battered the Russian-annexed peninsula over the weekend. One local official said a man on the peninsula's southern coast was killed, according to early reports, whilewind speedsof over 140 kilometers per hour (about 90 mph) were recorded in some places. Train traffic on Russia's Black Sea coast was disrupted after rail tracks fell into the sea, while oil loading at the port of Novorossiysk was suspended. About 500marine animalsin Sevastopol's aquarium were killed during the storm, which flooded one of its floors, the city's Moscow-installed governor said. More than two thousand towns and villages on the Ukrainian mainland were alsoleft without power due tobad weather on Monday.Ukraine's energy grid has been targeted systematically by Russian forces since Moscow's assault began last year, and officials have warned strikes could intensify over winter. The content is provided for information purposes only.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Memorials to victims of Stalinist repression in Russia are disappearing or being vandalised. At least 18 monuments to victims as well as foreign soldiers who fought in World War Two have been reported stolen or vandalised since February 2022. This is taking place alongside a resurgence in Stalin's popularity. In July, a survey by independent pollster the Levada Centre suggested that 63% of Russians had a favourable attitude towards the Soviet leader. In August the private Russkiy Vityaz (Russian Knight) Foundation inaugurated an 8m-high statue of Stalin in the town of Velikiye Luki. Its website argues these monuments are crucial given that Russia is fighting "a real Patriotic war" The "Great Patriotic War" is how Russians describe the 1941-1945 war between the USSR and Nazi Germany. The Kremlin regularly compares Russia's invasion of Ukraine to World War two. The reason behind his rising popularity is not certain but Russian propaganda justifying the war with Ukraine has also glorified its Soviet past.
label: SENSITIVE

text: British music retailer HMV returns to the iconic site of its former flagship store in central London on Friday. The re-opening of the historic shop comes as authorities fight back against a wave of so-called American candy stores. The one-time HMV store at 363 Oxford Street was opened in 1921 by English composer Edward Elgar and later helped propel The Beatles to fame. But in recent years, the capital's main shopping thoroughfare has struggled as big department stores such as Debenhams and House of Fraser shut. The store front will also see the return of the company logo -- the image of a dog listening to its late master's voice coming from a gramophone, HMV stands for "His Master's Voice" and is located on the corner of Oxford Street and St Paul's Street. The new HMV represented "exactly what we want Oxford Street to be all about -- an experience beyond traditional retail," says Westminster Council's Geoff Barraclough, of Westminster Council.
label: SAFE

text: Neil deGrasse Tyson tweeted that flat-Earthers are bad influences on their fans and supporters. The astrophysicist said that in a free country, it doesn't matter if you think the world is flat, provided you don’t ascend to become head of NASA. Tyson’s comments reflect another type of denialism that exists in a very influential place in America: the White House. President Donald Trump has called climate change a hoax and has proposed deep cuts to NASA”s budget for climate-change research in favor of space exploration. The tweets were posted after he published an essay titled, “Science in America,” arguing for just that. “Politics is not a foundation on which you base your science,’ Tyson wrote in his essay. ‘Science is a foundation ... lest you undermine a functioning, informed democracy.’ “ Show me a Nation with a science-hostile government, and I'll show you a society with failing health, wealth, & security.” “If kids who are fans of pop-stars think Earth is flat because they do, then it exposes a flaw in the concept of Role Models.“ “Show me a nation with a Science-Hostile Government, & I'll Show you a Society with failing Health, Wealth, & Security” — Neil deGrasses Tyson, in a series of tweets on Friday, March 8. The tweet was in honor of Earth Day and the coinciding March for Science.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Weather forecasters have predicted that storms could severely impact flights and road trips ahead of the holiday period. Severe thunderstorms are forecasted to intensify in the Southern Plains during Sunday afternoon and evening, expanding eastward into the Southern United States by Monday's end. AAA, which monitors holiday travel, anticipates that 55.4 million Americans will travel over 50 miles for Thanksgiving between November 22 and November 26. Early travelers departing on Monday along the Eastern Seaboard and into the Great Lakes region may experience relatively lighter rain and thunderstorms. Ski resorts in the interior western states, such as Nevada, Utah, Idaho, and Wyoming, can expect favorable conditions with the potential for mountain snow on Thursday and Friday. The government is looking into the legality of transferring unclaimed funds of the Sahara-Sebi Refund Account to the Consolidated Fund of India, with a provision to refund investors who stake claims later. Nawaz Modi, the estranged wife of Gautam Singhania, has sought three quarters of the industrialist’s net worth, reported at $1.4 billion, for their two daughters and herself.
label: SENSITIVE

text: So That I May Carry You With Me is an exquisitely detailed pastiche at the Daum Museum in Sedalia, Missouri. She unflinchingly discusses the diaspora that has our country teetering between xenophobia and open borders. A bit uneven in places, Hartman's work underscores the spiritual and human accountability we all face as one person, one planet. Icons from a Broken World is an internal gallery displaying eight portraits of refugees. The addition of glass beads to the portraits, painstakingly applied, highlight the subjects flatness. She covers the gamut of refugee imagery but in their sittings all appear the same; distraught, vacant, drawn. Hartman understands pastiche and mosaic and these paintings could be redone more abstractedly. She is aware of humankind's temporary state in transit, always in flux. But Hartman manages to boil down the hardened shell to reveal the sweet fruit of spirituality that encompasses the thoughts of all of us. She does both; she presents a spiritual reconciliation while asking us to stare into the abyss with her. She's a storyteller in a more cryptic manner. Returning to ideas that Hartman knows best, Alphabets and Earth: The Clay Letters is a series of cryptic iconography that reveals the concept of strangers in a strange land. Created in a style of small, intimate propositions on a larger scale, anything would lose their immediacy for these are nothing short of hypnotic prose. I'm disappointed as Hartman’s craftsmanship is otherwise exceptional.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Sue Waterfall said her road had flooded every year for five years. She said sewage had washed into the gardens and it left her "fed up, depressed" and "very stressed" Anglian Water and developer Beal Homes said the surface water flooding was designed to prevent homes flooding. They said the management of surface water was "working as intended" and had been approved by North Kesteven District Council and Lincolnshire County Council at the planning application stage. "I have got to the point now where I want my flat to flood because then they will have to put me in emergency accommodation and it will get me away from here. I'm not coming back," Ms Waterfall told BBC Radio Lincolnshire. The road on Pitsford Close will flood when rain is extremely heavy or sustained, when the attenuation isn't enough, they said. "The threshold levels of the property are set substantially higher than the road for this reason," they added. The developer said this included enabling "some rainwater to back up onto the site infrastructure in the event of extreme rainfall"
label: SENSITIVE

text: George R.R. Martin called 2016 a year of "death, death, and more death" in a blog post on Tuesday. The author and actress Carrie Fisher died on Tuesday after suffering a heart attack last week. Martin also paid tribute to Richard Adams, the author of Watership Down, who died at the age of 96 this week. “Please,” he added, “let this wretched year come to an end.’“I told you so. You did, George,’ he wrote earlier this year, when the world naively believed it had witnessed the apex of 2016’s misery. "Winter is coming," he wrote on the same LiveJournal. "I toldYou so.” "The world is poorer tonight," he added of Fisher and Adams. "A wonderful actress, a great writer,“ Martin wrote of the two icons. � “A wonderful, beautiful, talented actress, and a strong, witty, outspoken woman. ... probably forever ...” “This year just keeps getting worse and worse," he said of 2016. "It's been a bad year, but it's also been a good year, and I'm looking forward to the new year." "I'm glad I'm in Santa Fe," Martin said, "because that's where I'm going to be for the next few months." "It will be a long, cold winter, but I'll be glad when it's over"
label: SENSITIVE

text: IOC decides against immediately lifting Russia's Olympic suspension after fresh doping violations. Russians have been competing as neutral athletes at the Games, their Olympic status suspended. IOC said two Russian doping violations during the Pyeongchang Games had marred an otherwise clean report card. Russian delegation chief Stanislav Pozdnyakov has said that the prospect of flying the flag at Sunday’s closing ceremony meant more to his athletes than winning medals. The suspended Russian Olympic Committee (ROC) said it hoped to return to the Olympic family in the coming days. on Sunday: “I’m very disappointed,” said Elena Valbe, president of the Russian cross-country skiing federation. “It is difficult for me to understand how any figure skater, hockey player or skier can win gold and stand on the podium without their flag,’ said former Olympic ice hockey champion Igor Larionov. The lawyer for Grigory Rodchenkov, the former Russian doping laboratory director who turned whistleblower, said “cooler heads” at the IOC had prevailed. ‘Thomas Bach was a drowning man, but finally cooler heads within the IOC threw him a life preserver,“ Jim Walden said in a statement. "The acrimony caused by Bach's mismanagement should be his undoing," Walden added, referring to the IOC's decision on December 5th to institute the suspension for years of drug scandals. The IOC had said it would lift Russia's suspension for the closing ceremony on condition its athletes met a strict code of conduct.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A new book, Nabokov’s Favorite Word Is Mauve, runs the numbers on bestselling and classic literature. Author Ben Blatt found that James Patterson uses 160 clichés per 100,000 words. Elmore Leonard hates exclamation points and James Joyce loves ‘em. Blatt also found that John Steinbeck and Willa Cather both mention weather in the first sentence of their books. The bottom users include Ernest Hemingway, John Updike, and Chuck Palahniuk, Blatt writes. The stats might not tell us anything particularly world-shaking about the authors we love, but there's an inherent fascination about seeing the habits and stylistic patterns of great writers broken down into precise parts. Check out graphics and more stats from Blatt on Publishers Weekly on his book, "Nabokov's Favorite Word is Mauve," which is published by Simon & Schuster at $16.99. For more information on the book, go to www.simonandschuster.com/nabokv/favourite-word-is-mauve, or call the author's office at 1-800-273-8255 or go to http://www.samaritans.org/nabbokov/favorites-word/mauves. text: Sonny Grosso and NYPD partner Eddie Egan on The French Connection set March 17. Grosso describes their unique relationship when they would annually lead the NYPD with the most drug arrests. Egan mastered disguises such as a deaf mute, hotdog vendor, a priest, and many others. "Eddie deserves a lot of credit for the success of the film, he was a real tough guy," says director William Friedkin, who won an Oscar for directing The French Connections, a 5-time Oscar winning movie about Egan and Grosso's real-life exploits. "If you can't be roused by this pipe band, hello, check your pulse!" says Grosso of the Pipes and Drums band at the St. Patrick's Day Parade in New York City on March 17, 2013. "We were like a husband and wife -- we'd spend hours on end on stakeout, eating stale pizza and drinking cold coffee," Grosso says of the late Egan, who he calls the bravest police officer he ever met. "He was probably the most fearless officer I ever saw. There was never any standing back with him. He was a character, way out there but a great cop and very effective," adds Grosso, a retired NYPD officer who became the youngest first grade detective on the force in the '50s and '60s, when 40% of NYPD officers were Irish-Americans. "You can hear Irish brogues being spoken alongside Italian-American officers," he says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The AI Pin uses voice commands with AI to answer questions, translate languages, and play music. The technology is impressive, even mind-blowing. The only downside is that you look like an absolute weirdo, talking to a fruit in the middle of the grocery store. But ifApple starts adding AI to Siri— which seems pretty likely — that feature won't be unique, says CNN Tech's John Sutter. The Pin will go on sale at $699, but Sutter says he doesn't think it would be very useful in a public setting, like in a Trader Joe's produce aisle or on a walk with your child. It's very cool, and obviously, as someone who loves new tech and weird gadgets, I want one. But I don't want to be the person muttering to my shirt about protein content at the store at the time. I'm not looking to get rid of my phone and don't think the Pin could really do that anyway, Sutter writes.
label: SAFE

Keegan-Michael Key, of "Key and Peele," will play Horatio in his first New York stage performance. He was classically trained as a Shakespearean actor before veering into improv comedy, so our expectations are pretty high. The play will be directed by Gold, who won a Tony for his direction of Broadway's “Fun Home’ The production was expected to run this year at Theater for a New Audience's Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn, but the show was pulled in June 2016 because of artistic differences between Gold and artistic director Jeffrey Horowitz. Now, the play, having controversially switched venues and artistic directors, is officially back on the docket and will run at New York's Public Theater in June and September. The show will run for 10 weeks. It will be Gold's first time directing a Shakespeare play on the Broadway stage, and his second time directing on the national tour of "Fun Home" He also directed the Tony-winning production of "A Man Walks On To a Hot Tin Roof" on Broadway in 2013. text: Marcel Duchamp is either revered as a godlike figure of contemporary art or disdained as a charlatan. He paved the way for pop art, environmental art, assemblage, installation art and conceptual art. He was a champion of independent thinking. He failed at art school, in printmaking and with painting. Yet, he was not deterred. He continued to question, "What is art?" and "How do we see art?" He changed what we call art and how we see it. The Duchamps' source of art has found in the mind of the artist, he says. He says, "Duchamp was a controversial figure with contradictions. By this bold articulation, he changed what he called 'retinal' art and proposed an intellectual art, what today we call conceptual art" He says he sees an overuse of art proclaiming a DuchAMPian lineage or ideal that I am certain to provoke strong opinions from people smarter than I. The products that call themselves works of art copying ideas and images put forth previously are far too numerous, too sporadic and have been done again and again. Duchamping was compelled or obsessed to not fall into complacency or predictability; he challenged himself to not repeat and reuse the same thing. He disliked reproduction and secondhand experience, and from his failures, rebellion or both, he emerged successful. He said, "I am simply and purely an art appreciator. I am not an art historian or art scholar"
label: SAFE

text: Naveen Rao is the CEO of Databricks, which bought his startup MosaicML for $1.3 billion. He says generative artificial intelligence has a monetization problem. He likens it to the issue that crushed Napster, the 2000s-era music-sharing platform. Rao thinks of Mosaic's technology as a kind of democratization of generative AI, and he's brought that ethos toDatabricks. The more people building generative-AI technology, the better, Rao says. "What's interesting about technology is there's always some element of it that can be used in nefarious ways," he says, "but the way to stop that is by having more people armed with the same tools and being able to use them for good""We build tools that enable companies to differentiate their AI from everyone else's and leverage their data uniquely," Rao says of his company's open-source-trained LLM named Dolly. "That needs to be respected," Rao said of copyrighted materials.

text: Rising sea temperatures due to climate change are forcing oyster farmers in France's southwest to take a break from summer maturation. Scientists have found that because of fast-evaporating water, the salt concentration has become too high between early June and late August. Human consumption of oysters goes back thousands of years. They come in a wide variety of flavours and textures depending on water salinity, alkalinity, mineral content and nutrition. text: David Berglas was one of the most influential magicians of the 20th Century. Also known as the International Man of Mystery, he was the first magician to have his own programme on British TV, Meet David Berglas, in 1954. His son Marvin said: "My father was a giant in the magic fraternity, known for his originality, creativity and showmanship" He was born to Jewish-German parents who fled the country when the Nazis took power in the 1930s. After the war, when he was involved with US military intelligence, he ended up in Bradford where he studied textiles, according to the Jewish Bradford heritage group. He was appointed MBE in 2018 for his services to magic and psychology. The Magic Circle, seen as the most famous magic society in the world, confirmed Berglas died in London on Friday night. He had a second television series in the 1980s where he entertained celebrities, including Omar Sharif, Christopher Lee and Britt Ekland. text: The UN Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic Pollution will take place from today until Sunday November 19. The goal is to develop a legally binding agreement, finalized in 2024, to address the full life cycle of plastics. Involving 175 nations, the treaty aims to transform plastic waste management, paving the way for new technologies and industries. It's worked before with the ozone layer andacid rainand it can work again with plastic. The UN treaty will usher in transformative regulations on waste management and reduce the use of single-use plastics. It will also speed up the removal of harmful chemicals from product supply chains. If we can get a global agreement on this, we have a real opportunity to significantly reduceplasticwaste for a sustainable future. The treaty is set to be finalised in 2024 and its implementation to be problematic to as industry as well as the treaty and its Implementation Committee are set to work on the treaty's implementation and implementation. The negotiations are taking place at the UN Environment Programme headquarters in Nairobi.

text: More than 500 migrants rescued in the Atlantic Ocean off Spain's Canary Islands. Number of people arriving on the archipelago so far this year neared an all-time record posted in 2006. Spain's Interior Ministry said on Thursday that a total of 30,705 undocumented migrants had reached the Canary Islands in the first 10 months of this year. The islands have become the main destination for migrants from Senegal and other African countries trying to reach Spain, fleeing conflict or seeking a better life. The Spanish government said it would create additional emergency accommodation for some 3,000 migrants in military barracks, hotels and hostels. The Canary Islands accounted for the bulk of the 43,290 undocumented migrants arriving in Spain by sea last year, according to the Interior Ministry. The archipelagos lies around 100 km (60 miles) off Africa's west coast and are popular with migrants fleeing conflict and seeking abetter life. It is estimated that around 2,000 people have died trying to make the crossing since September.

Asia-Pacific (APAC) is expected to witness the highest growth rate .The region, led by China, Japan, Australia, and Australia, is growing rapidly in the quantum computing market. text: Cassini, the first spacecraft to orbit Saturn, ended its mission at 7:55 a.m. EDT (1155 GMT) It entered the gas giant’s crushing atmosphere at about 70,000 miles an hour (113,000 km per hour) The data took 86 minutes to reach NASA antennas in Canberra, Australia. “Farewell Cassini, how far you’ve come. On this eve, in fiery death, Saturn & you are one. VIP (Vaporize In Peace): 2004-2017," astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson said in a Twitter post‏ late on Thursday. The spacecraft has produced 450,000 images and 635 gigabytes of data since it began probing Saturn and its 62 known moons in July 2004. The end of Cassini's odyssey was met with applause, hugs and tears from NASA officials after its final transmission was received, according to video footage on the space agency’  website.. The final images from our nearly 20 years in space are arriving. Unprocessed images are available at: https://t.co/8r5YwwIKVp #GrandFinale pic.twitter.com/46ivtDAdqd Cassini’S final dive ended a mission that gave scientists a ringside seat to the sixth planet from the Sun. Since the spacecraft was running low on fuel, NASA crashed it into Saturn to avoid any chance the spacecraft could someday collide with Titan, Enceladus or another moon.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers found that Homo sapiens swapped DNA with a mysterious group of hominids known as Denisovans. Scientists managed to trace DNA of the Denisovan to some Melanesians in 2016. But after a new DNA survey of humans, scientists were surprised to discover a new distinct set of Denisovan ancestry among some modern East Asians. This Denisovan DNA is more closely related to the sample from the fossils discovered in Siberia, according to the study published in the journal Cell. The discovery demonstrates that there were at least two distinct populations of Denisovaans living in Asia, and likely somewhat geographically distant. It's a definite third interbreeding event, adding to the previously known Denisovan and Neanderthal mixtures, said Harvard DNA researcher David Reich, who was not involved in the study. He said other scientists using a similar DNA survey method might discover additional cross-breeding. “I am sure there are others,” he told the Washington Post. The study was published in Cell, a journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which is a division of the Association for Research in the Social Sciences and Human Behavior, and the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America. It was published by the journal's editor-in-chief, David Weinberger, on November 6. It is the first of its kind and is published online by the American Society for the Study of Human History, which was previously published on November 7, 2013. The journal is part of the Division of Social and Behavioral Sciences.
label: SAFE

text: Sphagnum divinum is actively evolving in response to hot, dry conditions. The peat releases carbon into the atmosphere as a greenhouse gas, further accelerating the pace of warming. The database and analytical method developed at ORNL will support biologists looking to understand the essential compounds that make up Sphagnum mosses. This information will help reveal how plants respond to a changing world. The work has been published inBioinformatics, a journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Mathematical Theory and Science (AAAM) and the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) The research was conducted at the Department of Energy's Oak Ridge National Laboratory and the University of California, San Diego. The results of the study were published in the journal Bioinformatic. The study was funded by the U.S. Dept. of Energy and the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and was conducted by the National Science Foundation (NSF) and UC Berkeley.
label: SAFE

text: The IRS has sounded the proverbial alarm bell over transactions involving charitable art donations and inflated appraisals. The IRS might encounter several problems in the realm of art donations if it does nothing more than roll out its standard procedures. A key issue with all charitable donations is value; things can get downright complex when it comes to gifts of art. This is because art, by its very nature, is unique. It might be more accurate to say that art, at least when it came to its value, is in the eye of the Internal Revenue Service (“IRS”). The IRS often does not take the donor at his or her word with respect to valuation; it has its own specialized groups to handle this. It has an internal team of appraisers that responds to anticipatory valuation requests by taxpayers and supports the IRS during tax audits, appeals, and litigation. It also relies on outside help, Art Advisory Panel. That is a group of up to 25 experts who, according to IRS Publication 5392, meet regularly, discuss pending valuation issues.
label: SAFE

text: A. Duvall, 47, moved from San Marcos, California, to Paducah, Kentucky, in 2021. She became disabled in 2016 and was receiving $1,400 a month in Social Security Disability Insurance. Around 818,000 former Californians left for other states between 2021 and 2022, compared to just 475,800 moving in, according to US Census migration data. Many cited the state'shigh cost of livingand crowded infrastructure as reasons for making the move east. But some residents living in states like Tennessee and Kentucky previously told Insider the influx of wealthier residents has contributed to rising prices in the state.. "I probably should have been born here instead of California," Duv all said. "California is almost the polar opposite of Kentucky, and in a lot of ways, it is" "I'm not going to bring my ways here and try to make people change," she said of her new life in Kentucky. "My thing is, either you adjust to Kentucky, or you leave"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Henry David Thoreau's phrase, "In wildness is the preservation of the world," launched a thousand calendars, mugs, T-shirts, and bumper stickers. Today the world looks very different. The defining environmental challenge is climate change. Climate change means there is no "wild" place, nowhere that human beings have not changed. The environmentalism that was defined by wildness/wilderness has drawn criticism for being elite, mainly white, male-centered, nostalgic from the start, and indifferent to most of the adult and workaday world. It turns out, too, that an Anthropocene ThOREau is more than wishful thinking. It is a lot of baby to toss out with the pre-Anthropocene bathwater. It was John Muir, the founder of the Sierra Club and a giant publicist of giant, wild landscapes, who switched Thoreaux's "wildness" to literal wilderness. He was hopelessly tied to trackless, depopulated places - the kinds of places he hardly saw or wrote about during a lifetime in New England. Turns out that wilderness isn't in his works as he works as his new new friend, as he does with his bean-field, he writes. It's a new era in Earth's history: the Anthropocene, the age when humanity becomes a force in the planet's development. It means we have take responsibility for a world we partly create, says Julian Zelizer, a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A new study shows dolphins use vocalizations to solve complex problems. Scientists can't say for certain that dolphins have what humans call a language. The findings suggest vocalizations may play a much larger role in efforts that require cooperation. The study was conducted at a facility in Florida that offers swim-with-dolphins experiences to students. in Key Largo, Florida, is one of the most popular swim- with-dolphin facilities in the U.S., with more than 20,000 students participating each year, according to the Dolphins Plus organization. The organization says it has more than 50 research projects related to acoustics, behavior and cognition, and is home to some of the world's most famous dolphin sanctuaries, including SeaWorld and SeaWorld. The facility also offers several programs to swim with captive dolphins, experiences that start at $150 per person, including "Dolphin Swam with Me" and "Swim with a Dolphin," which is available at SeaWorld's Florida Aquarium, which is open to the public for $50 per person. text: American artist Doug Aitken's work is being shown in three major European galleries this summer. A show of new work at Victoria Miro in Mayfair is focused on "Eyes closed, wide awake (Sonic Fountain II)," a sculpture made up of water and sound. Schirn Kunsthalle in Frankfurt will give the entire gallery space over to four film installations, related sculptures and a sound installation. Late June sees the only international edition of "Station To Station," a 30-day living exhibition, where art is spontaneously created at the venue by the participants that he has bought together for his temporary residency. The Barbican will show "Station to Station: the Feature Film" in its UK public premiere, a collection of 62 one-minute-long films recording what happened in the project's earlier incarnation in 2013. The art that occurred at each point -- Ed Ruscha exploring the American landscape, Beck performing with a gospel choir in the desert etc. -- makes up a snapshot of a particular moment in American art and highlight exactly where A itken sits in relation to it. This is a very modern portrait of the artist, Part-curator, part-patron, this is avery modern portraits of a modern artist, part curator, part patron. The exhibition will run from June 12 - September 27th, at the Barbican, London, June 27th- July 26th, and July 9-September 27th at the SchirN Kunstalle, Frankfurt.

Others charged in the case include renowned businessman Osman Kavala, academic Tayfun Kahraman and journalist Cigdem Mater. text: Polish-American artist Agata Oleksiak is known for her experimental yarn creations. Olek's current project will consist of 50 portraits of women who changed American history. The artist will travel from state to state until 2020, inviting local community members to help create each work. She plans to honor women who are significant to each state, hopefully illuminating some lesser-known heroines who have not been sufficiently recognized on a national stage. The first image was hung in early May, depicting abolitionist Harriet Tubman. Susan B. Anthony’s portrait, currently in the works, will be revealed later in the month. The project is open to the public, and Olek hopes to create at least one portrait in all 50 states by the end of the year. She described her experience working with local crocheters in Rochester as “incredibly powerful,” adding that she “broke her rule” by choosing two subjects by choosing Harriet and Susan. “I couldn’t choose, I had to do both,’” Olek said of choosing Tubman and Anthony. ‘We’re living in a time when people are stuck to their computers. I’m getting people together. I want to get people out of their homes, out oftheir habits.’ Olek told HuffPost in a phone call that she has been crocheting since she was born, who worked late nights that creeped into mornings. She describes working with fathers who had never crocheted before to learn to adapt to her project.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Alpine skiing team event makes its Olympic debut in Pyeongchang this week. Lindsey Vonn is the latest high-profile athlete to say she probably won't be taking part. The inaugural team event is scheduled for Saturday as the climax to the program. It will bring mixed sex competition, knockout racing and parallel skiing to the Olympic Alpine slopes for the first time. The team event, an attempt by the governing International Ski Federation to refresh the Alpineprogram, will be contested by 16 teams on a knockout basis with the winners of the final round taking gold. The men's downhill champion Aksel Lund Svindal, the men’s downhill champion, and Kjetil Jansrud have headed back to Europe after the completion of their individual events. Austria's Marcel Hirscher, who has claimed two gold medals, ruled out competing for Austria before the start of the Olympics because he felt it would compromise his bid to win a seventh successive World Cup overall title. The 28-year-old had said competing in the team event would allow him insufficient time to get to Slovenia for the resumption of the World Cup next week. American Teg Ligety said he would race in the event if overall World Cup leader Mikaela Shiffrin did, but on Sunday he confirmed his run in the men's giant slalom had brought an end to his Pyeonchang Olympics. “I was an absolute no before but I was thinking about it,” Vonn said on Monday.

text: Thaw of Arctic ice and snow linked to worsening summer heatwaves and downpours. Study is part of drive to work out how climate change affects frequency of extreme weather. Governments want to know trends to plan everything from water supplies to what crops to plant. But science of a warming Arctic is far from settled and some experts say evidence is inconclusive."The melting Arctic has wide-ranging implications for people living in the middle latitudes," lead author Qiuhong Tang of the Chinese Academy of Sciences told Reuters. The U.N.'s panel of climate scientists says sea ice in the Arctic could almost vanish in summers by 2050 with rising greenhouse gas emissions. The report warns of increasingly extreme weather across "much of North America and Eurasia where billions of people will be affected" by global warming. "The jury is still very much out," James Screen, an expert at Exeter University in England, said of efforts to see if there is a link between a melting Arctic and extremes further south in the northern hemisphere. "For people on the streets, what really matters is whether the extremes are changing or not," he said. "From the scientific perspective we want to understand why," he added. The study was published in the journal Nature Climate Change, which is published by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Some evidence in Sunday's study was "plausible ... but far from conclusive," said James Overland, of the N.O.A.C.

text: In film production, holding Murphy at bay is a full time concern. One of the first scenes I had to deal with took place on the street and hallway of a tenement building. Only because one of the quick thinking actors realized there were people in the hallway that didn't belong and yelled "cut" did that scene not end in tragedy. My favorite Murphyism and the one that I would advise all developing filmmakers to adhere to goes: "If everything seems to be going well... you have obviously overlooked something" This is not a cynical calculation. It is a reminder that in almost all situations, cinematic and not, the devil is in the details and you can't be too thorough. Remember, "anything that can go wrong, will go wrong." It most circumstances the outcome of "Murphy's Law" is little more than a minor inconvenience. But on big city streets, at night, doing major stunt work, Murphy may have a much darker side. It was by far the longest few seconds of my life. "Cut. Cut," I screamed into the Walkie-Talkie and waited for what I was sure would be gunshots and tragedy. And then, mercifully, a voice came over the radio. "That's a cut." So what had gone wrong? We had been so careful, so thorough. What had happened was this: Two undercover detectives on their way back to the precinct had seen the car chase and thought they were coming to the aid of their brother officers.
label: SENSITIVE

text: This year's monsoon season in India was devastating, with local governments estimating 428 deaths. Developing nations had long sought to address the problem, and finally broke through with an agreement. But many details were left unresolved, and dozens of contentious meetings were held in the year since. A draft agreement was finally reached earlier this month, just a few weeks before this year's Cop28 talks open Nov. 30 in Dubai.. A recent report by the United Nations estimates that up to $387 billion will be needed annually if developing countries are to adapt to climate-driven changes. The draft agreement calls for the World Bank to temporarily host the fund for the next four years. It lays out basic goals for the fund, including its planned launch in 2024, and specifies how it will be administered and who will oversee it. The agreement asks developed countries to contribute to the fund but says other countries and private parties can, too. It says allocations will prioritize those most vulnerable to climate change, but any climate-affected community or country is eligible.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Beatles just released a short film about how the upcoming single "Now and Then" has come about. John Lennon had created a cassette demo of the song, and when the other three Beatles made their Anthology albums in 1995, they tried to use the cassette to play around his voice and make a new song. George Harrison played some guitar in that effort, but it was decided that the quality of John's vocals on the cassette were muddied by the piano playing. The song was abandoned. Now, with Peter Jackson's new audio separation technology, developed for their documentary "Get Back," it's become possible to separate John's voice from the piano and improve its quality. Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr could add their parts and produce a brand new Beatles single: written by John, with guitar by George, bass by Paul and drums by Ringo. It's a beautiful song, especially in the context of John and George's death, and perfectly appropriate as a coda to the incredible catalog of Beatles music.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Merging data from the two using filters has created this stunning panoramic image of an expansive galaxy cluster known as MACS0416. The merged image is one of the most comprehensive views of the universe ever taken, according to NASA. The image shows hundreds of completely unrelated galaxies in the background. It also shows small stretched lines. These are evidence of gravitational lensing whereby the gravitational field of a foreground object is so intense that it distorts the space around it. It bends the light from an object behind it into circular rings, both reveal the object’s existence and magnifying it. The data from both telescopes produced two separate papers, one published in the The Astrophysical Journal and the other published today in the Astronomy & Astrophysics. “The whole picture doesn’t become clear until you combine Webb data with Hubble data.” said Rogier Windhorst of Arizona State University, principal investigator of the PEARLS program (Prime Extragalactic Areas for Reionization and Lensing Science), which took the JSWT observation.

text: The U.S. is warming about 60% faster than the world as a whole, a new report says. Since 1970, the Lower 48 states have warmed by 2.5 degrees (1.4 degrees Celsius) Alaska has heated up by 4.2 degrees (2.3 degrees Celsius), compared to the global average of 1.7 degrees (0.9 degrees Celsius)," the report said. text: The Federal Trade Commission is proposing a new rule that would force businesses like ticket marketplaces and hotels to clearly list all the fees they’ll wind up charging customers. The proposal would require businesses to list all fees associated with a transaction upfront, so customers are not surprised by them at checkout. The commission argues that surprise fees cost consumers tens of billions of dollars every year in purchases like renting an apartment, paying for utilities, buying concert tickets, or booking a hotel. The proposed rule hardly bans junk fees, despite the FTC claiming otherwise—it just forces companies to make customers immediately aware of those junk fees. However, the new rule could incentivize businesses to compete with each other for the lowest price. The FTC is seeking comments from the public on the new proposal, and the public can submit their comments at the FTC’s proposed rule here. The new rule would force the hand of businesses across the board to opt-in to the attempt at transparency, and make our markets more fair and competitive.

text: World-renowned artist and 500px photographer Alexia Sinclair's latest photograph: Into the Gloaming. Alexia is currently selling a one-off print run of the incredible photograph below for one month only at a special supporter price to help fund the rest of this project. Click here to find out more and support Alexia's work.. A storybook is merely a container -- a parcel filled with wonder that, once opened by a skilled storyteller, leaps off the page and envelops reader and listener alike. The gloaming is that time of day where the soft glow of dusk envelopes your soul. Where the nocturnal gatekeepers take control and anything seems possible. You can (at least I do) imagine secret doorways in the trunks of trees or toadstools the size of houses. It's easy to understand why it's commonly known as the magic hour, anything seem possible and that's where we begin. The stage set, Alexia did what she does better than just about any other artist in the world: she began a weeks-long, painstaking process to create a scene with so much detail you could (and should) easily lose yourself in the resulting photograph. She literally creates her scene and props by hand, or spends countless hours searching for them high and low -- the mushrooms, for example, were grown in a 600-meter long decommissioned train tunnel which prior to mushroom farming held World War II munitions for the United States Government.
label: SAFE

text: The world isn't doing terribly well in averting global ecological collapse, says Dr. Florian Rabitz. Despite decades of international agreements and countless high-level summits, success in forestalling this existential crisis has remained elusive. Rabitz believes that transformative novel technologies, such as those currently under consideration for combatingclimate changethrough large-scale manipulation of planetary reflectivity, require adequate governance solutions to reap their potential benefits or to reduce their potential harm. The problem with novel technologies is their unprecedented nature, says the author of the monograph, "Transformative Novel Technologies and Global Environmental Governance," recently published by Cambridge University Press. The author explores how international institutions respond (or fail to respond) to high-impact technologies that have been the subject of extensive debate and controversy."We might well disagree on what precisely should be done with these and other types of transformative novel Technologies," says Rabitz, "but in one way or another, the absence of appropriate international solutions is bound to create problems sooner or later"
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Arena Group, the company that owns legacy media organizations like Sports Illustrated and financial news site TheStreet, has been crafting a carousel of fake AI bylines to run at the top of AI-generated content posted to both sites. Authors like “Drew Ortiz” and “Sora Tanaka” both had bios describing their home lives and interests, from camping and fishing to fitness and nutrition. However, both had profile photos that were for sale from Generated Photos, a service that sells fake AI- generated headshots. The articles stemming from theseAI-generated profiles include shopping listacles meant to generate revenue through affiliate links. These kinds of bylines seem to be an attempt to fool readers into thinking they are getting the advice of real consumer product experts, but they may also be an effort to try and fool Google’s search and advertising algorithms. The Arena Group CEO Ross Levinsohn told The Wall Street Journal that “Google will penalize you” for spamming the internet full of ungodly numbers of AI articles.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Jenny Han is the author of The Summer I Turned Pretty and To All The Boys I’ve Loved Before. Her YA novels are centered around Asian-American protagonists. Stephen King and Judy Blume are among the authors who have inspired her to write. Han says there is still a lack of diversity in the YA genre, but things are "getting better""I would tell my teenage self to really be in the moment and to continue to write down some of the feelings of that moment," she says. "I like to read non-fiction on my e-reader, but as for fiction -- I usually like to have a copy to keep at home," says Han. "It’s all about keeping up with technology. What is hard about it is the illegal downloads -- and figuring out ways to still keep books profitable so that people can still make a living," she adds."I like the way that he writes about childhood, first love, heartbreak. There's a real innocence to the way he writes," Han says of King. "He writes about young people beautifully. It's never particularly easy to combat that," Han adds. "Writing is just hard for me. Or I'll call Siobhan when I'm blocked up and we’ll talk it out and I'll read it out. It feels like drawing blood," says the Brooklyn-based author. "When I was growing up, YA didn't exist in the way it does now, so most kids went straight from the Babysitters Club to The Shining"
label: SENSITIVE

text: The leaders will meet on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit. The agenda includes no shortage of difficult issues. The meeting comes as the United States braces for a potentially bumpy year for U.S.-Chinese relations. Biden will likely press Xi on using China's influence on North Korea, during heightened anxiety over an increased pace of ballistic missile tests by North Korea. The Democratic president is also expected to let Xi know that he would like China to use its burgeoning sway over Iran to make clear that Tehran or its proxies should not take action that could lead to expansion of the Israel-Hamas war, an official says. The White House says the leaders will discuss the “continued importance of maintaining open lines of communication” and how the they “can continue to responsibly manage competition and work together where our interests align,” the White House said in a statement. The leaders last met nearly a year ago at the Group of 20 summit inBali, Indonesia.

text: The agreement to set up a dedicated fund to help vulnerable countries cope with climate "loss and damage" was a flagship achievement of last year's COP27 talks in Egypt. A transition committee on the establishment of the fund met late Friday and into Saturday in Aswan, in southern Egypt. But the delegates were unable to reach an agreement and deferred the decision to another meeting due November 3 to 5 in the United Arab Emirates. The failure "is a clear indication of the deep chasm between rich and poor nations", Harjeet Singh, head of global political strategy for Climate Action Network International, said in a statement to AFP on Saturday. "The United States and otherrich countriesseem more focused on evading or minimizing their responsibility than engaging in good faith negotiations," said Rachel Cleetus with the Union of Concerned Scientists. text: Euclid's instruments are sensitive enough to pick up the smallest galaxies. One picture shows 1,000 galaxies in a cluster 240 million light-years away. The telescope snapped pictures of a relatively close spiral galaxy that is a ringer for our own Milky Way. By measuring the shape and movement of galaxies, astronomers hope to learn more about the dark energy and matter that make up 95% of the universe.. The observatory will survey billions of galaxies over the next six years, creating the most comprehensive 3D map of the cosmos ever made.. It took Euclid just an hour to capture the nebula's latest beauty shot; the five new photos accounted for less than a day of observing time. It will orbit the sun some 1 million miles (1.6 million kilometers) from Earth, and the telescope is named after the mathematician of ancient Greece. The $1.5 billion mission is a partner in the NASA-led Hubble Space Telescope mission and supplied the telescope's infrared detectors.
label: SAFE

text: Labour MSP Monica Lennon's member's bill would make Scotland the first part of the UK to enforce tough penalties for ecocide. It is intended to deter and punish events such as oil spills caused by corporate negligence, while deforestation or illegal fishing could also be within its scope. The legislation would set a minimum jail sentence of 10 years for the crime of ecocide, with a maximum of 20 years. It came as it was confirmed First Minister Humza Yousaf will attend the COP28 climate summit in Dubai later this month. COP28 is the 28th annual United Nations climate meeting at which governments discuss how to limit and prepare for future climate change. Controversially, this year's event is being held in the UAE - one of the world's top 10 oil-producing nations. It comes during what is almost certain to be the hottest year on record after four months of "obliterated" temperatures. The Met Office said it would take a record-breaking cold November and December for it to avoid becoming the hottest.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Google DeepMind's GraphCast can forecast weather up to 10 days in advance. The model can also offer earlier warnings ofextreme weather events. It takes less than 60 seconds to create a 10-day forecast, making it way faster than the conventional approach used by HRES. The team is open-sourcing GraphCast’s model code to give scientists and forecasters access to the technology, which will allow them to tailor it for specific weather phenomena and optimize it for different parts of the world. The ECMWF is already trying out the model and says it has potential to complement and improve the current best weather forecasting methods. It also wants to use the technology to gain a greater understanding of the broader patterns of our climate, the team said in a blog post on Tuesday. It hopes that deploying AI for weather forecasting “will benefit billions of people in their everyday lives,” it said. The study published by Science on Tuesdayoffers a more detailed lookat GraphCast.
label: SAFE

The officiating crew will meet with supervisors to review the call and discuss proper protocol. The officials will also discuss the use of instant replay in the future, and how it could be used in other sports. The World Championships are currently being held in Canada. The tournament runs until the end of the month. The final will be held in Toronto on November 14. The event is part of the World Hockey Championship. It is the first time the tournament has been held in the U.S. since 1998. The U.K. has been a member of the tournament since the 1980s, and has won two gold medals. The last time was in 1986. It was the first year the tournament was held in North America, and the first two years were in Europe. The first game was played in Canada, and it was won by the Czech Republic. The other two were played in the United States, and they were won by Canada and Finland. The game was the opening game of the 2014 World Hockey Championships, which were held in Vancouver. text: Economy reporter and quiz bowl winner writes and edits questions for high-school and college competitions. "The joy I get when a player shouts "That's a cool clue" for one of my questions is often unmatched," she says, "and it's also made socializing easier, since I'm usually able toime in on random topics that people are passionate about. And who knows, maybe the next question I write to make some extra change could be my next big big story? (No spoilers.) "I use "craft" intentionally. text: On Saturday April 18, the entire City of West Hollywoodbecomes an interactive gallery with "100 Walkers" --100 living works of art walking pre-determined routes through the city. The ambitious Dada-ist art piece from artist Richard Kraft, begins at 2pm in the El Tovar parking lot between San Vincente and Robertson. The walkers, all in black, wearing bowler hats and sandwich boards each with a unique image on both front and back will stroll through city, covering every street, remaining silent throughout. The effect is a subversion of advertising, creating cognitive shifts and sensory dissonance as the sandwich boards are seen in passing (they are especially powerful as cars drive by the walkers!) Once the walker disperse, they can be seen all over West Hollywood til approximately 5:30pm, particularly along all the main thoroughfares: Sunset, Santa Monica, Melrose, Beverly, San Vicente, Doheny, La Cienega, Crescent Heights and Fairfax. (The man open air cafes along Santa Monica Boulevard, Roberston and Melrose also make for good vantage points to catch walkers as the stroll by!) Last month, in March, his full-length book featuring collage and text, Here Comes Kitty: A Comic Opera, was released by Sligo Press. The start of "100 walkers" can best be viewed from the overlook in West Hollywood Park or from the parking structure at the West Hollywood Library at2pm. The end of the art walk is at 5pm.

text: A recent New York Times story posits that dogs' ability to experience emotion is about equal to that of a human child. One alternative is a sort of limited personhood for animals that show neurobiological evidence of positive emotions. Puppy mills, laboratory dogs and dog racing would be banned for violating the basic right of self-determination of a person. And you could say that dogs are already subject to criminal liability, to the extent that "dangerous animal" laws affect canine freedom. But one judge's conclusion that animals aren't afforded constitutional protections isn't the end of the story, as a lawyer for the ASPCA says. "Right now in every state they're eventually chattel. They're property," Stacy Wolf says of pets. "They're like your couch" But Wolf says there have been some small movements in the direction of recognizing that they're really not, in fact, people, and that the law still looks at them as property. The idea that animals have emotions and "psychological harm" can also help advance the law, she says. people can petition a court to free a qualifying animal from a zoo, or ban its use for food, entertainment, or medical research, among other things. A group called the Nonhuman Rights Project is planning to file a writ of habeas corpus on behalf of a chimpanzee. Lawyer Steven Wise said he "has certain rights in mind" he's hoping to see afforded to animals by the court: Specifically, the right of liberty and bodily integrity.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Wild shrimp hauls off the southern Atlantic coast have plunged in recent months. Black gill disease, caused by a tiny parasite, contributed to a die-off of white shrimp. The disease does not kill shrimp directly but hurts their endurance. Wild-caught shrimp generate $6 million to $8-million in annual revenue in South Carolina and about $12 million a year in Georgia, officials said."It's like the shrimp are smoking three packs of cigarettes a day, and now they're having to go run a marathon," said Mel Bell, director of South Carolina's Office of Fisheries Management. "We have seen it in the past in Florida, but it's when the shrimp in Georgia have moved down," said Marilyn Solorzano, who operates Miss Marilyn Louise Shrimp Co. on the St. Johns River in Jacksonville. "I'm not making any money," said Tommy Edwards, a veteran shrimper in Charleston, South Carolina. "Normally, we have enough money where we're set for the winter and repairs and so forth, but we don't have enough for a month's worth of bills," said Edwards, 52. "There haven't been enough shrimp inGeorgia this year to move down to Florida," she said. "When the shrimp were stressed, they're susceptible to being infected with the parasite," Bell said. The parasite is only on the shrimp's gills, which come off when the head is removed for human consumption, he said. He said the shrimp is safe to eat as long as it has not spoiled.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Vice President Kamala Harris met with Prime Minister James Marape of Papua New Guinea on the margins of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Leaders' Meeting in San Francisco, California. The Vice President underscored the U.S. commitment to the Pacific Islands region. The two countries also discussed strengthening economic cooperation, fostering an environment to enable private sector investment, and increasing cooperation to combat climate change. They also discussed avenues to advance bilateral security cooperation ties, building on the new Defense Cooperation Agreement signed by the two countries in May. The vice president thanked Prime Minister Marape for hosting the U-Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Dialogue in May and attending the September U- Pacific Islands Forum Summit in Washington. She also thanked him for his role as a regional leader and member of APEC. The meeting was held on the sidelines of the APEC Leaders' meeting in San Francisco, California, on November 16, 2023. For more information, visit: www.apec.org.
label: SAFE

text: A storm in Kiev has torn Ukraine's largest flag in half, city officials reported on Monday. The national symbol was damaged despite being lowered to half-mast in an attempt to protect it from the strong winds. Officials in the Ukrainian capital announced on Telegram that the damaged section of the banner had already been removed from the mast. A severe snowstorm covered Ukraine on Monday, leaving over 2,000 settlements without power and forcing the closure of over a dozen motorways. Along the Black Sea, high winds have also caused significant damage in Russia’s Republic of Crimea. Local authorities declared a state of emergency as nearly 500,000 people have been left without power. The“once in a century”storm saw winds of up to 144 kph tear through the peninsula on Sunday, leaving at least one person dead and up to 10 residents injured. It also caused the deaths of some 500 marine animals at an aquarium in the port city of Sevastopol. The banner measures 16 by 24 meters.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Olympic gymnast Aly Raisman called on the U.S. Olympic Committee to first complete a full independent investigation into USA Gymnastics. Raisman tweeted her statement to the USOC in response to their letter to USAG on Thursday. The USOC called for the entire board of directors to resign or else the sport’s governing body would lose their certification. On Friday, USAG said it would comply with theUSOC’S request to have all members of the board’ s remaining 18 members resign. USOC CEO Scott Blackmun gave the USAG a list of steps it must take to reform the organization, including electing an interim board by the end of next month and cooperating in an independent investigation. The gymnast insisted that Nassar had more victims who haven’t yet spoken out and said that it was necessary to uncover any USAG staff or board members who may have “fostered” Nassar’“What possible reason could there be for not making it a priority to know these things,” Raisman asked. “Even now, you see the United States Olympic Committee ― they just spoke out Monday for the first time. They have been quiet this whole time.” “For so long they put medals, reputation and money over the safety of athletes,’ Raisman said on the “Today” show on Thursday, “and we need to investigate how this happened”
