text: Nigeria Civil Aviation Authority has commenced an investigation into the circumstances surrounding United Nigeria flight NUA 0506 to Asaba. This is contained in a statement signed by NCAA Director-General, Capt. Musa Nuhu, on Monday in Abuja. “The Authority wishes to reassure the traveling public that it will leave no stone unturned as it has always done in the past to ensure continued safety of the aviation industry, ” he said. Meanwhile, Mr Achilleus-Chud Uchegbu, Head Corporate Communications of United Nigeria Airlines, in a. statement said the flight which took of in Lagos en route Abuja on Sunday was temporarily diverted to the Asaba International Airport, Delta. According to him, the diversion was due to poor destination weather.“At all material time, the pilots of the aircraft were aware of the temporary diversion and were properly briefed. However, a wrong announcement was made by cabin crew upon landing in Asaba creating confusion among the passengers.”
label: SAFE

text: The Orionid meteor shower will peak on Saturday 21 October. The shower originated in debris of Halley's comet, one of the most famous in history. It can be seen from both the northern and southern hemispheres, but will be better in clear skies. If you cannot see the display this weekend, it will still be possible to see the shower at its 'maximum' phase until around 28 October. It is named after the star constellation from where the meteors appear to come from. The Orionid shower comes from the direction of Orion, but the next sighting will not be until 2061, but it is an annual event. The best day to see it will be between midnight and sunrise on 21 October in the northern hemisphere, and sunrise and sunset in the southern hemisphere on 7 November. The meteors can be see across the sky, so if you can, choose a wide open space so you can scan the skies with your eyes. There is no fixed time when they will cross the sky so it can be a waiting game.
label: SAFE

text: DF Concerts announced it would bring the long-running music series to Stirling. The festival began in Glasgow in 2013 and has previously hosted bands such as Simple Minds and The Cure. The likes of Kaiser Chiefs, Hozier and Nile Rodgers and CHIC have been announced to play at different Summer Sessions events next year. Stirling will be celebrating its 900th anniversary next year, which council leader Chris Kane said was "hugely exciting and fitting" Expanding to Edinburgh in 2018, the event has become a much-loved and highly anticipated live music series in Scotland. It will join Edinburgh and Glasgow as the hosts of Summer Sessions in Scotland, while more cities will welcome Summer Sessions across England and Wales. The full programme of events will be announced soon on the Summer Sessions website, with more acts to be announced in the coming months. The event has gone from "strength to strength" and Stirling Summer Sessions would be a "very welcome addition", said chief executive Geoff Ellis.
label: SAFE

text: Video shows whales, dolphins and porpoises sleeping vertically in the water. Scientists suspect the animals sleep like this to monitor breathing, to keep an eye out for potential predators and to conserve body heat. Whales sleep with only half their brain at a time, according to neuroethologist Paul Manger. The video was filmed off the Turks and Caicos Islands by YouTube user URZALA prod. The animal's sleep position may not look as comfortable as going supine on your pillow top queen, but for mammals that live in theWater, sleeping up near the surface is about survival, Manger says. "While there are good ideas about why whales and dolphins sleep the way they do, none of these are, as yet, fully proven," Manger said in an email to The Huffington Post. video proves whales are pretty zen sleepers, says sleep expert Sarah DiGiulio. The whales appeared to be totally asleep about 7 percent of the time -- less than two hours a day -- according to a study by the University of Witwatersrand in Johannesburg. In one study, researchers captured footage of whales sleeping in the wild that showed they may sometimes sleep with both sides of their brain. You can contact her at sarah.digiulio@huffingtonpost.com. For confidential support, call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or see www.samaritans.org. In the U.S., call the National Suicide Prevention Line on 1-800-273-8255.
label: SAFE

text: Chicago Bears cornerback Marcus Cooper celebrated a touchdown with a premature celebration. The Chicago Tribune called him a member of the “Idiot Hall of Fame” for performing a “stupid move, even for a Bear.” The Bears eventually settled for a field goal to take a 17-7 lead at the half. They won in overtime, 23-17, for their first victory of the season. The Bears were given possession inside the 1-yard line after a Steelers penalty on the play, but they eventuallysettled for a Field Goal. It’s not where you start. It's where you finish, Cooper should have heeded his own words: It's not how you start, it's how you finish.“That TD would have come in handy, Marcus Cooper,” For The Win tweeted. “ WHAT ARE YOU DOING MARCUS COOPER #Bears pic.twitter.com/jmOMvdxcSt” “That touchdown would have been handy,Marcus Cooper.’ “It's not what you do in the end, but how you end it,’ Cooper said. � “I’m not a showboater. I’ve never been one of those guys. I don’t like to showboating. I just like to finish,“ Cooper said in response to a question about his touchdown celebration. ”I just want to finish the game. ”
label: SENSITIVE

text: "Into the Atmosphere" is a 3.5 minute montage featuring 12,400 photos. The video is an ode to California's rolling fog, changing sky and sparkling sea. "Into The Atmosphere," is my tribute to the state of California and the beautiful deserts, mountains and coastlines that exist there," wrote Michael Shainblum on his Vimeo page. "Although California is known for blue sunshine skies, seeing a colorful storm cloud over Half Dome or an incredible sunset at the La Jolla Coves is really a sight to see," wrote Shain Blum on the video's page. The full video is available to watch on Vimeo at the link below. The time-lapse video was created by Shain blum and is directed by Michael Schumacher. It was shot on a Canon EOS 5D camera and features 12,000 photos of California's scenery. It is the latest in a series of beautiful timelapse videos from the same person. For more, visit CNN.com/TimeLapse.. For the rest of the video, click through the video player below to see more time- lapse videos from around the world, including the UK and the U.S., Canada, Australia and New Zealand, as well as a selection of our favorites from the world's top time-loapse filmmakers. The videos are available to view on YouTube at the following sites: YouTube.com, iReport.com and Facebook.

text: There are very few types of granite that can withstand the stress of gliding along melting ice and smashing into more rock. Most granite is too quartz-rich for it to withstand the impact under curling conditions. Ailsa Craig is 10 miles west of mainland Scotland and serves as the world’s only source for the rare granite. Kays of Scotland has been making curling stones since 1851 and has the exclusive rights to the AilsA Craig granite, which is why it has provided the stones for every single competition at the Olympic Winter Games. green granite makes up the body. The blue hone, whose tight molecular structure makes it impervious to water and melting ice, is used for the insert and running band of the stone. About every 10 years, Kays extracts several thousand tons of the distinctive blue and green varieties of microgranite that can be mined from the island. The island was once inhabited by Catholics who sought refuge during the Scottish Reformation, but is now an unpopulated safe haven for various birds. It is also a volcanic plug – a literal rock formed over an extinct volcano, and it turns out that the unique makeup of the rock left behind is uniquely suited for makingCurling stones. It turns out there are three subgroups of the water-resistant microgranites that can can be quarried from the Island: Aileda Craig Common Green Granite, Ailsasa Craig Blue Hone Granite and Ailsa Craig Red Honegranite.
label: SAFE

text: Thick fog and smoke from multiple marsh fires mingled to reduce visibility. Twenty-five people were injured in the crash on Interstate 55 in St John the Baptist Parish. Some vehicles caught fire and were abandoned, leaving a trail of burnt-out wreckage. Louisiana has battled blazing wildfires, heatwaves and relentless droughts over the course of the summer. Exceptional drought - the highest category tracked by the US Drought Monitor - is currently in place across 62% of the southern state. Governor John Bel Edwards urged residents to donate blood at a local medical centre to "help replenish supplies that are being drained today to care for the wounded" The National Weather Service in New Orleans described the weather phenomenon as a "super fog" The smoky conditions reduced visibility to less that 10ft (3m) The NWS said on Tuesday morning that heavy overnight winds had helped to disperse fog in some areas, but warned that dangerous driving conditions persisted in many areas. The motorway will remain closed until at least midday on Tuesday.
label: SENSITIVE

Rising incidence of dental and oral conditions such as tooth canal infection, dry mouth, tooth loss, cavities, and dental trauma is rising worldwide. Invisalign clear aligners makes it even better suited to integrate this, as design the treatment plan upfront instead of reacting to its effects like generally do with fixed appliances. text: Spain won its first Winter Olympics medal since 1992 on Thursday. Regino Hernández Martín won bronze in the men’s snowboard cross event. His teammate Fernando Ruiz shared a video of the medal-winning run on Eurosport. The sportscaster couldn’t contain his excitement about his countryman's historic performance in video that his Eurosport colleague shared online (see above) The video has since gone viral and has been shared more than 10,000 times on social media since Thursday night. The last time Spain won a medal at a Winter Olympics was 26 years ago in Albertville, France, when Blanca FernáNDez Ochoa secured the third spot in the women's Alpine skiing event. The medal was Spain's first in the Winter Olympics since 1992, and its first since the men's snowboardcross event in the 1988 Winter Olympics in Seoul. The race was won by Javier Fernandez of Spain and finished in a time of 1:02:05.02. The gold medal was awarded to Javier Fernandez, of Spain, and the silver medal went to Federico Pellegrini of Italy. The bronze medal was given to Jorge Fernandez, a Spaniard who competed in the slalom event and won in the super-combined event. It was the first medal for Spain in the snowboard event since the 1988 Summer Olympics in Calgary, Canada. The event was held in the Gangneung Extreme Park in South Korea.
label: SAFE

text: Real estate data platform CoreLogic reports ever-increasing risks. More than 18 million properties valued at $8 trillion are at extreme risk. Data provides a holistic view of all potential hazards, including floods, hurricane winds, wildfires, severe convective storms, severe winter storms, along with earthquake activity. The data could be the catalyst for a community renovation, funding or what has tragically happened, insurance leaving the area.. Of the 1.8 million homes at risk in Miami, about 12% of the units reside in the country, about 1.5 million of the value of the homes are in the Miami area and so are the extreme risk properties in all markets across the U.S. The total value of all extreme properties at risk across the country is $8.8 trillion, with California, Florida and Texas each carrying between 2.5 and 3.5 trillion dollars in total damage. The number of extreme properties in Miami is the highest in the nation, with about 1 million at risk.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The United Arab Emirates planned to broker secret oil and gas deals through its role as the host of the UN climate conference, COP28, the BBC reported. Officials from the Gulf state drew up a list of talking points on potential new fossil fuels deals with 15 attending nations. A COP28 spokesman told Business Insider that the documents had not been used in meetings. The UAE in a statement to the BBC did not deny that it planned on holdingOil and gas deal talks, and said "private meetings are private" It did not say what was discussed in the talks. Leaders from nearly 200countries are gathering in the UAE on Thursday for the COP28 summit, which is aimed at cutting global carbon emissions by 20 percent by the year's end. The UN body which organizes the summit is banned from using the discussions for self-interested purposes, or in a way that's biased. The COP28 team told the BBC this was "simply untrue," and said it's committed to "meaningful climate action"
label: SENSITIVE

text: National Sawdust was founded by composer Paola Prestini and managing director Ana De Archuleta. The non-profit is devoted to nurturing artists and fiercely values curiosity, experimentation, innovation, and inclusivity. The dramatic and soaring 13,000 structure is set in a 100-year-old former sawdust factory. David Byrne created a new song with the Brooklyn Youth Chorus that appeared in American Utopia and Jessye Norman gave one of her final performances at National Sawdust. Just last month they collaborated with the Grammy Museum to present an intimate conversation with Jon Batiste followed by a riveting performance. In September they acquired the equity of those philanthropic Investors and now own it. “Acquiring the building is of utmost importance as it not only secures the organization's long-term presence in the community, but also ensures our ability to offer a wide range of cultural programming and provide support to artists and arts organizations seeking space for new work and experimentation,” says De Archuleta.
label: SAFE

text: Ute Lemper, the acclaimed German chanteuse, bares her continental soul at the inviting 54 Below nightclub, downstairs from Studio 54, tonight and tomorrow. The great Kurt Weill interpreter is taking a departure from her acclaimed repertoire. Noted for her charismatic delivery of Weimar-era classics, Lemper navigates a more intimate musical universe in Songs From the Broken Heart. A second global import, Confucius, a new dance drama performed by the China National Opera & Dance Drama Theater at Lincoln Center, is a hypnotic production headed to Washington, D.C. Jan. 13-15. The opera tells the tale of the famous scholar's journey through the kingdoms of the Zhua Dynasty and his quest to bring a philosophy of benevolence, harmony and righteousness to its decadent, indifferent ruler. For Americans, it's a remarkable opportunity to appreciate the splendor and singularity of Chinese dance and music, deftly directed by Kong Dexin, a 77th-generation direct descendant ofconfucius. Themes of death, love and redemption permeate her oeuvre. So does humor. She manages, in the guise of Mac the Knife, to take theatrical swipes at Donald Trump. "Hell is built piece by piece," she sings; in a jazzy rendition of emotional infernos. She has, as Eugene O'Neill wrote, "a touch of the poet." Lemper strips away life's pretense and vanity; our tortured souls are her canvas.
label: SAFE

text: Nora the polar bear made her public debut at Columbus Zoo and Aquarium on Friday. She was born on Nov. 6, 2015, weighing just 1 pound. The zoo posted footage of her playful debut, witnessed by 1,000 people, to Facebook and YouTube. Visitors can see Nora every day for one hour from 9:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., zoo officials said. Only 20,000 to 25,000 polar bears now live in the wild, according to the zoo's website. They are found in the U.S., Canada, Russia, Greenland and Norway, but not in the Southern Hemisphere, the zoo said. The polar bear population is plummeting due to disappearing sea ice, which affects the animals' feeding habits and their ability to swim. The wild population of polar bears is estimated to be between 20,500 and 30,000, with the majority living in the Northern Hemisphere, it said. They live for an average of 24.1 years and can grow to 8 feet tall and 550 pounds. Males live on average for 20.7 years and grow to 10 feettall and 1,500 pounds, it added. They can also live for up to 20 years and reach 10 feet tall, it says. The animals are not endangered, but their numbers are on the decline because of climate change, which has led to the loss of sea ice in the southern part of the world. They're found in Canada, Greenland, Norway and Russia.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Three Tesla Model S cars caught on fire this year, all due to high-speed impacts. Not a single person was hurt. By comparison, the U.S.A. has had more than 250,000 gasoline car fires in the past year and a half. Earlier this year in my home state of North Carolina, the state was trying to pass a bill that would ban Tesla from selling cars in my state. And they're not the only state that has tried this move: New York, Texas, Minnesota and Virginia have all tried to pass similar bills. The National Auto Dealers Association says Tesla "has a whole mess of lawyers" to defend their franchise laws in Washington and Washington, D.C. They say Tesla is rocking the boat. What started as a ripple has now become a wave and the boat they are rocking is so enormous in its domination, some may have thought it to be unsinkable. They are rocking it in a way that is making people uncomfortable, especially the people who are heavily invested in it. It's on. We didn't expect these antiquated allies to go down without a fight. We don't underestimate the power of the press and the establishment and the money they can throw around to influence politicians, journalists and journalists. We're in for a fight, and it's going to be a long fight, but we're in it for the long haul, and we're not going to back down. We've got a long way to go.
label: SENSITIVE

text: 35 elephant carcasses were retrieved from various safaris and protected lands in Zimbabwe. Scientists ruled out intentional poisoning, poaching, and drought conditions. Six elephants had a bacteria known as Bisgaard taxon 45 in their system. The bacteria is not known to kill African elephants, scientists said, but they are beginning to see a potential pattern of cases like this in herds across Africa. The study authors said they are still stumped as to how the bacteria was transmitted to the elephant populations. However, they write that climate change-induced factors like heat, drought, and population density could make this type of bacteria transmission more common. The 35 deaths in Zimbabwe also coincided with a mass die-off of elephants inBotswanain 2020. At least 350 elephants died within a three-month timespan, and researchers at the time concluded thatblue-green algaecontaminated local water sources and poisoned the elephants. The scientists did not believe the deaths in Botswana and Zimbabwe were connected, however.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Transcription elongation, the process of synthesizing RNA from DNA, occurs when RNA polymerase II, a multiprotein complex, travels down a strand of DNA. The regulation of transcription elongation heavily relies on a variety of intracellular factors seamlessly working together, as research from the Shilatifard laboratory and others have shown over the last two decades. This fundamental finding laid the groundwork for subsequent research which has helped illuminate how its disruption causes different developmental defects, diseases and even contributes to theaging process."We are confident that our article will assist in advancing future research that investigates both the mechanisms and the physiological relevance of Pol IIelongation," said Yuki Aoi, Ph.D., a postdoctoral fellow in the Shiltsford laboratory and lead author of the editorial. The authors also discussed how recent in vivo studies, including those conducted by the Shilsford laboratory, have contributed to an improved understanding of the factors that controltranscription elongated. When targeted, factors may also serve as therapeutic targets for treating various diseases and that when targeted, could potentially inhibit or reverse accelerated aging.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Lego Star Wars Ob-Wan Kenobi Jedi Straighter is a good way to bring some of the Star Wars Universe home. If you’ve got the need for speed you might like this Lego set. It features an icon of drag racing, the Ford Mustang Shelby GT500. This set is an homage to NASA’s 1990 STS-31 million that put the space telescope into obit. It has movable solar panels and a hatch door, just like on the real space shuttle. For some people the world of fictional space exploration isn’t enough, and for you there’ll be the Space Shuttle Discovery and the Hubble Space Telescope. The Lego Darth Vader helmet is an 834-piece set that offers a complex but rewarding build experience and makes a great gift idea for birthdays and holidays. It's a detailed recreation of The Mandalorian helmet, cleverly recreated with drum-lacquered elements, while Lego bricks in different shades of gray allow you to highlight authentic counters of the actual helmet.
label: SAFE

text: "Alone Together" is at Red Bull Studios in New York until April 12, 2015. The piece features six internet "performers" creating content live. Viewers walk up a staircase, look into the content flashing and blinking before them, and decide whether they want to hit a "Like" button. For the Super Bowl alone this year, there were 71,245 articles, with 7,072 of them being written just about Katy Perry's halftime show. "There's no definitive end to any of this," said Ryder Ripps, the artist behind the project. "Alone together" is partly about capturing a moment of our time so we can have a shot of wrapping our heads around the underlying causes that cause content nausea, he said.. The exhibition is not intended to be discussed a day or two after it opens, but to be explored over the course of a few weeks. It's open to the public until the end of the month, but tickets are available for a limited time on the Red Bull website and at the gallery's website. For more information, visit redbull.com/alone-together and follow Ryder on Twitter @RyderRipps or on Facebook @ryderripps and on Instagram @ryryrips and #alonetogether. text: The plan is a key part of the EU’s vaunted European Green Deal. The plan seeks to establish the world's most ambitious climate and biodiversity targets. It has had an extremely rough ride through the EU's complicated approval process. The final votes - normally a rubberstamp process - could still throw up some hurdles. But the EPP, other conservatives and the far right have insisted the plans would undermine food security, fuel inflation and hurt farmers. and conservationists give a conditional and guarded welcome to a major plan to better protect nature and fight climate change in the 27-nation bloc. The EU's main agricultural group, COPA-COGECA, said that despite the concessions in the new plan, “the overall final compromise reverts to a totally unrealistic proposal for farmers and forest-owners” The EPP's Christine Schneider still did not give the plan the wholehearted support of her group for the last votes in parliament, leaving the final adoption of the plan in doubt.

text: The Large Hadron Collider, a 17-mile-long particle accelerator on the Swiss-French border, was shut down after a weasel gnawed through a transformer. The charred remains of the small beast were reportedly found by engineers investigating the situation. It is unclear whether the animals are trying to stop humanity from unlocking the secrets of the universe. The European Organization for Nuclear Research suggests the animal may have been a marten, according to an official report on the incident. The animal died, the EONR says, and plans to restart the collider were delayed several days because of the incident and several other small factors, the Associated Press reports. The E ONR says it is investigating the incident, but no further action has been taken against the weasel or marten. The LHC is the world's most powerful particle collider and is located on the French-Swiss border. The Collider is expected to be fully operational by the end of the year, and will be able to conduct research on the universe's origins and the formation of atoms and molecules for the first time since the universe was created in 380,000 years ago. The particle accelerator is the largest of its kind in the world, with a capacity of more than 1.5 million colliders. It has been used to study the origin of light and dark matter, among other things, as well as to make new drugs and treatments for cancer, heart disease, and other conditions that affect the nervous system and the immune system.
label: SENSITIVE

text: European researchers found that each of us has an "individual motor signature" The extent to which your movements are similar to another person’s can determine how easily you can coordinate with that person. By comparing the two individuals' movement signatures, the researchers could also determine the level of comfort and rapport in the relationship. The researchers concluded that analyzing these motor signatures could one day offer a new pathway into diagnosing and treating mental illness, such as conditions involving social phobias. the study was published in the journal Interface on Wednesday, and involved a series of three experiments and about 82 participants. It turned out that the players who were better at mimicking each other's movements -- including qualities like speed and weight of movement -- also exhibited more collective behaviors. The study shows that people who move in a certain way, will also react in similar ways when they are performing joint tasks, Dr. Krasimira Tsaneva-Atanasova said. "This could therefore be used in the future to help diagnose patients with certain conditions by studying how they move and react to others," she said in a statement. "Essentially, our movements give an insight into our inherent personality traits," the study's co-author said. It is normal, human behavior to mirror the posture and movement of those we agree with and like, body language expert Carol Kinsey Goman said. For instance, scientists could develop virtual reality technology in which a patient is asked to mimic the bodily movements of an avatar.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Emma Straub is the author of Modern Lovers, The Vacationers and Laura Lamont’s Life in Pictures. She and her husband plan to open a bookstore in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Straub says a bookstore is a place she can go to find new ideas, and to read a poem, and pick up a picture book for one of her children. She hopes her store will be “salve for the wound” of BookCourt's closure, and is aiming for a May opening date. She says bookstores are important for people like her who have small children, and who need a place to go when it's not warm outside. She also says she can’t remember anything if she can't walk through a bookstore and listen to music she’d like to listen to, because her husband is more technologically advanced than she is and has his music on a cloud-whatever, but she still likes to listen in a bookstore. The goal is May, she says, but it may take longer than that because of the lease details, which are still being ironed out, but they’re aiming for the same time as other small businesses. The store will offer “discoverability, expertise, and a sense of place,” Straub said. “An algorithm is never going to replace a human being saying, “Oh, you like Ann Patchett and Meg Wolile Meloy? Oh my god, you’ve never read Mailemeloy?’”
label: SAFE

text: 21 natural gas boilers have been installed at the industrial zone nearby Ukraine's Zaporizhzhya Nuclear Power Plant (ZNPP) All nine mobile diesel boilers, located at the ZNPP, have been in operation most days to generate the heating needed as the autumn weather gets colder prior to the onset of winter for the plant and the nearby city of Enerhodar. The IAEA has been concerned that some of the maintenance activities that have been carried out on the safety systems of the reactor units may have been incomplete, warranting additional maintenance to be carried out. "Nuclear safety and security remain at risk the longer the reduced levels of trained and experienced staff are employed at the plant," Director General Rafael Mariano Grossi of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) said. "Our presence remains essential," he added. "It is not a sustainable situation for Europe's largest nuclear power plant," added Director General Grossi. "The team will monitor closely the efforts taken to prepare for the difficult coldest months of the year," he said.

text: LZ Granderson: President Trump abdicated and besmirched his moral leadership as president of these United States of America. LZ: Are persons who supported the institution of slavery “morally equivalent” to those who opposed it? LZ asks: Are the opinions and views of those who believed it was okay for slave traders to transport millions of ancestors of the current generation of African-Americans to be slaves in our country to be given the same respect and veneration as the opinions of those whose ancestors who were slaves? We recommend that President Trump keep with him at times the text of the speech that Rabbi Joachim Prinz, President of the American Jewish Congress, delivered on March 28th, 1963, at the March For Jobs and Freedom in Washington, D.C.: “When I was the Jewish rabbi in Berlin, I learned of the Jewish community under the Hitler regime, and I learned that all of them were all in favor of freedom’” LZ says: “The world will little note, nor long remember what we say here, but it can never forget what they did here. The brave men, living and dead, who struggled here, have consecrated it, far above our poor power to add or detract. It is for us the living, rather, to be dedicated here to the unfinished work which they who fought here have thus far so nobly advanced.” He asks: Did any of those in Charlottesville, Virginia, demonstrating to prevent removal the statue of Robert Lee ever read or heard about Lincoln’s Gettysburg address?

text: Southern Co.'s third-quarter net income eased as higher retail electricity sales were offset by lower sales to industrial customers. Revenue fell to $6.98 billion from $8.37 billion a year earlier. Residential electricity sales rose 4.6% from a year ago, while commercial sales rose 3.7% and industrial sales fell 2.3%. "Adjusted earnings drivers for the third quarter 2023, as compared with the same period in 2022, were warmer than normal weather at the company's regulated electric utilities," the utility said in a statement. The company's largest segment by kilowatt-hours, was Residential, followed by Commercial, then Industrial, and then Residential again. The Atlanta utility said earnings fell to £1.42 billion, or $1.29 a share, from £2.47 billion in the year-ago quarter. The average Wall Street target of $ 1.32 a share as tallied by FactSet was for the quarter to end on October 31.

text: Muhly & Bloch, performed and recorded between January 24-26, 2013, is Zuill Bailey's third collaboration with the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra. In creating Schelomo - Rhapsodie Hébraïque for Cello and Orchestra, composer Ernest Bloch draws upon Ecclesiastes 1:2-9, intending that the cello be the voice of King Solomon, son of David. The recording really showcases the unique sound my cello has - the bass growl, the soaring top, and the speaking element of the middle. It's one of the great cellos on earth and, being such an early one, it's huge - almost a church bass. That's what gives this cello its unique sound. It was used in the Budapest String Quartet for forty years. I got it at a very unique time in my career, right at the beginning. It has become my voice." The theme of the entire project can be described as the finding of one's voice - beginning with the two composers. The goal with this U.S. premiere was to capture lightning in a bottle - and be lucky to have Muhly in attendance. "How many times do we get to actually ask the person who wrote the music to guide us, as opposed to speculating about it? The wonderful part in all of this, is that he was there!" said Mr. Bailey. "It's an intense study to try to understand how this works. On the other side, it sounds very natural, very simple"
label: SAFE

text: The RNC had just over $9 million cash on hand at the end of October. That's the lowest figure in over 8 years. The RNC also faces criticism for its handling of the2024 presidential primary debates. The next RNC-sponsored debate is set to take place on December 6 in Tuscaloosa, Alabama. "I don't believe the party should be in the debate business," said Scott Reed, who served as RNC's executive director in the mid-1990s. "Let the conservative marketplace decide, and let the campaigns decide where they want to show up," said Reed. "It's been a colossal failure," said another RNC executive director, who said the party made a mistake by hosting the third debate on the same night as the CMA Awards. The party's chair, Ronna McDaniel, said that the criticism has taken a "personal toll" on the RNC chair and that she "assiduously monitors criticism online" She added that the RNC "is always going to be a bit of a punching bag"

text: Activist artist Dread Scott creates in a language of searing simplicity. His work subverts American iconography to reveal the brutal injustices embedded in our nation's marrow. Scott’s first major piece, “What is the Proper Way to Display a US Flag?” was on view at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago in 1989. President George H. W. Bush called the work “disgraceful,” which signaled to Scott that he was doing something right, he said. The flag is now on display at San Francisco’S Guerrero Gallery as part of the exhibition “Past, Present, Future” Along with the flag, Scott will also show a piece entitled “IMAGINE A WORLD / WITHOUT AMERICA,’ named after a quote by Bob Avakian, leader of the Revolutionary Communist Party, USA. The piece dares Americans to put their own nationalism in check and imagine a radically different world where they are not the focus of the image, Scott told The Huffington Post. The show is aimed to address the current political moment, a reversal of progress for those who have spent their lives marginalized, silenced and oppressed. In this current political climate, when years of progress are in danger of being reversed, his unapologetic work needs to be seen, Scott said. He said: “I generally keep my art and activism somewhat separate. Typically my art isn’t bringing people to a demonstration or seeking particular demands.”
label: SENSITIVE

text: Adult fragments of a coral species can better tolerate bleaching and recover faster when treated with tougher heat-evolved symbionts. The study also found that treatment did not compromise thecoral's ability to grow. Symbionts are the tiny cells of algae that live inside the coral tissue, providing corals with energy to grow and the survival of reef-building corals depends on this mutually beneficial relationship. The research was a collaboration between AIMS, the University of Melbourne, Monash Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences and the Melbourne Centre for Nanofabrication. The next critical step of this research will be controlledfield trialsbefore it can be determined whether the intervention could work outside of the laboratory, with more than one coral type and at scale. The work is published inGlobal Change Biology. The long-term stability of the symbiosis offers hope they may be able to provide benefits to their coral hosts for many years, the scientists say. The new findings on adult coral close the circle and demonstrate the advantages are not lost in adulthood.
label: SENSITIVE

text: British astronaut Tim Peake will run the 26.2-mile London Marathon on April 24. He will be the first man to run a marathon in space. Peake has been preparing for the big day for months. If you want to run with Peake, you can join him for a training run using the RunSocial app (free, but currently only available for iPhones and iPads) You can also run the entire London Marathon with the spaceman on April 25 -- find out how to do that here. The race will be held in aid of Prince Charles' charity Prince's Trust, the U.K. Space Agency and the European Space Agency have dubbed themselves "Team Astronaut" and Peake's team "Team Peake" Peake completed the London Marathon in 1999 in 3 hours 18 minutes 50 seconds, but will have to contend with the same distance in zero gravity. He'll be using RunSocial, an app which allows runners to watch interactive, “mixed reality” videos of actual courses while on the treadmill, to help him prepare for the race.. The London Marathon will take place on Sunday, April 24, with approximately 38,000 runners taking part in the race, including Peake and several other European and U.S. space agency representatives. The event will raise money for Prince Charles's charity, the Prince of Wales' Trust, as well as a number of other charities, including the Royal Institute of British Architects and the Royal College of Obstetricians and Surgeons.

text: The Cauldron Wizarding Pub & Inn aims to be a magical pub in London. Founder Matthew Cortland hopes to raise $500,000 for the project on Kickstarter. The pub will feature floating candles, lights and taps that go on and off with a flick of a wand. The Cauldron will also be lined with books, with visitors encouraged to bring their own. Cortland said he aims to open up the pub to school groups in order to encourage an interest in S.T.E.M. subjects and foster an appreciation for literature. The project almost shares a name with The Leaky Cauldron, the pub on Charing Cross Road that appears to non-wizarding folk as a dusty old shop. It will need to avoid explicitly using the name “Harry Potter” or other direct references to the series due to licensing issues, but it will be modeled after one of his real-life favorites, John Kavanagh, a pub alongside Glasnevin Cemetery known locally as “Gravediggers’” For more information, head to the project’s website, which is open to the public for pre-sales and donations. The campaign goes live on June 26, the day Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was published in 1997, and the final amount raised will be contingent on the amount raised.. From June 1 to 30, HuffPost is celebrating the 20th anniversary of the very first "Harry Potter" book by reminiscing about all things Hogwarts.

text: The Delhi government has announced the return of theodd-even road apportioning scheme for a week. November 13-20 will be the fourth time the vehicle-rationing scheme will be implemented in Delhi in the last seven years. The idea is to cut the number of cars on the road by roughly half which, the Delhi government hopes, will bring down AQI levels somewhat. The scheme was tried out twice in 2016, and then in 2019. Several categories of vehicles were exempt, including taxis (which are CNG-run), cars driven by women (for considerations of safety), electric and hybrid vehicles, and all two-wheelers. There are an estimated 75 lakh active Delhi-registered vehicles currently, about a third of which are cars. The odd-even scheme would, therefore, mean that about 12.5 lakh cars would go off the roads each day, not considering electrics and hybrids. About 20 lakh vehicles that are registered in the NCR cities or elsewhere also ply in Delhi.
label: SAFE

text: Parrotfishes are key players in regulating algae and reef life. Their parrot-like beaks and fused-together teeth are used for scraping and biting dead coral. Larger parrotfish are like sand factories, producing as much as 840 pounds of sand per year. For Oahu’s snorkeling hot spot, Hanauma Bay, that means hundreds of tons of fish-made sand each year.. Worms, sponges, and oysters also produce Pacific ocean sand, but no animal is as proficient as the parrot fish, a badge of honor it has held for centuries. According to the Maui Ocean Center, the native Hawaiian name for the female redlip parrot Fish translates to “loose bowels.” We can see why: The fish doesn’t have stomachs, their meals pass straight through the long intestine, exploding in a cloud of sand out the backdoor. The fish is the reason Hawaii beaches are constantly ranked the best in the world, where a significant portion of that pristine, white, beautiful sand is actually poop. It's the only way to get the best beach sand in Oahu, where the beach is constantly ranked top-notch by the U.S. Geological Survey. It’d be impossible to get all the sand on the beach if it were not for the fish, who eat the algae and coral that grow on the surface of the water. It is also the only animal that can scrape and bite dead coral, while additional teeth in their throats help to break it all down.
label: SAFE

text: XL Dissent is a massive surge of protest against the Keystone XL tar sands pipeline and a powerful show of solidarity with all communities who are fighting the fossil fuel industry. "An entire movement has thrown itself into in this Keystone fight, from local frontline groups to big national green organizations," 350.org co-founder Bill McKibben wrote in an email. XL Dissent will only help cement that commitment and energize opposition to the project. President Obama has a choice to make. He can side with Big Oil and approve Keystone XL, tarnishing his environmental legacy. Or he can stand with the generation of young people that helped him into office and reject this disaster. It's already clear that this is one for the history books. The action this morning began up at Georgetown University, where last summer President Obama pledged that he would only approve the pipeline if it didn't significantly increase greenhouse gas emissions. At around 10:30am, students surged out of the gates of campus and headed towards the White House. Along the way, they stopped at Secretary Kerry's house and unfurled a giant mock oil spill in the middle of the street. After they get arrested, students are being taken to a police processing center in Anacostia where they will be fined and released, if all goes according to plan. More than 70,000 people have now signed on to the KeystoneXL Pledge of Resistance to show that they are willing to engage in civil disobedience if President Obama moves forward with approving the pipeline.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Aug. 21 solar eclipse will travel across 14 states along a path 70 miles wide. NASA has issued some basics to help make sure you can see the big event without damaging your eyes. The agency said to use special eclipse viewing glasses with the designated ISO 12312-2 international standard. It also advised not to use lenses more than 3 years old, or ones that have been scratched or wrinkled. The viewing glasses are widely available for purchase, and nearly 5,000 libraries are giving them away. The space agency said a welder’s hood with a shade number 14 filter or darker would also be effective, but it warned that not all hoods meet that standard. Another option is a pinhole projector, which you can MacGyver with a cereal box, a piece of white paper and some tin foil. The eclipse will also be streamed online by NASA, using cameras around the nation, along with some in high-altitude aircraft and aboard the International Space Station. NASA has more tips on its special Eclipse 2017 website as well as a PDF Eclipse Guide. It will stream the event online here, as well: The agency will stream it online, using camera around the country and aboard high- altitude aircraft, and some in the International space Station. It has a link to one you can get a copy of the guide on its website here. It is available in English, Spanish, German, French, Italian, Portuguese and other languages, and can be downloaded by clicking here.

text: President Bola Tinubu has inaugurated the Abdul Samad Rabiu (ASR) International Centre for Innovations and Entrepreneurship. The N1bn facility, equipped with state-of-the-art amenities, underscored ASR Africa’s dedication to driving positive change on the University of Maiduguri campus in Borno State. The centre was in line with the Renewed Hope Agenda of the President Tinuba administration for the rapid resuscitation and prosperity of the economy. Vice President Kashim Shettima represented the President at the inauguration ceremony on Saturday. The ASR International Centre, which was established in April 2021, boasts a 150-seat auditorium, artisans and handcraft spaces, fabrication machine laboratory, training zones, a coding and app development laboratory, robotics, drones, and mechatronics facilities, and incubation spaces. Vice-Chancellor of the University, Professor Aliyu Shugaba, expressed optimism about the centre's impact on creating a thriving innovation and entrepreneurial ecosystem.

text: EMIT imaging spectrometer aboard the International Space Station has shown an ability to detect more than just surface minerals. Since August 2022, it has documented more than 50,000 scenes of methane emissions. Tracking human-caused emissions of methane is key to limiting climate change because it offers a comparatively low-cost, rapid approach to reducing greenhouse gases. EMIT has proven effective at spotting emission sources both big (tens of thousands of pounds of methane per hour) and surprisingly small (down to the hundreds of pounds per hour)."The number and scale of methane plumes measured by EMIT around our planet is stunning," said Robert O. Green, a JPL senior research scientist and EMIT's principal investigator. The EMIT science team creates maps of plumes and releases them on a website available at the joint U.S.-U.S. Geological Survey Land Distributed Active Archive Center (LPAC) The mission's data is available for use by the public, scientists, and organizations.
label: SAFE

text: Oxfam's Climate Equality: A Planet for the 99%, assesses the consumption emissions of different income groups. It would take about 1,500 years for someone in the bottom 99 per cent to produce as much carbon as the richest billionaires do in a year. The report reveals the outsized emissions of the richest 1 per cent will cause 1.3 million heat-related excess deaths - with most of these deaths occurring between 2020 and 2030. The death toll from floods is seven times higher in the most unequal countries compared to more equal ones. The huge scale of climate inequality revealed in the report highlights how the two crises are inextricably linked - fuelling one another - and the urgent need to ensure the rising costs of climate change fall on those most responsible and able to pay. Governments must act now, and the climate crisis is exacerbating existing inequalities in the UK, and will continue to do so unless the government accelerates the move to a fossil fuel future, says Oxfam.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Apple is set to release the fourth-gen of their budget-friendly iPhone SE line in 2025. Reports suggest that its body is going to look a lot like the iPhone 14. Until now, the SE series featured an iPhone 8-style design, but that will end with the upcoming model. The fourth generation iPhone SE (which has been referred to as D59 or codename Ghost) will host the same flat design without a touch ID button that you now see on all recently-released iPhones. The reason behind the SE 4 being relatively lightweight is that it sports a single camera instead of the triple-lens we see on the 14. You get a 48-megapixel rear camera with a custom backplate that caters to the design change. In terms of how the iPhones differ in terms of design, there are two main features: the multi-purpose Action button and a USB-C port, both of which were recently seen on the iPhone 15. All of it is based on prototypes and conjecture, and it is always possible that some of it might change during the development phase.
label: SAFE

text: In the first two weeks of November, fires destroyed nearly 770,000 hectares (1.9 million acres) of the world's largest tropical wetlands. This accounts for 65% of the damage done by fires in the region this year. The Pantanal holds thousands of plant and animal species, including 159 mammals, and it abounds with jaguars. The state of Mato Grosso do Sul launched on Nov. 14 a joint task force, mobilizing the state’s entire fleet of aircraft to help firefighters, either dropping water on fires or flying out firefighters to the region”s most remote locations. The heat wave that swept through much of Brazil this week, combined with the El Niño phenomenon led to higher temperatures and drier weather conditions, both favorable to fires, experts say.. Firefighters, troops and volunteers are working night and day to try and stop the fires, which are threatening not only the region's rich fauna and flora but also houses and touristic guesthouses.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Jeff Koons' new series of paintings, "Gazing Ball," were painted by artists he knows or has trained. Louis Nizer: Many of the artists who worked on the paintings are very fine artists in their own right. Koons is truly an "Artist as CEO" who, if anything, seems to enjoy showing off the fact that skill is something he can afford, says Nizer. Nizer says maybe, just maybe, it's a good thing that skilled representation by friends of Steven Assael made its way into Gagosian gallery, whose names will be the ones who get credit for the work, he says. "I'm basically the idea person," Jeff Koons once told an interviewer, "I don't have the necessary abilities, so I go to the top people" and he does create employment for artists, Nizer writes. "It's like saying that some top bankers should go to jail for their roles in the 2007-8 subprime mortgage crisis: it's old news and hardly anyone is interested, especially in New York," Nizer adds. "Is De-Skilling Your Art Education?" goes viral, generating thirty thousand Facebook likes against the current "academic prejudice" against painters, he asks. "The moral universe will finally bend their way... I know I know," says Assael, "and I know the painters will know what it is -- they seem to intuitively know what is going on. Everyone seems to know it"
label: SENSITIVE

text: A gallery of artworks inspired by "Get Out" is now on view over on the movie’s website. The online gallery is accompanied by a quote from filmmaker Jordan Peele. “Art is the one tool we have against the true horrors of the world,” he said. ‘Get Out’ is an inclusive experience that inspires people to just talk,’ Peele said. The film recently crossed the $100 million mark at the box office. It's about a white woman who brings her black boyfriend to meet her family for the first time. The movie was written and directed by Peele and stars Lakeith Stanfield, Daniel Kaluuya and Keegan-Michael-Beadle. It was released in theaters on March 26. It has already grossed more than $93 million worldwide. It is the second-highest-grossing film of the year so far, behind only “La La Land” (which made $103 million in the U.S. in 2013). The film is based on the novel by Stephen King and is directed by Jordan Peeve, who is also the writer and director of “Carrie” and “Get Out.” It is about a black woman and her white boyfriend who meet in the suburbs for the very first time, and what happens when they find out they’re both from different sides of the same racial divide. The story is told through a series of clues and symbols that are buried throughout the film.
label: SENSITIVE

text: National Wildlife magazine has held a photo contest for 43 years. The contest is a way to encourage people to get outside and learn about wildlife. Here are some of the winners from the 2012 contest. Submission deadline is Monday, July 15, at 11:59 p.m. ET, U.S. You don't have to be a professional photographer to participate in the contest. The National Wildlife Federation is accepting submissions for the 2013 contest for seven categories: Baby Animals, Landscapes and Plant Life, Backyard Habitat, People and Nature, and Habitat and Backyard Connecting People andnature. Back to Mail Online home.Back to the page you came from."I've never seen this star with the same perfection," says Francisco Mingorance of the beach in Granada, Spain. "It's rare to have nature arrange itself in such an organized manner," says Jamie Scarrow, who captured the scene from a viewing platform directly above. "After getting this image, I have visited the beach many times, but I've never been able to see this star," he says of the "star" of sea foam on the shore. "I began to stop until the light had disappeared," says David Hall, who waded into British Columbia's Adams River to photograph migrating sockeye salmon during October 2010, the largest run of these fish in a century. "This is one of the most beautiful birds we've seen in Asia," says Hal and Kirsten Snyder of Taipei, China.

Also, we want Dr. Ibrahim to bring and unite all the youth organisations in the country with the aim of listening to them and developing a strategic way of communicating with them to meet her objectives,” he said. text: Hurricane Dorian is expected to make landfall within the next 24 hours. Weather officials warn of dangerous storm surge and flooding in low-lying areas. Schools and government offices have closed, and public transportation is running special evacuation routes. The National Guard has been activated to assist with evacuation efforts. The storm is currently a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 100 miles per hour (160 km/h) and gusts of up to 150 mph (240 km/hr) The National Weather Service has declared a state of emergency in the state of New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. The state emergency services have positioned rescue teams and supplies in strategic locations in preparation for Dorian's expected landfall. The hurricane is now a Category 3 storm with maximum winds of 110 mph (175 km/hour) and heavy rain. It is moving towards the eastern coast of the United States, but is not expected to become a major hurricane until later this week or early next week, the weather service says. The U.S. National Hurricane Center has issued a tropical storm warning for parts of the east coast of New Jersey and Puerto Rico. It says the storm could make landfall as early as Sunday. The weather service has issued an emergency alert for the rest of the state, warning of a possible life-threatening storm surge in low lying areas and heavy rainfall in coastal areas. It has activated the National Guard to assist in the evacuation efforts, with rescue teams positioned at strategic locations across the state.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The part of Raquel De Angelis is perfect for Renée Fleming. The intricately choreographed efficiency of the two butlers was a delight. The Eisenhower-era costumes and wigs were absolutely stunning. One of the most touching details is the story of how the Maestro and the Diva met. The Maestro has never been able to progress beyond this story with any of his ghost writers, and at the end, it is instrumental in theMaestro and Diva reaffirming their love."People go to the opera because it's better than life. So it is with the theater," the diva says. "With the stage set just so, the rest of the story is no surprise. But that's not important. It's the theater that matters" The play ends with an image of the DivA in the Maestros' arms, singing sweet, romantic songs to him. "That is how the play ended, and that is how this review ends," the reviewer writes. "It was quite charming. When they sang along with the opera recordings that accompanied the scene changes -- quite well, I might add -- it was amusing and quite charming," he says of the butlers' lounge-act performance of "Makin' Whoopie" "Kudos to director Kathleen Marshall for a thousand delightful details. Kudos also to the spectacular design team: costume design by Michael Krass, scene design by Derek McLane, wig and hair by Tom Watson"
label: SAFE

text: The Puppy Bowl is Animal Planet's counter-programming to the Super Bowl. All of the participating dogs come from animal shelters or rescue groups. This year, two of the puppies are animals rescued from Puerto Rico in the wake of Hurricane Maria. Kaleb Jr. and Archer, both mixed-breeds, were transported to the U.S. mainland by The Sato Project, a nonprofit focused on helping Puerto Rico’s stray dogs. Both have already been adopted by families in New York state, and both have been given new names — Murphy and Maddox, respectively. The group is also accepting applications for temporary dog foster homes as well as for volunteers in both New York and Puerto Rico. As of Wednesday, nearly 30 percent of Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority customers still had no power. The Suto Project still has other dogs available for adoption, though, and is also looking for volunteers to help foster dogs in both Puerto Rico and New York. The program will air on Animal Planet at 8 p.m. ET on Sunday, February 4, with a live broadcast on the Animal Planet website and Facebook page. For more information, go to www.animal Planet.com/puppybowl XIV and follow them on Twitter @PuppyBowl and @AnimalsPbPk. text: Perfume-free campaign asks members and visitors to forego perfumes, after-shave and scented lotions. Church is swapping out cleaners, candles, air fresheners and bathroom soaps. Fragrance industry asserts the benefits of scents, whether natural, man-made, or designed to smell like nature. "There are people out there who would like to go to church, but they can't," church elder says of chemical-sensitive members.. A small fraction of Americans are hypersensitive to scents. Many may be subtly affected and at increased risk of future health problems from living in an invisible fog of chemicals. The American Medical Association studied it in 1991, but "found no scientific evidence that supports the contention that multiple chemical sensitivity syndrome is a significant cause of disease," R.J. Mills, an AMA spokesperson, told HuffPost. "I think we're addicted to chemicals and some people don't want to admit there's a downside to it," Dr. Philip Ranheim, an environmental doctor based in Washington, Wash., said. The fragrance industry sets its own standards and facilitates its own safety reviews, with help from outside experts, he said. But there's bias against people with chemical sensitivity, Ranheim said, because of the larger body's ability to tolerate chemicals.. At one point, "minute amounts of diverse chemicals" can trigger symptoms that point against one significant exposure or the accrual of repeated low-level exposures. The AMA believes that "multiple chemical sensitivity should not be considered a recognized syndrome"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Jo Farrell was driven about 120 miles from Edinburgh to Northumberland. She had started in the role of Scotland's top police officer just 11 days earlier. Ms Farrell said she was sorry for her "error of judgement" A civilian worker from Durham Constabulary was also a passenger in the police car. Police Scotland have confirmed this person was dropped off a further 15 miles south, in Gateshead. Next week Ms Farrell will use her first public speech to argue for increased funding to ease the force's financial woes. She has kept a low profile since she took charge of the UK's second biggest police force. The Scottish Police Authority said: "The authority is aware the chief constable used a police vehicle following the cancellation of a scheduled train journey. "The chair has discussed this with the Chief constable who has apologised. The authority considers the matter closed." The police driver, a road policing officer, was then said to have returned to Edinburgh - a round trip that would have taken about six hours.

text: DFA Undersecretary for Bilateral Relations and ASEAN Affairs Ma. Theresa P. Lazaro co-chaired the inaugural Strategic Dialogue with UK Minister of State for Indo-Pacific The Rt Hon Anne-Marie Trevelyan MP. The Strategic Dialogue was established to set strategic policy directions under the Philippines-UK Enhanced Partnership. It also caps a highly productive year of thematic bilateral meetings on political, maritime, defense, economic and climate and environment cooperation. The two co-Chairs looked forward to the finalization of Memoranda of Understanding on Defense Cooperation and on Cyber Security, reflecting the momentum generated by the Enhanced Partnership and adding further value to the ever-growing strategic engagements between the countries. Both sides also welcomed closer economic cooperation, having identified ways to encourage even stronger bilateral trade and investment ties. In terms of investments, the UK has the distinction of being a top source of investments in the Philippines, with potential to increase even further through the launch of the British Investment Partnerships in the country this year.

text: Activists in Israel say that as right-wing, pro-war voices dominate the social discourse, their work has never felt more important. Israel Frey, an ultra-Orthodox Israeli journalist, was forced into hiding after expressing support for the people of Gaza – which he said made him the target of far-right activists. And it was reported that an Israeli citizen had been arrested on account of a publicly displayed sign. “There is no sanctity in an occupied city,” read the sign, which had reportedly been hung from the window of his Jerusalem home for years. ‘Will it get worse? Yes, perhaps – it is concerning’ said Israeli Ofer Neiman, a pro-Palestinian resident of Jerusalem.

text: This is a defining era for the scientists, engineers and researchers who have dedicated their careers to developing creative solutions to combat the existential threats posed by climate change. Human ingenuity has already led to innovations like sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), carbon capture technologies, and automation solutions. Public and private-sector organizations have an active role to play in the journey to net zero. They need to adopt technologies that can be utilized now to meet their sustainability commitments and take steps to attract and retain talent focused on further developing energy transition-enabling inventions. The time to move on sustainability is now. There are already innovative solutions to flight climate change that do not require further development and are ready now to be implemented in various industries. With science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) jobs projected to grow 15% between 2021 and 2031, early exposure to STEM concepts and skills can help spark interest in and inspire future innovators to pursue careers that matter to the energy transition. An EducationWeek survey found that less than a third of US Kindergarten through 12-grade teachers teach their students about the science behind climate change, citing a lack of resources.

text: The video was posted by GoPro and 'captured' by Matthew Copham, "a Safari Footprints guide" who does tours throughout the African wilderness. Click play below and get ready to quite possibly and audibly say aloud: "Awwww...""We have for you an accidental, but absolutely amazing moment captured on camera that is sure to make you smile today: an adorable cheetah licking a GoPro," GoPro said in a post on its Facebook page. "It was an accident, but an amazing one," the company said. "We have never seen anything like it," it added. "I'm so happy to have captured it," said the company's founder, Nick Szymanski. "This is the most beautiful thing I've ever seen," he said of the moment. "The whole world is going to love it," he added, "because it's so cute and cute and adorable." "It's just so cute," said Szemanski, "and it's the most amazing thing ever," said GoPro's founder. "There's no words for it. There's no way to describe it. It's just the most adorable thing you've ever see," said a GoPro spokesperson. "You just have to see it to believe it," she said. 'It's a miracle,' she said, "that it happened," said another GoPro user. "And it was captured by a GoPro camera," she added. 'We're going to share it with the world,' said the GoPro owner.
label: SAFE

text: The Global Agricultural Films Market Size To Grow from USD 11.60 Billion in 2022 to USD 17.82 Billion by 2032, at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 7.4% during the forecast period. Agricultural films, also known as agricultural plastic or Agriplastics, are extensively used in modern farming practises to boost crop output, protect plants, and conserve resources. On the basis of raw materials, the global agricultural films market is segmented into LDPE, LLDPE and Reclaims. Among these, LL DPE is dominating the market with the largest market share over the forecast time period. Mulching accounted the largestMarket share of mulching films over the next five years. Precision farming methods, like carefully timed watering and fertilisation, have made it practical to use mulching Films. Asia-Pacific holds the highest demand for Mulching films, particularly in regions with suitable climatic conditions. text: Interlinked climate behavior, or teleconnections, isn't a well understood field but will be necessary to fully comprehend how our climate system works. "Think of it as a domino effect on a global scale," said co-author Jingfang Fan of Beijing Normal University. The researchers plan to use this knowledge to pinpoint which regions may be at a higher risk in the future and to devise strategies to address these challenges. "Using what we've learned, we plan to predict how climate events will unfold and connect. We're diving deep to explore why these events happen and how various climate 'tipping points' within ourclimate systemmight be linked," said Fan. "Within just five years, we may see temperatures rising to levels that global scientists have been warning us about," saidFan. "It's like the planet is running a fever that's steadily getting worse."Climate networks are akin to maps wheredata pointsare marked as locations, and the connections between them reveal similarities. The extent and intensity of the impact ofteleconnections has increased more prominently in the Southern Hemisphere during the past 37 years.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Michael Phelps and his wife, Nicole, announced the arrival of their second son, Beckett Richard Phelps. The 23-time gold medalist posted the good news Tuesday on a few Instagram accounts. “I truly do feel like the happiest man in the world,” he wrote. The couple announced they were expecting late in August, about a year after Phelps ended the winningest Olympic career in history with his 23rd gold medal at the Rio games. He said mom and baby were “healthy. And Dad is thrilled.” The couple have a 2-year-old son, Boomer, who will celebrate his second birthday in May. The baby is expected to make his debut at the 2018 Summer Olympics in Rio in August. He will compete in the men's 4x200-meter freestyle relay and the men’s 4x100-meter medley relay, as well as the individual medley and freestyle events in the 4x400-meters relay and men's team medley events. The 4x500-meter relay is the first time the U.S. has competed in the Summer Olympics since 1996, when it took place in Seoul, South Korea. It is the second time the Summer Games have been held in South Korea, after the 1996 games in Seoul and the 2000 games in Sydney. The U.K. has only competed in two Summer Olympics, in 1996 and 2000. The last time was in Athens in 1988, the year of the opening ceremony.

She was released on a $100,000 bail bond and will appear in court on November 14. She is currently being represented by attorney David Cevallos, who is also representing former NBA star Billie Jean-Bette Williams, who was arrested in a similar incident in 1998. She has not been charged with a crime in connection with the crash. The incident occurred in the early hours of the morning in a parking lot in Fort Worth, Texas. It was not immediately clear if she was involved in any other incidents in the past. She faces a possible fine of up to $1,000, as well as a possible ban from the NFL and the NBA, if she is found guilty of driving while intoxicated. text: Researchers from the Universidad Carlos III de Madrid (UC3M), the Polytechnic University of Madrid (UPM) and Loyola University have discovered that personality does not seem to have much influence when it comes to choosing social friendships at school. This work is important because it challenges the common belief that friendships are based on similarity—that is, homophily. This understanding may have important implications for how we understand and build our friendships, especially in societies where cultural and thought homogeneity may be highly valued. In short, this research can help us build healthier and more productive relationships in our personal and professional lives, say the study's authors. The research may also have implications for the creation of workplace policies and practices. For example, if employers understand that differences among workers can be beneficial for creativity andjob performance, they could encourage diversity in their teams and work environments, they say. The study presents a detailed study of the social relationships of students at 13secondary schools, including more than 3,000 students and around 60,000 reported positive and negative relationships.

text: The Selkirk Rex is a new breed of cat that has a thick, curly coat. Researchers from the University of Veterinary Medicine, Vienna, identified the new breed in a study published last year. The breed's origin dates back to 1987 when a feral cat birthed a litter of five in Montana. It is the only type of cat named after a person, making it the only cat breed named after its stepfather, Jeri Newman, says. The International Cat Association, the American Cat Fanciers Association and CatFanciers' Association have already accepted the cat breed, which has three layers of fur. The poodle cat is also referred to as the "cat in sheep's clothing," according to the International Cat association. The Selk Kirk Rex has a significantly thicker coat than related breeds Devon Rex and Cornish Rex, which are also characteristically curly but carry recessive genes, the study notes. The team noted in the study that the breed arose from a spontaneous genetic mutation, which makes the curly hair a dominant trait. It has yet to be officially accepted by any of the cat fanciers groups, but some have accepted it as a breed of kitty, such as the Catfanciers of America and the Cat Cat Association of the United States, which have already approved the breed for use in their own shows and competitions. The kitty is also known as the Poodle Cat because of its three-layered coat, which is why it is also called the "poodle cat"

text: Pseudogymnoascus destructans has killed around 6 million American bats since 2006. It now infects 22 U.S. states and five Canadian provinces, decimating entire bat colonies. Study: Fungus can live on insects, undigested insect parts in guano, wood, dead fungi and cave fish. Heat is one of the few silver bullets for the cold-loving fungus, which only manages to infect warm-blooded bats because hibernation decreases their body temperatures."This means that whether the bats are there or not, it's going to be in the caves for a very long time," mycologist Andrew Miller says. "Identification of the closest known relatives of this fungus makes it possible to move forward with work to use this tool to kill this fungus," USFS researcher Daniel Lindner said earlier this year. "Ultimately, we hope we can find a way to defang the disease," Lindner says, offering hope that science might find a new way to kill the fungus. "All in all, the situation for hibernating bats in the U.s. is pretty grim," Miller says, "but that won't stop American bats, which play a variety of economic as well as ecological roles in crop-eating and crop-spreading industry," he adds. "We need to do something to stop the spread of white-nose syndrome in the first place," he says."It can basically live on any complex carbon source," says lead author Daniel Raudabaugh.
label: SENSITIVE

The push in the four communities follows a surge in drilling around the state which has become home to a total of more than 51,000 operatingOil and gas drill sites. A recent report from advocacy group Environment America reported that Colorado is the second-highest fracked state in the U.S. with 18,168 fracking wells, second only to Texas."Colorado has been called the ground zero of fracking," Ana Tinsly, spokesperson for Frack Free Colorado, said in a press statement. "Gas and oil companies are virtually self-regulated, with devastating consequences, as we saw in the recent flooding of thousands of fracking sites that were allowed to be built on a flood zone," Tinsley said. John Hickenlooper said of fracking fluid back in February, when invited to give the keynote address at The Atlantic's Next Generation Energy Forum in Washington.

text: British YouTuber Exurb1a creates a four-minute explainer of the universe. He covers neutrinos, quarks and atoms, the periodic table and DNA. "Nothing means anything and we're all going to die," he says in the video, which also includes a dig at an ex-girlfriend and several celebrities. "I'm still fairly confused why it got so many views," he said of the video's reception. "The reception was way beyond anything I expected, and I'mstill fairly confused," he added, adding that he plans to make more explainer videos in the near future. "It's a bit risqué, but that's not the point," he told CNN in an email. 'I was amazed that they didn't seem to have after I checked," he adds of viewers' reactions to the video. 'It's just a little bit of fun,' he said, adding, "I don't know why it's so popular. It's not like I'm trying to be funny, I'm just trying to make a point." 'I'm not trying to get attention, I just want people to know what I'm talking about,' he added. 'There's no point in trying to explain the universe to people who don't understand it,' he says.

text: Paul Rand (1914-1996) is acknowledged as the artist who lifted graphic design to a new level of Art. At the Museum of the City of New York, the breadth and scope of his career is in full display. text: Donald Trump criticized the National Football League during the 2016 campaign. But in 2016, the NFL set a revenue record, fueled by TV viewership. Trump is calling for another one, but you should expect the NFL to survive, and even thrive. The “Boycott NFL’ is destined to do as well as the boycott of the musical “Hamilton,” or of Stephen King’s “It.” We may find that Trump is as good for boycotts of sports and entertainment as Barack Obama allegedly was for the gun industry. John A. Tures is a professor of political science at LaGrange College in La Grange, Ga. He can be reached at jtures@lagrange.edu. His Twitter account is JohnTures2. He is also the author of the book, “The Power of One: The Rise of Donald Trump and the Rise of the Republican Party.’“The power of one is the power of two: The power of the left and the right,’ says John Tures. “There is no such thing as a two-party system. There is only one party system, and that is the United States.““You can’t be the president of the U.S. if you’re not the leader of the free world, and you can”t be president of a country if you are not the head of the country.�”

text: Extreme climate events have a significant impact on water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services. Droughts, floods, and cyclones can damage toilets, water supplies, and sewerage infrastructure. This has disastrous health impacts on the communities living in the slum settlements of urban cities. Water was mentioned for the first time in the final declaration adopted at the UN Conference of the Parties (COP27) held at Sharm el-Sheikh in November 2022. Building on the resolutions and commitments made at COP27, countries have to make serious efforts to find effective solutions to address the climate impact on WASH at the forthcoming COP28 in Dubai, say the authors of a new study on the vulnerability of slum areas of Bhubaneswar and Jaipur to climate change. The study emphasises the consequences of climate events on water and sanitation services. The authors of the study say the country still struggles with developing a climate-resilient WASH infrastructure and sustainable practices. They ask whether programmes like the Swachh Bharat Mission and AMRUT scheme have adequately addressed climate preparedness on both small and large scales.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Severe flooding and landslips cut off rail links to large parts of southwest England. Some areas have been underwater for over a month in the wettest January on record. angry residents criticise the government for not doing enough to prevent flooding. Britain's Met Office said several weather warnings remained in place for the coming days, with more heavy rain and gale force winds expected to hit Britain's south and west.. Prime Minister David Cameron has announced extra funding for flood defence repairs and maintenance. The Environment Agency chairman Chris Smith has faced calls to step down after a frosty reception when he visited flood-hit areas this week. "I'll apologise unreservedly and I'm really sorry that we took the advice," said the government's communities minister Eric Pickles, who took over responsibility for the flood response. "We thought we were dealing with experts," Pickles said on Sunday. "It was a mistake, there's no doubt about that, and we perhaps have relied too much on the Environment Agency's advice," he told the BBC, saying the government now realised rivers should have been dredged to help prevent flooding, he said. The leader of Britain's anti-European Union party UKIP, Nigel Farage, has called for some of the overseas aid budget to be diverted to help tackle the flooding. "Too little, too late," said Farage, speaking to the BBC during a visit to the region on Sunday, he described the government’s response as "too little,too late"

text: A Boeing 787 Dreamliner landed at Troll Airfield in Antarctica on Wednesday. The flight was operated by European low-cost carrier Norse Atlantic Airways. It carried 45 researchers and staff from the Norwegian Polar Institute, as well as 12 tons of research equipment. Antarctica has no permanent residents due to its extreme cold, but about 4,000 peopleresidethere during the summer months. In November 2021, an Airbus A340 operated by Portuguese charter companyHi-Fly landed on the seventh continent, becoming the first of its type to make the trek. In 2015, Icelandair's charter subsidiary Loftleider Icelandic Airlineslanded a Boeing 757 in Antarcticain 2015 — another world first for that model. The carrier has since made more recent trips in 2021 and 2022 using Boeing 767s and C-17 Globemaster cargo jets, among other models. The operation is no small feat, with harsh weather conditions and the reflecting runway creating added challenge and risk for landing planes on the rugged glacial landing strip.

text: Four men have been charged over the theft of an 18-carat gold toilet from Blenheim Palace.
