Seven people had been arrested over the heist, but no charges have been brought until Monday, four years after the toilet was stolen. The gold toilet was fully functioning, and visitors to the exhibition could book a three-minute appointment to use it, the Guggenheim Museum in New York said. The four suspects will appear at Oxford Magistrates’ Court on November 28, prosecutors said. the Crown Prosecution Service said Monday it has authorised criminal charges against four men, ages 35-39, over the Theft. text: Radio Disney is teaming up with Ohio's oil and gas industry to teach school kids that pipelines are awesome. "Rocking In Ohio" is an interactive, game show-like presentation entirely funded by the Ohio Oil and Gas Association and presented jointly with Radio Disney. Environmental activists are less enthusiastic about the partnership. Radio Disney has announced it is ending its partnership with the oil andGas industry. The traveling show is part of an industry-funded outreach program called the Ohio oil and Gas Energy Education Program (OOGEEP), which partners industry representatives with science teachers in the state. If this fall's pilot program is successful, it will be rolled out throughout Ohio in 2014. "The sole intent of the collaboration between Radio Disney and the nonprofit Rocking in Ohio educational initiative was to foster kids’ interest in science and technology," a Radio Disney spokesperson said in an emailed statement to The Huffington Post. "Having been inadvertently drawn into a debate that has no connection with this goal," Radio Disney said in a statement, "Radio Disney has decided to withdraw from the few remaining installments of the program" The show has made at least 26 stops at county fairs, science centers and schools. Youngstown previously saw a whole year of "rocking inOhio" as the city was struck by 167 earthquakes between January 2011 and February 2012. A recent study concluded the quakes were linked to an injection well that was used for disposing of the wastewater from oil andgas operations. No earthquakes had been recorded in Youngstown between the late 18th century and 2010, and the tremors have stopped since the well was shut down.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Former cycling champion Lance Armstrong agrees to pay $5 million to settle a federal suit. The suit claimed he defrauded his sponsor, the U.S. Postal Service, by using performance-enhancing drugs. The settlement ends the long-running false claims suit brought by fellow cyclist Floyd Landis. Armstrong won the biggest race in professional cycling, the Tour de France, a record seven times, six of them while riding for the Postal Service team. He was stripped of his titles and banned for life from the sport in 2012 after it accused him in a report of engineering one of the most sophisticated doping schemes in sports. and will pay $1.65 million for the court costs of his former teammate Landis, who also used performance- enhancing drugs and who was stripped in 2006 of his Tour De France championship. and his cancer survivor wife, Elliot Peters, says the settlement is the last legal matter related to Armstrong’s doping. and is reached ahead of a scheduled May 7 trial date. and Peters says he thinks the postal service realized it could not prove damages to it caused by Armstrong”s behavior. and that it reached the settlement ahead of the scheduled May7 trial date and that Peters says it was reached before the trial date was set for May 7. The Justice Department had sought $100 million in damages on behalf of the Post Office, according to statements from Armstrong's attorney and the Department of Justice. “No one is above the law,” Acting Assistant Attorney General Chad Readler says in a statement.

text: Paleontologist Bill Sanders has been studying proboscideans, the order of mammals to whichelephantsbelong, since the 1980s. Sanders has devoted his 40-year research career to tracking 60 million years of Afro-Arabian Proboscidean evolution. His survey was recently published in a book titled "Evolution and Fossil Record of African Proboscidesa" Now, just three species of African elephants remain: the forest and savannah elephants, the Asian elephant and the big tusks-bearing Earsmaas. The animals are a keystone of African faunas, ecologically dominant and the oldest surviving mammals in the world. They are also the world's oldest surviving species of elephant, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. The book's title, "Elephants, in a way, are the giant versions of canaries in a mine for the planet," is a nod to the elephants' role as canaries.

text: MB&F unveils its Horological Machine No. 11 ‘Architect’ watch in Dubai. The three-dimensional timepiece houses the brand’s 21stcaliber and the case is inspired by architecture of the 1960s. Each retails for $230,000 and is being offered in two versions – one with a blue dial plate or one with an 18-karat 5N rose gold dial plate. text: Ellen Weider has been engaged with the print medium for over thirty years. Her solo exhibit at the Manhattan Graphics Center in Manhattan showcases twenty-five black and white prints. Drypoint is a type of intaglio process, frequently used in combination with etching and acquatint. The majority of Weider's plates are circular. This serves to stand either in contrast to rectangular and angular constructs, or as a repetitive iteration of spherical elements within. Top motifs for Weider embrace the use of organic forms that speak to the mysteries of nature, and an ongoing vocabulary of geometric, architectural, and personal iconography. In Wish List, Weider places totemic hieroglyphics onto the façade of a chest of drawers. A series of scratchings evocative of the female body inhabit the center panel. The nervous energy and quirky, tactile lines of Drypoint reference the ironic humor of a New Yorker cartoon. Contained within the impression, here is a chair without a sitter and ordinariness of every day life. A companion piece, Balance, offers the viewer another piece of furniture -- a table without a leg -- a leg hovers between a metaphysical interpretation and the question of "When is a table just a table?" Weider -- like all artists -- has served her thought and comment on the world around her. The immediacy and spontaneity of drypoint has served as a muse to Weider for over 30 years, dating back to those who scrawled primal characters on a cave wall.
label: SAFE

text: Researchers in Cambridge, Massachusetts, have hit a breakthrough in their quest to develop pigs whose organs and other tissues can be transplanted into humans. The team, led by a biotechnology company called eGenesis, announced Thursday that it has successfully used a powerful gene-editing technique known as CRISPR to modify the DNA in pig cells. It's a huge step, as those viruses (more specifically known as porcine endogenous retroviruses, or PERVs) pose a not-yet-fully-understood but potentially significant health threat to humans. Next, the company needs to make sure it can consistently replicate virus-free pigs, which it’s already well on its way to doing. After that, it will need to test how the human immune system responds to the organs and modify them so they aren’t rejected, creating what she referred to as “pig 2.0,” featuring “advanced immune compatibility.” In the United States alone, almost 117,000 people are currently awaiting a lifesaving organ transplant, according to the United Network for Organ Sharing. About 60 percent of transplant operations since 1988 have been for a kidney (which has an average wait time of five years), 22 percent a liver (wait time: 11 months), 10 percent a heart (four months), and 5 percent a lung (4 months) The company is making very real, tangible progress toward that goal, but it doesn't want to speculate on when xenotransplantation might be a common procedure.
label: SAFE

text: A new paper says seas could rise more than six feet by 2100. Many cities, including New York, Boston and Hong Kong, would be partially underwater. The worst effects could be avoided if we slash or stop carbon emissions. World leaders have pledged to keep global warming below a threshold of 2 degrees Celsius. But the world isn't there yet, and global temperature records -- including the one set in February, the warmest such month on record -- continue to be broken.. The authors expanded the sea level rise estimates to the year 2500, and found that Antarctica could cause more than 50 feet of sea level Rise alone. In an interview with The Guardian, co-author Rob DeConto said global warming could force "retreat" from cities, rather than the "engineering of defenses" to avoid the worst effects of sealevel rise. But he noted that if humans are able to slash emissions, most of the Antarctic would remain frozen. The study was published Wednesday in the journal Nature, and is based on historical data from 130,000 years ago and 3 million years ago, when temperatures were warmer and seas were higher. It was written by David Pollard of Penn State University and co-authored by Rob Deconto of the University of Pennsylvania. It is the first study of its kind to look at the effects of melting ice sheets on sea level, which could contribute more than three feet to sea level rises by the end of the century, the authors say. five feet in the next century alone.

The research was carried out during the Japanese Antarctic Research Expedition of 2022/2023, which reached heights of approximately 1,000 meters above the sea level. text: The Broad, a new art museum in Los Angeles, opened last week. Some critics have been quick to point out the museum's deficiencies. The Broad is "a Trojan gift-horse and a giant Bose speaker masquerading as a temple of culture," one critic says. "The Broad's munificence is motivated only by their need to impress, and they can't possibly actually care about art," says another. "I'm going to make sure to use my personal visit as an opportunity to show that I'm just a bit cool for the place," says one critic, "This place is a bit above the fray and I'm not going to step back and say simply "I don't like it""The Broad is the worst thing to happen to Los Angeles since its electric streetcar system was shut down through the evil machinations of General Motors," says a critic of the museum. "Ask around," says Pulitzer Prize winning critic, Philip Kennicott, "and no one seems to like him," he adds. "This museum is our gift to L.A. and we hope you enjoy it," says Eli Broad, who founded the museum with his wife, the late philanthropist J. Paul Getty, and his late son Norton Simon. "It's absolutely stupifying," says artist Ralph Loynachan, "The whole museum's absolutelystupifying, it's glorious" and "I just want to go back and look at it again".

text: A setback in the Telescope Array has prompted scientists to reevaluate their experimental design. Researchers are optimistic about future success and are looking forward to the next phase of the project, which will involve the construction of a new observatory in New Mexico, Mexico and Texas. The project is expected to be completed by the end of next year and will be used to study the Earth's atmosphere from a new vantage point in the form of a giant observatory called the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) The LHC will be the first of its kind to be built in such a way that it can observe the Earth from such a large distance as to be able to observe the universe from a distance of more than a billion miles. It will also be the largest observatory of its type in the world at the time of its completion, with a capacity of around 100,000 square miles (250,000 km) and a cost of around $1.5 billion (US$1.6 billion) The project will be funded by a number of funding agencies, including the National Institutes of Health and the European Space Agency, as well as the National Science Foundation and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NSF). text: NASA's Juno spacecraft has entered orbit around Jupiter. The $1.1 billion mission all hung on a single 35-minute engine burn. Juno will continue a lengthy dance with Jupiter, circling the giant planet 37 times over a 20-month period. The spacecraft is set to meet a fiery death when it burns up in Jupiter's atmosphere in February 2018."I’m ready to unlock all your secrets, #Jupiter. Deal with it," a voice-over says in a NASA video. "It just so happens, deep inside this body are the secrets we're after," the video says. "Secrets about our early solar system." The heavily armored spacecraft has been built to withstand the planet's extreme, radiation-rich environment. "When you sail into terra incognita, that is always going to make you sit on the edge of your seat, because you don’t really know for sure what you’re facing," Heidi Becker of NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory told National Geographic. "We've only got one shot," Guy Beutelschies, director of space exploration systems at Lockheed Martin, told NPR. "If we miss this flyby, we're assuming the mission's over." The mission is also expected to provide scientists with a better understanding of our solar system as a whole, NASA said in a statement. "Jupiter is spectacular from afar and will be absolutely breathtaking from close up," Scott Bolton, principal investigator of Juno from the Southwest Research Institute said.

If pro athletes and entertainers want to freelance as political pundits, then they should not be surprised when they’re called out for insulting politicians’ There was no racial intent in my remarks,’ Ingraham said in a statement. ‘I have used a variation of that title for more than 15 years to respond to performers who sound off on politics,�’ she said of her 2003 bestseller ‘Shut Up & Sing.’ “We’ve got to speak what we believe in, we’ll definitely not shut up and dribble. I will definitely not do that. I mean too much to society, I meantoo much to the youth,“ James said.

text: Three new schools will open in Joplin, Missouri, this week, the latest step in the town's recovery. The May 2011 tornado that hit the town killed 161 people and destroyed 8,000 buildings. The three new schools cost $65 million, and were funded mostly through insurance and a bond issue voters approved in April 2012. All of the schools have been outfitted with safe rooms, where students and staff can take refuge in case of a tornado, school officials say."Milestones are important in the road to recovery and this certainly is a big one for us," said C.J. Huff, superintendent ofJoplin schools. The tornado was the single deadliest in the U.S. since records were first kept in 1950, according to federal agencies that track storm impacts. cold weather is expected to keep the new schools from opening on Monday, so they will be closed on Tuesday and Wednesday, the school district says. The new high school will open next fall to replace the school demolished in the tornado, and the students are now in a former store adjacent to a shopping mall, officials said. The city manager says 90 percent of the 7,500 homes and 500 commercial buildings destroyed in the storm have been replaced, and most of the damaged buildings have been repaired or replaced. "We said early on that we were going to build back bigger and better than before the storm," said Joplins City Manager Mark Rohr, who is also a former mayor of the town.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Beitar Jerusalem says it is adding "Trump" to the team's name. The team says it wants to honor President Donald Trump for recognizing Jerusalem as the capital city and moving the U.S. embassy there. The move has stirred resentment among Palestinians who hope to establish their own future capital in east Jerusalem. Beitar requires approval from the Israel Football Association, and could face legal challenges because “Donald Trump” is a registered trademark in Israel. The six-time league champion team has been penalized before because some fans have chanted anti-Arab and Muslim slogans during matches, CNN pointed out. The name change is not a done deal, according to The Jerusalem Post, and the team has not said if it will change its name to "Beitar Trump Jerusalem" or "Beitel Trump Jerusalem," as the team previously said it would do if the name change was approved by the FA. The club's offices were once set on fire after it signed two Muslim players in 2013, and fans have been known to chant anti-Muslim and anti-Palestinian slogans at matches. The U.N. Security Council passed a resolution condemning the move, but it has yet to be implemented by the United States, which is scheduled to open its embassy in Jerusalem on Monday. The embassy was scheduled to be moved to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv, sparking fierce protests, but the move was delayed until later in the week by the Obama administration. The Israeli Premier League team has won six league titles in a row.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers led by Shigehisa Akine at Kanazawa University have demonstrated howenvironmental changes can also accelerate or decelerate this chiral inversion process. The research ispublishedin the journalScience Advances. The researchers focused their study on metallocryptand (R6)-LNi3, an organic molecule featuringmetal atoms. It can exist in one of two possible forms described as the P or M type (right- and left-handed, respectively) The binding between cesium ion and the P type molecule was more than 20 times greater than that with the M type so the solution eventually switched to a higher proportion of the P:M ratio of 75:25 over the course of 21 hours. With potassium ion the equilibrium ratio was lower again at 68:32 but reached within just a minute, three orders of magnitude faster than for the cedium ion. The study can provide a new insight into the development of an on-demand time-programmable molecular clock fornew generationchemical technologies.
label: SAFE

text: Massachusetts College of Art and Design showcased its 108th student fashion show, entitled "Vision" Anna Wintour and Tim Gunn surely would have coveted these boutique-ready garments. Students study pattern drafting, illustration, computer creation, draping, women's and men's wear, tailoring, made-to-measure, bridal, fashion history and more. The program doesn't force themes (à la Project Runway) upon students, but rather allows them "to do what they do best," says James Mason, who curated this year's show. "I was struck by their varied methodologies as well as the diversity of the designs themselves," says Richard Bertone, editor-in-chief of The Boston Globe. "My only regret is that I did not see all of the collections as there were certain things I'm not certain of," he says. "You Need Me" is published by Pino Domenico at a cost of $24.99. For more information on the MassArt Fashion Design program, visit massartdesign.org or go to www.massacredirect.org. text: Michael Foster, a prominent volleyball athlete, is under investigation for violating anti-doping regulations. The case has sparked discussions about the pressures athletes face and the importance of clean competition. Sports organizations are reviewing their testing protocols to ensure comprehensive coverage. Athlete education programs emphasize the risks of performance-enhancing drugs to health and career. It is expected that the case is expected to be resolved within the next few months. It has been reported that Foster has been suspended from the sport of volleyball for a year and a half. He has not commented on the allegations against him, which he has called "completely untrue" and "completely without merit" The case is being investigated by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency (USADA) and the Department of Justice (D.C. Department of Education). It is not known if Foster will be charged with any crime, or if the case will be settled in a civil suit or a criminal trial, which could take place in the coming months. The investigation is ongoing and is being looked into by the USADA and the D.C., Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) The case was first reported by Sports Illustrated and has since been reported by CNN and other media outlets. Similarly, AQI in Major Dhyan Chand National Stadium was recorded at 404 and in Dwarka Sector 8 at 403. The AQI was 323 on Tuesday morning, as per the System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR-India). The Air Quality Index from 0 to 100 is considered as good, while from 100 to 200 it is moderate, from 200 to 300 it is poor, and from 300 to 400 it is said to be very poor and from 400 to 500 or above it is considered to be severe. text: CL J1001+0220 is 11.1 billion light-years from Earth. It contains 11 massive galaxies in its core. Nine of those 11 galaxies are forming stars “at a rate that is equivalent to over 3,000 Suns forming per year,” NASA says. The discovery was made using NASA’s Chandra X-ray Observatory and other telescopes, the space agency says. It was described in a study published Tuesday in the Astrophysical Journal. The cluster is “going through an amazing growth spurt unlike any we’ve ever seen,’’ Tao Wang of the French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission says. “This galaxy cluster isn’t just remarkable for its distance, it’re also going through a growth spur unlike any of us have ever seen," he adds.. The study was published in a journal published by the American Astronomical Institute and the French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission, which is part of the European Atomic Energetics Commission, which makes up the European Astronomy Commission (EAEAC) The EAEAC is based in Paris, France, and the EEAAC is a member of the International Astronomical Union (IAEC) and the European Institut of Astronomy, Space and Astronomy and Astrophysics (EASA), which makes the discovery.
label: SAFE

text: The sculpture, the work of Chicago-based artist Scott Reeder, simply reads “REAL FAKE” in metallic gold, uppercase letters. The artwork delivers a not-so-subtle dig at number 45, who has been frequently described as a “charlatan,” a ’scam artist’ and a ‘duplicitous demagogue’ Reeder’s piece was installed on Monday night by the Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events (DCASE) as part of the city’'s Year of Public Art program. Just one day after the piece wasinstalled, Trump was exposed for hanging fake Time Magazine covers with his face on the cover on the walls of his golf clubs around the world. The six-foot-tall artwork was first displayed at Art Basel in 2013, so, regardless of how fitting the Trump associations may be, it was made long before Trump was even a presidential candidate. The piece is not the only work of protest art scheduled to invade Trump Tower this summer. An architectural firm New World Design Ltd. has plans to erect golden flying pigs that would obscure Trump's logo from view. The firm says the references are many, from flying pigs and Miss Piggy comments to a taste for gold embellished interiors. Ultimately, this is a very rational design and is in direct contrast to the chaotic nature and bizarre antics of our current leadership,’ the firm said in a statement.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers have created a "shark-eye" camera that "simulates how the shark sees underwater" The impetus for this was the discovery of a group of shy sharks who produce a bright green biofluorescence. Biofluorescence is when molecules in the skin of an organism absorb the blue-hued wavelengths of visible light in the water and re-emit them as other colors. The team noticed the sharks increase the contrast of their biofluorescent glowing pattern the deeper they travel underwater. The contrast makes them brighter, allowing the sharks to make themselves more visible to neighbors of the same species and possibly communicate with each other, the researchers said in a statement. The researchers recently also made the first observation ofBiofluorescence in marine turtles. that all of these findings are "a big step toward a functional explanation for fluorescence in fishes," said John Sparks, a curator in the American Museum of Natural History’s Department of Ichthyology and a co-author of the study. "We’ve already shown that catsharks are brightly fluorescent, and this work takes that research a step further, making the case that bio fluorescence makes them easier to see by members of theSame species," Sparks said. "These animals [can] see other animals that are biofluorescing in the deep blue sea" and, if so, what way they're using it, Gruber said in the statement. "What does all this newfound bioflu fluorescent we are finding in the ocean mean?"
label: SAFE

text: Suella Braverman's plan would introduce new penalties in England and Wales for homeless people who authorities believe have rejected offers of help. She said: "We cannot allow our streets to be taken over by rows of tents occupied by people, many of them from abroad, living on the streets as a lifestyle choice" The plan is expected to be included in the King's speech on Tuesday, which sets out the government's legislative agenda. Labour's deputy leader, Angela Rayner, said the government should take responsibility for the housing crisis, rather than blame homeless people. London mayor Sadiq Khan described the proposal as "deeply depressing" and said it would leave vulnerable people to face the harsh weather conditions without any shelter whatsoever. The Liberal Democrats' home affairs spokesman, Alistair Carmichael, said it was "grim politics" to "criminalise homeless charities for simply trying to keep vulnerable people warm and dry in winter" The proposals are designed to replace elements of the 1824 Vagrancy Act.

text: Todd Williamson's exhibit No Rhyme or Reason is on display at the Rymer Gallery in Downtown Nashville. Williamson's style is clear and holds up to the Modernist ideal of formalism inciting an immediate emotional reaction. Williamson uses color to provide focus to the viewer but leaves the existential meaning to be resolved by the individual. Part color theory, part therapy these paintings appeal at visceral level. This is art to live with, perhaps to greet you at the door or stay where you relax. It is the type of work that commands simultaneous focus and escape. So I ask you, what do you imagine when you see Todd Williamson's art? Are you relieved, relaxed, thoughtful, worried? Your answer may say more about you than Williamson. Leave a comment; start a discussion. See No RhYme orreason at theRymer Gallery through May 2, 2015. For more information and artwork visit the Rymmer Gallery website, www.therymergallery.com and Todd Williamson’s page, http://www.toddwilliamson.com. The exhibit is on view until May 2 at The Rymer gallery, 5th Ave of the Arts, Nashville, Tennessee, 33rd Street and Magnolia Avenue, Nashville. The gallery is located in the historic buildings on 5th Avenue of the arts in downtown Nashville, located on the corner of Magnolia and 5th Street. To order a copy of this issue of Nashville Arts Magazine, visit www.nashville Arts Magazine.

text: A dog buries a dead puppy in what appears to be an act of mourning. The dog's attempt to preserve the pup's bone is rather astonishing. Last week, a Reddit user posted a photo of her two pets, a dog and cat, sleeping in the crate of their recently deceased sibling. According to a veterinarian, dogs experience basic emotions, including grief, just like people do."I had to put my dog Mauja down last Saturday. I didn't think my other animals were missing her, and then this happened," the Reddit user said of her deceased dog, Mauja. "There they were last night ... sleeping in Mauja's crate," the user added of her pets, Kooky and Gracie, who had never slept together before. "I didn't believe my other pets would miss her," she said of Mauja, who was put down on Saturday. "Then this happened. ... There they were," she added of the pets, who were sleeping in their deceased sibling's crate, "sleeping in the same room." "I was like, 'Oh my God,' " the user said. "It's like they're saying, 'I love you so much,'" she said, adding that Mauja had been put to sleep the day before, "and I'm like, what is going to happen?" "I don't know what to do," the dog replied. "What am I going to do?" the user asked, before realizing what was happening.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Five cheetah cubs are fighting for their lives after being delivered prematurely. Three males and two females are receiving around-the-clock critical care. Cheetahs are considered endangered, as their worldwide population has shrunk. Fewer than 10,000 remain in 23 African countries, according to the Namibian-based Cheetah Conservation Fund. The Cincinnati Zoo is a leading captive breeder of cheetahs, a big cat that is native to the savannahs of Africa. and is one of the oldest in the U.S. in terms of captive breeding. and number of cubs born at the zoo. Since 2002, about 54 cheet cat cubs have been born at Cincinnati Zoo. and Botanical Garden. and one in the United States in total. and about 54 in the world. since 2002. and more than 1,000 in the Asia-Pacific region. and many in Europe. and the Middle East. and North Africa. The zoo is the oldest captive breeding facility in the country. and has a population of about 2,000. in its breeding facility. and several other facilities in Ohio, Kentucky, Tennessee and New Jersey. and in South Carolina. and South Dakota, among other places in the South. The cubs will receive special care for the next eight to 12 weeks. and are expected to survive for up to a year, zoo officials say. and zoo visitors are allowed to peek at them through nursery windows. They are being bottle fed every three hours.

text: Brandon Kralik and Richard T Scott will be exhibiting their work at Syzygy in Lakeville, Connecticut on April 4th. The show is a summation of their work up until this point, which, for all of us is a critical point, for we as human beings are entering uncharted waters. The idea behind this exhibition is one of hope, one that combines classical painting techniques of the past and brings them with us into the 21st Century, into what we call a post contemporary paradigm. Painting is very much alive and now, more than ever, it can offer us a reprieve, a contemplative comfort, a place to rest the eye, even to counter the stress in our lives and relax the health threats posed by electromagnetic radiation. To be in the company of well crafted paintings is indeed a comfort. If you live with original oil paintings then you probably know what we are talking about. It is our hope that there is a place in it for paintings that are derived from a position of empathy and which speak to humanity in a dignified, symbolic language that is unique to painting. We hope to help deliver classically crafted paintings to a broader audience, a viewing public who not only has an interest in, a craving for what is happening here but is actually in need of what we have to offer. Richard and I have both heard this from collectors and viewers of our work for years, our aim to continue to add the work toward the masterpiece, as a whole with our work.
label: SAFE

text: Alexander Krushelnitsky is suspected of testing positive for meldonium. Court of Arbitration for Sport has launched a doping procedure against him. Russia has been accused of running a state-backed, systematic doping program. Russia is competing at Pyeongchang as neutral athletes, unable to use their own flag or national symbols. The Russians had been hoping that a clean record would persuade the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to allow them to march at the closing ceremony on Feb. 25 with the Russian flag and in national uniform. If confirmed, the violation would be considered by the IOC’s OAR Implementation panel, the body in charge of monitoring the OAR team's behavior at the Games. The World Anti-Doping Agency banned the drug in January 2016, deeming it to be banned for performance-enhancing purposes. In total, over 40, including more than 170 athletes, have tested positive for the drug since it was banned, including over 40 Russians. The IOC said on Monday that any doping violation will be decided by CAS and that a decision would come very quickly after analysis of a B sample. The case could imperil Russia's efforts to regain full Olympic status for future Games, which the IOC has said it would consider if it is confirmed. It is too early to draw conclusions about the ongoing probe, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters on a conference call in Moscow. The Russian curling federation said Monday it had launched an internal investigation of the doping case.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Soft material-based actuators have gotten a lot of attention in the scientific community in recent years because of their lightweight, quiet operation, and biodegradability. Researchers from Scuola Superiore Sant'Anna in Italy and Johannes Kepler University in Linz, Austria, developed a system that enables accurate force measurement in these actuators. The technique can be used to create robot muscles, changeable optics, and tactile surfaces. The study was published research in Nature Electronics. The research could lead to low-cost, high-performance solutions for assistive devices, automatic machines, and mobile robots for terrestrial, marine, and space exploration, according to the researchers. "The beauty of our model is its simplicity and that it is not limited to existing actuators," said co-first author David Preninger, co- first author of the paper and PhD-student at the Soft Matter Physics department at Johannes KeplerUniversity. "Our study enables the identification of material combinations that bring up to thousandfold energy consumption reductions" adds Prof Kaltenbrunner.
label: SAFE

text: At least 15 native Pacific Northwest tree species have experienced growth declines and die-offs. Researchers say drought-driven die-off is beginning of long-predicted shift in tree growing ranges. "Firmageddon" refers to more than 1,875 square-mile (4,856-square-kilometer) die- Offers evidence forests are reacting to climate change and droughts, says forest expert."The forests are moving uphill," says Forest Service aerial survey program manager, Daniel DePinte. "This is not considered a true fir mortality event," says Patrick Tobin, associate associate professor of ecology and ecology at the University of Washington. "Douglas fir is not officially part of Firmageddon," says forest health specialist, David Shaw, a forest specialist at Oregon State University. "We see increased Douglas fir mortality at higher elevations," says study co-author, David Shaw, a professor of forest health and forest science at OSU. "That's why it's the canary," says Buhl.
label: SENSITIVE

text: This year's overall harvest of cocoa, used to manufacture chocolate, is set to be very low. The crop is harvested twice annually -- October to March for the main crop and a May to August mid-crop. Some areas have seen rainfall this year between 20 and even 40 percent above the 1991-2020 norm. Cocoa provides a wage for around one in five Ivorians -- some six million people -- but if we deliver, how will we deliver? "In a liberalised system, (prices) would be winners in the current context," says Ivorian economist Seraphin Prao."Thirty years I've been in cocoa -- and this is the worst season yet," said Siaka Sylla, chairman of the cooperative grouping some 1,500 planters in Ivory Coast, the world's top producer of the bean. "We'd forecast a 20 percent drop on last year and our forecasts are confirmed," said Yves Brahima Kone, who heads Ivorian regulator the Coffee-Cocoa Council (CCC)
label: SENSITIVE

text: Kehinde Wiley will paint a portrait of former President Barack Obama next year. He will be the first black artist to paint the Smithsonian National Portrait Gallery. The former president and first lady hand-picked the artists who will render their official portraits. Wiley’s paintings are not simply exercises in corrective representation. They are intended to probe the mechanics of seeing and being seen, the artist said in a statement.. The performance of black American identity feels very different from actually living in a black body in the U.S., Antwaun Sargent, a 29-year-old critic, said. “He believed they were heroic, that they had painted the way they imagined themselves, the way society has always ignored them,” he said of Wiley. ‘Painting is about the world that we live in. Black men live in the world. My choice is to include them. This is my way of saying yes to us,’ Wiley said in an interview with CNN in May. � “I knocked on doors in the dead of winter when Obama was running for Senate. To see him choose an openly queer, black man who has devoted his career to depicting black folks, it's really full circle for me.” “Sometimes I’d walk through the galleries just to look at the way the faces and the hands are painted, all the nuances of black," Eugenie Tsai, the Brooklyn Museum curator who organized a 2015 exhibition of Wiley's work, recalled.
label: SENSITIVE

The incumbent president is favoured to win, particularly since there is only one round of voting, but representatives of five leading opposition groups met this week in South Africa to study the possibility of proposing a single candidate. text: Nick Foles was ready to retire from football at age 26, frustrated with his situation. When Carson Wentz got hurt though, in came Foles. He threw for 373 yards and three touchdowns in one of the wildest Super Bowls ever. “The stage is never too big for him,” said tight end Zach Ertz, who caught the game-deciding touchdown pass. The Eagles didn’t win because of a superior defense and a mistake-free day by a game manager of a quarterback. They needed someone to be better than Tom Brady and Foles proved to be that person. Philly beat the New England Patriots 41-33 in the Super Bowl to win their first Super Bowl in more than a decade. It was the first time the Eagles had won the game in the big game since Super Bowl XXXVIII in Minneapolis in 2004. The last time they had won a Super Bowl was in Vince Lombardi’s final season with the Cardinals in 2004, when the Eagles won the Lombardi Trophy in “Super Bowl XXXII.” The Eagles have won two Super Bowl titles in their last three attempts, the last in Super Bowl LII in 2010 and the most recent in ‘08. The Super Bowl win was the Eagles’ first since the “Philly Special” in 2002, when they won their first title in Superbowl XXXIV in New Orleans in ”Super Bowl XLII’ in ’08.
label: SAFE

Former Hull 2017 chair Rosie Millard: "I think very important things like the sensibility of Hull - the fact that Hull is cool, whereas once it used to be laughed at, that is a real change" The city's transformation is still in progress, with a multi-million pound Hull Maritime Heritage project, new road links and an improving night time culture. But many say Hull and its people have had a richer through the bad times due to their moment in becoming, and being, City of Britain. text: Marvin J. Taylor is the Director of the Fales Library and Special Collections at New York University. He founded the Downtown Collection, which has now grown to 12,000 linear feet of archives. The collection, which now includes vinyl, is so extensive that half of it is currently off-site, in a temperature and humidity controlled building in Putnam Country. The exhibit Martha Wilson: Downtown, an exhibit drawn from Wilson's personal papers, is one of 435 collections housed in the Downtown's comprehensive, controversial, and some might say, cantankerous archive. The first piece of downtown literature he read, given to him by his partner was Words in Reverse (1979) by Laurie Anderson, which presented texts from her performance pieces, where words, graphics, and minimal music merge in provocative non-linear ways. For Wilson, who founded Franklin Furnace, a not-for-profit arts organization whose mission was to "present, preserve, interpret, proselytize and advocate on behalf of avant-garde art" in Tribeca in 1976, the breaking down of divisions resonated deeply. "Marvin and I come from the same point of view," Wilson wrote in a journal entry by Wilson from the fall of 1998, she speaks of meeting Taylor. "I felt like my experience as a downtown person should be preserved by Downtown," Wilson said. "If Christy Rupp wanted to make posters of rats and post them on a curb that could have been made out of chicken bones," Wilson quipped.
label: SENSITIVE

text: More than 10,000 eagle pairs nest each year across the Lower 48, and many more in Alaska. The bald eagle was on the endangered species list for decades, and massive recovery efforts were put into place to bring the national symbol back. The conservation effort has not been easy and is still a challenge in some areas, such as the Channel Islands off the California coast. A neurological disease known as avian vacuolar myelinopathy (AVM) that causes brain lesions and impaired motor skills that ultimately result in death is a new danger the bald eagle species faces. The culprit seems to be blue-green algae, which becomes concentrated in the eagles' prey. The next steps will be watershed management to minimize exposure to the algae."Forty years ago, we probably would not have seen a single bald eagle here," says Bryan Watts, a conservation biologist at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va. A bald eagle nest cam in Decorah, Iowa brings in millions of viewers every season as the parents hatch their chicks. It's not often a livestream angled on a bird's nest gets that kind of viewership! The incredibly successful recovery over the last several decades is a conservation story to champion — and one to instill hope for other endangered species whose recovery is still underway. "The fascination with watching this species come back with vigor has been equally as wonderful as witnessing the recovery itself," says Elizabeth Shogren, author of "Bald Eagles: A Natural History of an Endangered Species"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Monday is the day people around the U.S. have been excited about for the past few months. Photographers across the country captured the phenomenon in various stages with cameras fitted with special filters. Check out the best photos so far of this rare coast-to-coast event below, and we’ll keep updating throughout the day. The total solar eclipse will be visible from coast to coast from August 21 to September 21. It will be the first coast-To-Coast eclipse of the 21st century, and the first in nearly 100 years. The eclipse will last for about two hours and 40 minutes, with a maximum of two minutes and 40 seconds. The moon will pass between the Earth and the sun in the event of a total eclipse, making it the longest total eclipse in recorded history, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The event will also be visible in parts of Canada, Alaska, Hawaii, New Mexico, Oregon, South Carolina, Wyoming and New England, with the exception of a few places in the Midwest and Plains states. It is expected to last for less than an hour and a half, depending on the location, and will be followed by a partial eclipse in the east and the west later in the afternoon and evening. The full eclipse can be seen from the east coast to the west coast, and from the West Coast to the north and south to the east in the mid-Atlantic and Great Lakes region of the United States and the Pacific Northwest.
label: SAFE

text: Abnormally low rain has dropped the Cutzamala system to historic seasonal lows. Officials began restricting water from the system by roughly 8% on Oct. 17. Friday's cuts represent a further 25% of the system's total flow. Officials did not specify when the restrictions would lift, saying only that restrictions would stand for “the next few months’ Mexico has never before announced such stringent or long-running restrictions to the city's water because of drought."The problem we face requires that, as citizens, we take responsibility," a water official says. three new water wells and improvements to 58 existing wells are announced, despite experts warning that city's groundwater is already severely depleted. The commission also says it will continue work on a new water treatment plant at the Madin reservoir, just northwest of Mexico City. The rainy season, which at normal levels of precipitation would replenish Mexico City's water, won't start until around May.. Mexico as a whole had 25% less rainfall than expected this year, compared to averages from the past three decades.

text: "The road ahead is not going to be easy. It never is, especially for folks like you and me," Michelle Obama said in her commencement address in May 2015. "I did walk on stage in a competition once, while audibly hearing a shocked audience member mention "Ein Schwarze..." (German for "A Black") "Once in Italy, I had to walk to my hotel and it was a hump. It was a small town and everyone knew I was not from there. I only saw two other Black people there" "My family was very openly refused taxi service in Berlin coming from an airport and made such a scene that caused another White taxi driver to comment, "What was his problem?" "Primarily in Europe, make-up artists refuse to apply my make- up because they don't know how to work with my complexion" "I have never worn a wig in Europe or been "whitened up" as I have in the States." "We had a concert at a country club with an Latino singer. They told us we had to park in the back and enter through the front door. When I told him I would go home first I walked in front of him and told him to do it in the front. He said, "I'm sorry, I didn't mean to offend you." "I can never sing certain traditional roles on the basis that I was never so bold to proclaim in America... This is something opera houses in America would never be so bold"

text: Kodo is credited with popularizing the Japanese drum taiko style around the world. They recently wrapped up their North American tour, which took them all over the U.S. and Canada. Kodo: Many changes have been made to Kodo's productions ever since we have welcomed in Kabuki actor, Tamasaburo Bando as our artistic director. The theatrical and humorous pieces were internationally acclaimed, and audience of all ages were able to enjoy the performance. The audience reactions are always very genuine; the length and timing of applauses, cheers, laughs, and the standing ovation after the finale, really reflects their feelings during the performance, Kodo says. The group's compositions are written by the performing members, and our production in particular, Mystery, featured many of the traditional Japanese folk arts from allover the country. The "ma" is a Japanese expression using a significant length of pause and silence. "Ma" is used to create humor in theatrical scenes, and express tension in concentrated serious scenes. The troupe will be back on U.s. soil in 2017, and you can see them in Europe next year. They spend most of their time during overseas and in Japan, and they will perform in Osaka Japan in May of 2015 for the musical production called Amaterasu. In August, we will host our 28th annual international music festival called Earth Celebration here on our home soil on Sado Island. After our performances of the production, Mystery,. we will have our next new production called Eternity, touring domestically in Japan. At the end of 2015, the newest production called Chaos will premier.

text: The Guggenheim Museum has removed three controversial artworks from an upcoming exhibition. The works, all by conceptual Chinese artists, came under fire last week when activists characterized them as “instances of unmistakable cruelty against animals in the name of art” In a statement on Monday, the museum claimed that “explicit and repeated threats of violence” ultimately led to the works’ removal. “Art and China After 1989” features avant-garde pieces from 150 Chinese artists working between the end of the Cold War and 2008. Themes of globalization, utopia, oppression, authority, violence, competition and control are prevalent throughout the show, with animals often symbolizing the debased human condition many endured during this transformative period in Chinese history. The final piece on the final block is Xu Bing’s “A Case Study of Transference,” which includes a live boar and sow in front of an audience. The original piece had comprised of temporary tattoos of nonsensical text in Roman characters. The American Kennel Club also released a statement, declaring, “Depictions of animal cruelty are not art’” Another contested work, the title piece of the exhibition, is Huang Yong Ping”s 1993 “Theater of the World” The work is a wood, steel and mesh dome equipped with heating lamps that can house hundreds of insects and reptiles inside, including locusts, crickets, beetles, grasshoppers, geckos and cockroaches.

text: New regulations to reduce the pervasiveness of flame retardants hit the books on Jan. 1. California's new Technical Bulletin 117 removes a decades-old requirement. The state rule, which became the de facto standard for the rest of the nation, meant use of the chemicals flourished for years nationwide. No safe method currently exists for disposing of furniture contaminated with flame retardant, experts say. "This is huge for the health of everybody in this country and for our environment," says chemist Arlene Blum, who first published an article about health dangers of chemicals 37 years ago. "What happens to the tens of millions of toxic sofas and chairs and baby products in this nation?" asks Blum. "There is the concern about second- and third-hand furniture ending up in these communities," says Ami Zota, an environmental health professor at George Washington University. "Right now, there are no easy solutions to this problem," says Zota. The American Home Furnishings Alliance, an industry trade group, said there will be "little or no cost involved in switching to the new testing procedure" The industry says there is "no reason for consumers to dispose of old upholstered furniture differently than other unwanted furniture. If it is reasonably in good condition – without tears or excessive tears – we would recommend it to a charity or a second-hand store," says the group, which is in anticipation of the regulation change. "We are going to see exposures to Flame retardants drop off," Zota says.
label: SENSITIVE

text: China launches its first privately developed rocket from a launchpad in northwestern China. The launch of the “Chongqing Liangjiang Star” rocket marks the first time a non-state Chinese rocket has successfully entered orbit. Chinese President Xi Jinping has made becoming a “space flight superpower’ a top priority for the Chinese government. The Chinese government has a goal of sending a permanent manned space station into orbit by around 2022, state media say.. The rocket uses energy-saving technology, such as wireless communications instead of wired internet that by cutting weight has helped lower fuel costs by about 30 percent, Xinhua says. The craft can place a 100-kilogram load into orbit 800 kilometers from the earth, according to state media. It is the result of a government effort to foster China’s commercial space flight and encourage private participation in the sector, the state media said. The company expects 10 missions for carrier rockets in 2019, founder Shu Chang told the official China Daily last week. “I hope we can become one of the biggest small-satellite launchers in the world,” Shu said, adding that the company expects a large export market for its rockets in the future. The base’S strategic location as part of the Belt and Road initiative, a key foreign policy initiative by Xi that aims to develop trade links between China and Eurasia, will provide a largeExport market for OneSpace, Shu said. They say they are grateful to have survived so far, but it is a bleak life without the sport they love and which gives it meaning."Football is powerful way to demonstrate that the Palestinian people, despite the challenges they face, are human beings," says trainer Ehab Abujazar, who used to be a player himself and has trained Ahmed and Ibrahim for many years. text: Scientific studies show that climate change is occurring faster than species are changing. Some species have been able to meet the challenge with rapid evolutionary adaptation and other changes in behaviour or physiology. However, rapid adaptation to climate change often comes at a cost. Populations get smaller due to the deaths of individuals that cannot tolerate new, hotter temperatures. Even if species do evolve to survive with climate change, their smaller populations may still go extinct due to problems such as inbreeding, harmful new mutations or plain old bad luck, such as a disease epidemic. Evolutionary adaptation isn't species' only option. The only option is acclimation, sometimes called "phenotypic plasticity" or "phenomenal acclimatization" The authors found that the species that gained an average of 0.2 C (about 0.1 F) from climate change were more than 100 per cent more likely to survive than those that lost 0.3 C ( about 0.4 F) in the last century.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Chinese researchers claim to have identified a unique group of cells that contributes to the ageing process. The cell subtype surrounds the motor neurons in the spinal cord and is believed to accelerate the ageing. It is a factor in the shuffling gait common among the elderly, according to an unedited paper published by the peer-reviewed journal Nature. The researchers tested the effects of vitamin C on 10 cynomolgus monkeys aged 17-18 years who were randomly divided into two groups. One group was given a daily dose of Vitamin C at 30mg/kg - dissolved in drinking water and given after breakfast - for 40 months. The other monkeys received the same quantity of drinking water, but without the supplement, to act as a control. The team analysed single cells to identify unique groups that developed around ageing motor neurons. Despite accounting for only about 0.3-0.4 per cent of all spinal cord cells, motor neurons are the principal actors in regulating body movement. They control the body's motor functions by directing skeletal muscles throughout the body.
label: SAFE

text: Bob Greene: Leonard Bernstein's MASS was my favorite music as a child. He says it was full of colorful, emotion-free opera-types singing in Greek. Greene: MASS is a textbook example of what a composer can do when he has the craft to conceal his craft. Bernstein's music is entertaining, illuminating and heartfelt, Greene writes, but with a clever twist. in "A Simple Song," Bernstein spells "G-d" out in music with the middle left out in the traditional fashion, just as Bernstein leaves the third out of his chord. The word "God" has been placed on the "forbidden" tritone, rife with ambiguity and harmonic instability, ready to modulate into any key; it's a note of many colors, but, in the event, serves as a "passing tone" to the words "simple song," which pass in four beats through iii, and a feint toward the dominant of A minor before settling on the relative major of A, C major, for the word 'lauda' And so it continues, sounding like a pop song and functioning on several levels all the way in the way Bernstein himself did at once, a musician's dream and a composer's dream. The next section frankly "comps" the listener in a way a novice guitarist might, like a cocktail pianist in C major in disarming way, keeping things unsettled but keeping the listener unsettled with an E-E flat cross.
label: SAFE

text: The U.S. and Chinese leaders meet Wednesday while attending the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in San Francisco. They go into the meeting on the back of five months of government-to-government talks that have accelerated in recent weeks. The November 2022 meeting in Bali, Indonesia, took place after China had suspended talks to express anger over a visit by then-U.N. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan. But tensions over Taiwan and flare-ups between China and the Philippines in the South China Sea are a sobering reminder that an unexpected incident could set back efforts to improve ties, just as an apparently errant Chinese balloon did early this year. "This rests on a stronger foundation than the Bali meeting did," said Jude Blanchette, a China expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "The more probable reality is it's going to be a little bit of that but we have a lot of speed bumps that can trip up the two at any point," he said.

text: "Voyage of Discovery" is a five-month exhibit hosted by the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The artwork includes a wide range of media, and features both individual and collaborative pieces. The exhibit runs through May 31 in Washington, D.C., and features works by artists Michele Banks, Jessica Beels and Ellyn Weiss. The pieces reflect the artists’ responses to the transformation of land and sea, says the AAAS website. "The artists are deeply aware of the damage done by climate change, yet intrigued by the possibilities of what lies below the ice and snow," says the website for the exhibit. a sampling of artwork on display at the exhibit: "Core, Drill, Spill" by Michele Banks and "In The Balance," mixed media by Jessica beels. "In the Balance," by Michele banks and Elynn Weiss: "The color of the land from white to green to black. The dramatic shift of theColor of the Land from White to Green to black" The exhibit is open to the public until May 31, and includes both solo and collaborative works by Banks, Beels, Weiss and other artists. It's on display in the National Gallery of Art, Washington, and the National Museum of Natural History, New York, in New York City, in addition to the National Air and Space Museum, which is also in the city's Little Italy neighborhood. The exhibition is on display through the end of the year, and is free to visit.

text: Merriam-Webster has added the word "Sheeple" to its dictionary. The word is a portmanteau of "sheep" and "people" The most-known example of the word is likely “Wake up, sheeple!” The word has been used as a politically-charged word since the 1940s, an Urban Dictionary entry says. It has also been used to support the war on terrorism in the past, the Urban Dictionary says. But, in 2017, could the dictionary be making another kind of statement by adding “sheeple” to the dictionary now? It’s a good idea to think about what the word means to you, and what it could mean to your friends and family, if you’re a fan of the dictionary. It could be a sign of things to come, or at least a hint of what to expect in the coming months and years, as we head into the 2016-17 presidential election season. It's a good time to be a sheep, and a great time to start thinking about how to use the word “Sheep’le’ to describe your friends, family and co-workers in a positive way, as well as in a way that doesn’t make you seem like a bad person or a bad influence on your friends or co-relatives. It can also be used to refer to people who are docile, compliant or easily influenced.

text: The Solar Impulse landed at Dulles International Airport outside Washington at 12:15 a.m. EDT. It will remain in the U.S. capital until it takes off for New York in early July for the last leg of its historic trip. If the plane completes the journey as planned, it will be the first solar-powered plane capable of operating day and night to fly across the United States. The aircraft is propelled by energy collected from 12,000 solar cells in its wings that simultaneously recharge batteries for night use. The project began in 2003 with a 10-year budget of 90 million euros ($112 million) and has involved engineers from Swiss escalator maker Schindler and Belgian chemicals group Solvay, organizers say. It is a test model for a more advanced aircraft the team plans to build to fly around the world in 2015, they say. The plane made its first intercontinental flight, from Spain to Morocco, in June 2012, and flew from Dallas to St. Louis in early June, the project says. It flew the first leg of the journey from San Francisco to Phoenix in early May and flew later that month from Phoenix to Dallas in late May and early June in St. St.Louis in earlyJune. The planes will be used to test new clean energy technologies, the organizers say, such as solar panels, wind turbines and other renewable energy sources that can operate at night and during the day for long periods of time in the future. to boost support for clean energy technology.

text: First images from Europe's Euclid space telescope released on Tuesday. They include a nebula resembling a horse's head, never-before-seen distant galaxies and even "circumstantial evidence" of elusive dark matter. Euclid blasted off in July on the world's first-ever mission aiming to investigate the enduring cosmic mysteries of dark matter and dark energy. It will do so partly by charting one third of the sky -- encompassing a mind-boggling two billion galaxies -- to create what has been billed as the most accurate 3D map of the universe ever. A series of scientific papers analysing what is in the five new images will be published soon, according to the ESA, which has dubbed Euclid its "dark universe detective" and dubbed James Webb its "space telescope of the future" and is currently hovering 1.5 million kilometres (more than 930,000 miles) away from Earth. images from another 16 hours -- making up a full day -- will be released in January.

text: Ted Gioia's recent article "Can Club Owners Make Musicians Play for Free?" is quickly going viral on social media with the jazz community. Unless involuntary servitude has been somehow re-instituted for jazz musicians playing clubs, I'm not sure how any club owner is forcing any musician to play for free. A musician's desire to make a living as a performer does not automatically require the rest of society to like it and pay for it. How many club owners would ask Lady Gaga or Keith Jarrett to playFor free? None. Why? Because both artists can generate ticket sales and bar receipts that exceed their fees. It's a mutually beneficial arrangement for both the club owner and the artist, which is how it must be. For most groups, especially jazz genre, it is impossible to do this on a regular basis. On top of that, keep in mind that approximately 60 percent of these businesses fail in the first three years. As if all of that boilerplate warfare weren't difficult enough, it gets worse by making several comparisons between musicians and strippers. And many jazz musicians are just confused -- they think that by virtue of opening a bar or restaurant, the owner automatically becomes a philanthropist with a registered 501(c)(3) If that's not the case, it's time for those unpaid wages to be paid! I don't blame the musicians. In most instances, they struggle to survive and have to grasp at any opportunity, however meager. But the owners are a different matter.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Cards Against Humanity redistributes $1,000 to 100 of its poorest customers. Against Humanity Saves America” initiative. It says the money has enabled it to purchase a plot of vacant land on the US/Mexico border and retain a law firm specializing in eminent domain to make it as time-consuming and expensive as possible for Trump to build his preposterous wall. Other outcomes included cards, thank you notes from children, and a policy paper written by the Chicago Children’s Museum in partnership with DonorsChoose to “support teachers who are creating alternatives to traditional homework.” You can read all the stories Card Against Humanity shared here. The game's creators say the move is meant to tackle the “biggest issue in the world: wealth inequality” The company also said it initially wanted to launch a “campaign to eat all the rich people and live in their houses,” but its lawyers advised against that, so it “settled for something more achievable.’“We ranked everyone based on their survey responses and geographical census data to figure out who most needed money,’ the site explains. “The poorest 100 people received a check for $1,.000, paid for by everyone else.�”

text: Irish startup Silicate is preparing to launch the initial trialof its advanced weathering technology to permanently eliminate carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere. The trial is set to occur near Chicago, US, with 500 tonnes of crushed waste concrete to be scattered over 50 hectares of agricultural land. Over one year, the ground concrete will disintegrate in the soil, activating an enhanced weathering process. During this process, the concrete will react with CO2 and turn it into carbonates, regarded as long-term storage solutions for CO2 emissions. Incorporating this substance into the soil helps to balance the pH levels, enabling better nutrient absorption for the plants. Consequently, this leads to healthier crops with increased yield and quality. Silicate then assesses the sequestered carbon emission, selling credits to major corporations to assist them in reducing their carbon footprint. By actively reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving soil health, Silicate’s solution is paving the way for a more eco-friendly and efficient future.
label: SAFE

text: A fish that has never been seen alive before has been caught on camera swimming in the depths of the Mariana Trench. The 4-inch-long ghostly looking creature, believed to belong to the Aphyonidae family, was glimpsed exploring a ridge 1.5 miles below the water's surface. "This is just remarkable," Dr. Bruce Mundy, fisheries biologist with the NOAA National Marine Fisheries Service, said in the now viral video. The Okeanos Explorer team is surveying the deep-water areas of the Marianas Trench Marine National Monument and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands until July 10. The scientists have been investigating fish habitats, mud volcanoes, ridges, deep-sea coral and sponge communities in a bid to further understand the extreme life present in the trench. "Some of us working with fish have wish lists, you know, a sort of bucket list of what we might want to see," Mundy added in the clip. "And a fish in this family was probably first on those lists for a lot of us," he said in an interview with CNN's "This Is Life on Earth" with Jarrett Bellini on Friday. "I am sure that this is the first time a fish of this family has ever been Seen alive," he added. "It's really an unusual sighting" and "just remarkable," he told CNN of the fish's appearance in the video. 'This is really a really unusual sighting," Bellini said.
label: SAFE

text: The global sports supplement market is projected to advance at a CAGR of 12.1% and reach a size of US$ 27.89 billion by 2034-end. The rise is being driven by growing fitness awareness and an increasing number of health-conscious consumers. The market stands at the intersection of health, fitness, and innovation, reflecting a global trend toward prioritizing physical well-being. Social media serves as an unparalleled platform for influencers, athletes, and fitness enthusiasts to showcase their lifestyles and endorse products. The endorsement of these products by prominent fitness personalities, celebrities, and athletes on social media platforms not only heightens consumer interest but also propels market growth. The United States exhibits a robust fitness culture, with a considerable portion of the population actively engaged in sports and fitness pursuits. This cultural trend, coupled with a growing awareness of health and wellness, has led to an upsurge in the demand for sports supplements across various consumer segments.

text: Chris Mazdzer is the first U.S. man to win a medal in the luge singles at the Winter Olympics. Austria's David Gleirscher took gold and Germany's Johannes Ludwig took bronze. The event premiered at the 1964 Winter Olympics, which is 54 years ago. Erin Hamlin, the flag-bearer at the Opening Ceremony, won the first ever medal by an American woman in the event in Sochi. The U.s. men’s team had previously captured medals in theLuge doubles competition (1998 and 2002) in Pyeongchang, South Korea, but this was quite a step up for the team that had finished 13th in two previous Winter Games. It's the first men's singles luge medal for TeamUSA, bringing home the #Silver! pic.twitter.com/jnd9VyDcyf — Team USA Luge (@TeamUSALuge) February 14, 2018 It was also the first medal for an American women in the Luge singles competition at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, which was also 54 years old. It was the first time an American had ever won a bronze medal in luge. The team had won two golds in the doubles competition in 1998 and 2002, but never a singles medal before this year's Games in South Korea. The men's luge team will compete in the men's slalom event on February 16 and the women's singles on February 17.

text: Australia's tropical northern rivers still run wild and free. These relatively pristine areas have so far avoided extensive development. There areongoing scoping studies exploring irrigating agricultural landusing water from these rivers. Reducing river flows would also disturb mangrove and seagrass habitats and threaten the iconic endangered largetooth sawfish. Freshwater flows to the sea play a crucial role, boosting the productivity of marine, estuarine and freshwater systems. Thesecomplex interactionsmust be carefully considered in the assessment of future development plans. Any plan to dam or extract freshwater from Australia's last wild rivers should account for these effects.This is already a dry continent already challenged byclimate change. Every drop counts. text: Russian photographer Aleksandr Rodchenko revolutionized photography in the 1920s. His early work was part of the thriving Russian artistic avant-garde. His later work, from the 1930s until his death in 1956, focused on sporting events, parades and other traditional subjects for propaganda. Through June 28, the Palazzo Manin Codroipo in northern Italy is presenting one hundred works from the artist showcasing his subjects, techniques, and inventions. The collection covers his work for magazines, cinema and advertising, as well as an evocative self-caricature from 1922 and many beautiful compositions created with Varvara Stepanova, his partner and companion. This exhibition strips away the dictates of Socialist Realism to reveal the vivid, thoughtful, unforgettable images for which Rodchenko is known. This post was originally published on HuffPost Italy and was translated into English. It has been updated to make clear that the exhibition runs through June 28 in Italy, not June 30 in the U.S. and that it is not open to the general public in the United States or Canada. For more information on this exhibition, visit the Paluzzo Man in CodroIPo in Northern Italy or click here for more information about the exhibition. The exhibition runs from June 28 through June 30. The Palazzi ManinCodroipi is located in the town of Manin, in the province of Liguria, northern Italy, and is open from 9am to 5pm daily.

text: Researchers found that women of color in astronomy and earth sciences face a disturbing amount of harassment in the workplace. Women of color said they felt unsafe at work 40% of the time (28% of which they attributed to their race), while 18% said they avoided work events because of these concerns. "How do you become a fantastic scientist if you're not in the room to do science or learn science?" one of the study's authors said. If we're going to make strides in space and science, we definitely need women. Making sure these women feel safe at work should be a guarantee, not an uncertainty, according to the study. NASA said it does not tolerate sexual harassment, and any behavior that demeans or discourages people from fully participating is unacceptable. The agency takes very seriously its obligations, both legal and ethical, to make sure that when it provides federal dollars to a STEM educational program that the program is extending equal opportunity to all of its participants," the agency said in a statement. "I'll admit that I had a very stiff drink and cried myself to sleep that night [after I first looked at the results]," one study author said. "As someone who's worked on this issue for many years within this field and with these people, I know these respondents. They are my friends and my colleagues. I know their faces," she said of the survey's results. "Science is for everyone," NASA said in response to a request for comment from Refinery29.
label: SENSITIVE

It’s an incredibly exciting market for us and a major focus of ours." text: Apple Music Classical was launched earlier this year for iPhone and Android. The app can play songs in high fidelity at 192 kHz/24-bit rate and supports spatial audio. However, unlike Apple Music, it does not support the ability to download and play music offline. Users who already have an active Apple Music subscription can download and listen to songs on Apple Music Classical for free. It is already available oniOSandAndroidand can be downloaded for free from respective app stores. It features more than 5 million tracks ranging from celebrated masterpieces to new releases. text: Hepworth Brewery adds Chart Industries’ (NYSE: GTLS) Earthly Lab’s CiCi® carbon capture technology to help them reduce their carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions. Hepworth is also recycling the CO2, a key resource used in breweries, to also hedge against theCO2shortages in the UK that have plagued the food and beverage industry since 2020. This marks the first installation of Earthly Labs small scale CO2 capture solution in Europe. Chart will accelerate its support of the multibillion carbon capture utilization and storage (CCUS) market with the support of its recent acquisition of Howden, headquartered in theUK. The UK government announced its new approach to carbon capture, usage and storage in October 2017 called the Clean Growth Strategy. The approach was designed to enable the UK to become a global leader for CCUS and ensure that government has the option of deploying CCUS at scale during the 2030s. To reduce transportation emissions and make better beer, Hepworth relies on local ingredients supplied by the farmers of Sussex including organic barley from the Goodwood Estate.

text: Deforestation in the Amazon causes land surfaces up to 100 kilometers away to get warmer, according to a new study. The research, by a team of British and Brazilian scientists, suggests that tropical forests play a critical role in cooling the land surface. In the southern Amazon, where forest loss is the greatest, reducing deforestation would have the biggest benefit reducing future warming by more than 0.5°C in Mato Grosso state. The study, "Amazon deforestation causes strong regional warming," was reported in the journalProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. The regional warming due to Amazon deforestation will have negative consequences for the 30 million people living within the Amazon basin, many of whom are already exposed to dangerous levels of heat, the researchers said. The scientists also analyzed how future deforestation might further warm the Brazilian Amazon over the 30 years from 2020. They looked at two scenarios, one where the Forest Code is ignored and protected areas not safeguarded. The second, where there is some protection in place.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Prince of Wales announced the winners of his annual Earthshot Prize. He said he believed this was the decade for collective action to protect the planet. Each winner will receive £1m ($1.2m) to develop their innovation. The prize's name refers to the "Moonshot" ambition of 1960s America by then-President John F Kennedy, who pledged to get a man on the Moon within a decade. The awards ceremony was co-hosted by actress Hannah Waddingham and actor and producer Sterling K Brown, with attendees including Hollywood star Cate Blanchett and former New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern. There were also performances from Bastille and OneRepublic, who Prince William revealed his youngest son Louis was a fan of. Guests were asked to wear "pre-loved" clothes.

text: The Beatles released what Paul McCartney calls "the Beatles' final song," titled " Now And Then ." This new piece has emerged not from an archive, but from the intersection of artistry and artificial intelligence. "Now And Then" originated from a 1970s Lennon recording in New York's Dakota building. The 2023 enhancements feature McCartney and Starr's instrumentation alongside Lennon's vocals, with Harrison's guitar work and Giles Martin's string arrangement completing the ensemble. Some argue that despite the technical masterpiece, the Beatles as a collective entity ceased with the passing of Lennon and Harrison. text: The EU approved in April the world's first plan to impose a levy on high-carbon goods imports from 2026. The levy would pose a big threat to steel producers in China as long as their production remains more carbon-intensive than in the EU. The new regime entered a trial stage in October, requiring importers of goods into the EU only to report carbon emissions embedded in those products. The carbon border levy aims to put EU industries and foreign competitors on a level footing, to prevent EU producers relocating to regions with less stringent environmental rules. However, it will also raise costs of steel products shipped to the EU, weakening China's price competitiveness, experts say. The scheme will likely increase China's export costs ofsteel products by between 4 per cent and 6 per cent, Jiang Wei, the association's vice chairman, told reporters in late October. The China Iron and Steel Association (CISA) said the EU's unilateral establishment of CBAM is in essence a new trade barrier created under the auspice of low carbon.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service proposes to remove federal protections for gray wolves through most of their historic range in the lower 48 States. At least 1,321 wolves have been killed by trophy hunters and commercial and recreational trappers in Wyoming, Montana, and Idaho alone. Montana sold over 6,000 wolf-hunting licenses this season; each license -- $19 for state residents -- allows a person to kill up to five wolves. Wolf watching generates approximately $30 million annually to the towns around Yellowstone; the cost to reintroduce and recover wolves into the Northern Rockies was estimated to be more than $150 million. The Service has extended the public comment period regarding their proposal to delist wolves from the ESA and has rescheduled public hearings. If you want to see wolves in the wild please click here, take action, and make your voice heard. The service will accept comments through December 17th. Check out Project Coyote's homepage and Facebook page for more updates on the proposed delisting of gray wolves. The current wolf population in Montana is estimated at 625. The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources estimates the total state wolf population to be around 800 -- and would like trappers and hunters to reduce the population to 350 -- a number scientists say is not sustainable. In just seven days of this year's wolf hunt in Wisconsin, 97 wolves were killed -- about twice the pace at which Wolves were killed last year, the state's inaugural and very controversial wolf-hunt season. The result:

text: Swift was the most-streamed musician all around the world in 2023.
