Rounding out the top five most-played artists on Spotify throughout 2023 are The Weeknd, Drake (No. 4) and Peso Pluma (no. 5) The latter star appearing above names like Travis Scott and SZA is surprising, considering how new he is. He only reached the U.S. charts for the first time in the last year or so, but now he ranks as one of the top stars on the planet. The current Grammy nominee likely would have ranked as the most popular act on Spotify even if she had remained silent throughout the year, but she certainly didn’t. She began 2023 riding high off of the success of her recent album Midnights.

text: Rooney was admitted to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2000. He served as U.S. Ambassador to Ireland from 2009-12. Rooney’s father, Art, purchased the Steelers in 1933 and the family has run the team since. Pittsburgh has won six Super Bowl titles under the family”s leadership. The edict that teams with openings must interview at least one minority candidate became known as the “Rooney Rule.’ “My heart is heavy today as the passing of Dan Rooney leaves a void that can never be filled,” Carolina Panthers owner Jerry Richardson says. “While a winner and a competitor at the highest level, he was kind, classy and a true gentleman. He was a giant in our industry,’ Baltimore Ravens owner Steve Bisciotti says. The cause of death has not been released, but the Steelers say it was not a cause of injury or any other health problems that have plagued the team in the past. The NFL commissioner calls Rooney “one of the finest men in the history of our game” and a “role model and trusted colleague to commissioners since Bert Bell, countless NFL owners, and so many others in and out of the NFL’” The Steelers say they are “devastated” by the news. The team says the team is “deeply saddened’ by the loss of the man who has been with the team for more than 60 years.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere hit new record highs in 2022, U.N. warns. Carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide all broke records last year, says World Meteorological Organization. Such levels of heat-trapping gases will mean further temperature increases, more extreme weather and higher sea levels, says WMO. 2015 Paris Agreement saw countries agree to cap global warming at "well below" two degrees Celsius above average levels measured between 1850 and 1900 -- and 1.5C if possible. The bulletin comes ahead of the November 30-December 12 COP28 UN climate summit in Dubai, which will be held from November 30 to December 12, 2015, says the WMO's chief Petteri Taalas. "Despite decades of warnings from the scientific community, thousands of pages of reports and dozens of climate conferences, we are still heading in the wrong direction," says W MO chief Petters Taal as he warns of the need to reduce fossil fuel use as a matter of urgency.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Oregon beat Kansas 74-60 in the Midwest Regional Finals. Tyler Dorsey led the game with 27 points. Jordan Bell was all over the court, scoring 11 points, grabbing 13 rebounds, blocking eight shots and even getting four assists. The Ducks will face the winner of the South Regional final between North Carolina and Kentucky in the national semifinals. Oregon shot 51 percent for the game while holding Kansas to 35 percent shooting. Oregon, helped by Dorsey’s 6-of-10 from distance, shot 11- of-25 from beyond the arc. Kansas, the favorite playing before a virtual home crowd, was dominant in their first three games winning them by an average of 30 points and scoring at least 90 points in each. The Jayhawks did not have the rim protector that Oregon had and that was a big difference in the game. Oregon had a +4 edge in rebounding but what was more important was Bell's eight blocks. The Oregon Ducks will now face Kentucky or North Carolina for a place in the Final Four in Phoenix, Arizona on Sunday. The game was played in front of a sell-out crowd of 17,000 at the Moda Center in Kansas City, Kansas. Oregon won the first two games of the tournament by a combined score of 80-60. The win sends the Ducks to their first Final Four since 1939 and their first trip to the Elite Eight since 1939. They will face either North Carolina or Kentucky for a chance to face off in the NCAA Championship.

text: Delhi is world's most polluted major city. Pollution hit hazardous levels on Friday, forcing the city to shut schools and impose emergency measures. Air quality index as high as 565 in some areas, the Indian capital was the world’s most polluted city on Friday morning. Regional commission for air quality management activated a crisis plan, which includes halting construction works, encouraging the use of public transport and working from home when possible. Air pollution from a range of sources, including road traffic, construction and biomass burning in agrarian states contributed to nearly 1.7 million deaths across India in 2019, according to The Lancet journal. While Asia remains a hotspot of pollution, concerns over the health impacts of poor air quality are growing around the world, with major cities in the US and Canada experiencing pollution levels similar to Delhi's due to wildfires, an occurrence likely to become more frequent due to climate change. Apple set a new quarterly revenue record in India with a strong year-on-year growth in the September quarter.

text: "Memphis" is about as timely as one can get, given the intensification of attention to racial conflicts. The cast--the entire cast--had the opportunity to discuss their own experiences of the racial divide in our country. When we assume things--or people--to be one way or another, theater can be gruesome in its power and power in our personal lives, writes CNN's Nina dos Santos. "Memphis," is a Tony award winning show about a white man from Memphis who radically transformed music history by starting to play "black" music, gospel and rhythm and blues, on mainstream stations. It's a richer experience since the actors are all involved in serving as well, so both they and audience members get to relate on different levels to one another, says Dos Santos, who saw the play in Fort Collins, Colorado, and was moved by the performance of the whole cast and crew. The show ends with dessert and bill paying come in intermission when the people you just saw as stars that could bring you to tears, come back to serve you again, says dos Santos, and it's a great way to say goodbye to a great play. Theater producer and director and owner of the Midtown Arts Center, Kurt Terrio, talked about the need for affordable theater, and about how having dining be part of the occasion can also remove some of the obstacles involved in traveling significant distances, he says. He says Fort Collins doesn't have those problems, since it seems to the naked eye to have fewer African Americans in the whole of it, than " Memphis" had on stage.

text: The Winter Olympics in Pyeonchang, South Korea, are already stomach-churning. The host country has called in the troops after pulling 1,200 civilian security guards from duty amid a norovirus outbreak. Dozens of guards were already hospitalized Sunday for sudden vomiting and diarrhea. The civilian guards will be sequestered until it is determined that they are “well,” CBS News reported. The infected guards are in stable condition, the statement said, and all Olympic living quarters and buses are being sterilized. The CDC says you can contract norov virus by drinking contaminated liquids, touching contaminated surfaces and putting fingers in your mouth, or having contact with someone who is infected. Competition begins Wednesday and the opening ceremony is Friday, according to the Olympics committee. The outbreak has not been ruled out, but officials are focusing their investigation on food and water sources at the facility where the guards resided, CBS News said. They are also inspecting other facilities that rely on groundwater, the report said. The investigation is ongoing, and officials still have not determined the origin of the norov Virus, the CDC said, but it is believed to be a food or waterborne illness that can be transmitted through contact with contaminated surfaces or by sharing a fork or utensils. The Winter Olympics begin Wednesday, and the Opening Ceremony is Friday. The U.S. team is scheduled to compete in the men's hockey tournament on February 14 and the women's hockey competition on February 15.

text: The mountain valleys of the North Indian state of Uttarakhand have been heavily developed with hydropower projects, tourism resorts and other infrastructure. When a cloudburst hit the state in June 2013, the choked rivers were unable to cope with the ravaging floods. Floodplains, marshes, dunes, reefs and mangrove forests -- often referred to as green infrastructure or bioshields -- are vital to making our societies more climate resilient. A new report published by International Rivers offers guidance on how to strengthen climate resilience in the water and energy sectors. The guide explains how rivers act as natural climate buffers, how large dams increase the vulnerability to climate change, and how climate resilience can be integrated into water resource management and infrastructure planning. The new report equips civil society groups to advocate for infrastructure investments that strengthen rather than weaken the climate resilience of ecosystems and human societies. Contact Dipti Vaghela at International Rivers if you would like to host a training or suggest a translation of the new guide, or if you want to offer a training on climate resilience to civil society organizations around the world. The report will be complemented by a video, and used for civil society training workshops on climate resilient in different parts of the world, including the U.S., China, South and Southeast Asia, Africa and Latin America. It will also be used for a video to be shown at the International Rivers Climate Resilience Summit in New York on November 26-27, 2013, at 10:30am.

text: Wolf Hall is based on the novels by Hilary Mantel. Mike Poulton has adapted them in broad brushstrokes and director Jeremy Herrin keeps all the gossip and scandal and backstabbing moving along nicely. But the great strength of the novels is their interior richness. Sadly, the play doesn't attempt this. A further problem is the Winter Garden Theatre. This is a gigantic venue perfect for spectacle (like ABBA's long-running Mamma Mia and Cats) You might assume Wolf Hall is a spectacle too (20+ actors! Medieval pageantry!) But it's not. The setting is spare and the strongest moments are very quiet ones. By and large, the closer you are to a drama the better you'll appreciate the actors and that is especially true in this giant space. I was lucky to have seats better than 75% of the audience but they were still too far away. Get within eight rows of the stage (and centered) and it won't improve the play as such but you'll certainly have more fun than the many people far behind you. Oh how this might have played better at say the tiny Circle In The Square. (Truly, finding the perfect venue for a show is a rarely acknowledged challenge. I assume economics played a factor in bringing this to the Winter garden since it's such an expensive endeavor, so who can blame them?) The script is certainly of a piece with the theater -- it's big and broad too, and the actors seemingly take their cues from it.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Next month, thousands of federal firefighters may face hefty pay cuts. The cuts could reduce staffing levels among the federal workforce. Congress latersigned off on a pay raise of $20,000 a year, or 50% of a base salary for federal firefighters. But the House still doesn't have a speaker after Rep. Kevin McCarthy of California wasoustedfrom the role last week. The National Federation of Federal Employees said that "30 percent to 50 percent of the workforce" could leaving their positions if pay increases were no longer in effect. But with the threat of a showdown looming, time is running out for a permanent solution to the pay issue. The threat of an exodus of firefighters has many worried with the risk of wildfires becoming a growing environmental and economic threat across the country, but especially in Interior West states like Colorado. The photographer is based in Berlin, Germany and lives with his wife and two children. He is a Taiwanese-French-American and lives in Berlin with his family. "This is Gavin Beschen’s favorite photo to shoot. He has tons of style, which makes my job really easy in early early in the morning," Laserwolf said of his favorite surfer to work with, Russ Bieli. "I call this one beginner's luck because I nailed it my first time shooting out at Pipeline," LaserWolf said of the photograph above. "The sky was on fire with all sorts of red, pink and oranges" said Laserwolf of the sunrise photo above, "I got up to shoot the sunrise this morning. It's full on vibes on full vibes," said LaserWolf of the sunset photo above. 'This is probably my favorite photo that I've shot. I don't know how I didn't get sucked over," Laser wolf said of a photo he captured while shooting in Tahiti. 'I'm up in the lip of the wave looking down on the surfer inside the barrel,' he said of another photo he shot. 'When one of these grabs a hold of you, there is no escaping it. text: Uganda's civil war decimated traditional Acholi ways. "Forged in Fire" is a modern play rooted in Ugandan and Acholi storytelling and musical traditions. The basic elements of theatre are universal: poetry, motion, emotion, visual arts and music. Anyone can relate to these things, even if you are blind or deaf, you will appreciate theatre. The play shows my cultureing with persistent violence, leavened with music, dance, and humor. I am also tweaking our instincts to consume the dark stories of the world, to seek out the dark. If others can relate, maybe they will begin to dream about peace on Earth, where no child suffers unnecessarily, no child on Earth suffers unnecessarily. It's a play about a child who is a tour guide taking tourists beyond sight-seeing and into the heart of the war zone. To me, that character is asking the audience to step beyond looking, when they see something terrible happening, to act when they act. It is a play with songs, forged in fire. (Runs through May 15, in New York.) Theater might be unique form of memory and love, but Godfrey was and is part of me, part of my identity and my existence. It has been important to me. Theatre enhances life; it makes me feel more alive, as a performer and spectator. Theatre has a broad reach and endless life. It makes you feel alive as a person, as an individual, and as a community.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Hops, the flower of the hop plant, are the crucial fourth ingredient in the beer brewing process - alongside water, yeast and malt. In some key hop-growing areas, there was a drop of nearly 20% in output. Hotter, longer and drier summers are predicted to worsen the situation, and could lead to beer becoming more expensive. The authors warned growers to adapt their farming techniques. Beer is a staple of European culture - with 8.5 billion pints sold in the UK alone, according to the British Beer and Pub Association. The price of beer has already increased by 13% since the pandemic in 2020, due to an increase in energy costs driven by inflation, and the gas crisis following the invasion of Ukraine. But the study authors warn that further investment is needed, and say it will be necessary to expand the area used to grow aroma hops by 20%, to compensate for future decline. The research has been published in the journal Nature Communications. The study predicts that the bitter acids will reduce by up to 31% by 2050.

Since this is Bill Evans, the music sings as well as swings.. The vinyl version will be released for Record Store Day on Friday, Nov. 24, with the CD edition scheduled for Dec. 1. “Waltz for Debby” receives a lovely, spirited rendering, and while “My Foolish Heart” begins at a mournful tempo in two performances, Evans’ embrace of the melody soon dispels the gloom.“I Didn’t Know What Time It Was’’ is the only recording of the Rodgers-Hart song.

text: Pulitzer Prize-winning American poet John Ashbery died Sunday at age 90. The cause of death was not disclosed. Ashbery won the Pulitzer Prize for “Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror’ in 1976. He was deeply influenced by abstract expressionist art and early in his career was an art critic. He tried to capture the experience of disorder in his poems, with experience slipping away from the process of understanding, he said in a 1983 Paris Review interview. The son of a biology teacher and a farmer, Ashbery wrote his first poem at 8 and was awarded the National Humanities Medal in 2011 by President Barack Obama. He published more than 20 books of poetry and was known for the complexity of his style, U.S. media reports say, citing his husband David Kermani. He died at his home in Hudson, New York, the New York Times and ABC News say. He is survived by his wife and three children. He won the National Book Award and National Book Circle Critics Award in the same year of his 1976 Pulitzer Prize win, according to the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting. He also won a Fulbright Scholar award in France in the 1950s and 1960s. The poet was a member of New York's New York school of poetry in the 50s and 60s, and later of the New England School of Poetry, which he co-founded in the 1970s and 1980s. He wrote his last poem in 2011.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A large Australian team led by Monash University has devised a new approach to killing antibiotic-resistant bacteria using lipid nanoparticles. The nanoparticles target specific layers on the surface of the bacterial cell. The new complex was effective against to a wide selection of hypervirulent strains of K. pneumoniae, A. baumannii, and P. aeruginosa, including multidrug-resistant pathogens. Other steps will expand the study to test against other pathogens where resistance to established treatments is proving problematic. The research was published in the journalSmall. It was led by Prof. Jian Li, Prof. Anton Peleg, and Associate Prof. Hsin-Hui Shen of MonashUniversity, Australia. The study was funded by the Australian Centre for Neutron Scattering and the Australian National Institute of Health and Welfare, Canberra, and the University of Melbourne. The team also received a grant from the Australian Research Council and the Department of Science and Technology, the Australian Academy of Sciences, Canberra.

text: Mick Hussin was on holiday in Byron Bay, New South Wales when he saw a pack of dogs chase a wallaby joey into a nearby creek. Hussin jumped into the creek and was able to grab the animal by the tail and pull it to shore. He cupped his hands into a funnel and began performing CPR on the joey. "After ten minutes of performing CPR, the wallaby's hands started to move. It was the greatest feeling when I saw its paws move," Hussin said. "It is sad that a few seconds and the ability to deliver CPR is the difference between life and death," WIRES general manager said in a press release. "We are very pleased that Mr Hussin chose to breathe the kiss of life into this beautiful creature," the organization's general Manager said in the press release, according to a NSW Wildlife Information, Rescue and Education Service (WIRES) This wasn't the first animal rescue operation for Hussin, who had only completed his CPR training a few weeks before. 10 years ago, he rescued an injured puppy from a puddle. Now "it's a 68 kilo Rottweiler-cross-Great Dane and still living with us ... he could fit in your hand when we found him," he told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. "I thought I might've been wasting my time, but I thought I would keep trying anyway," he said of the rescue operation 10 years years ago when he rescued the puppy.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Flower Market Madeline by Edouard Léon Cortès turned up in Mawdesley. It was one of 3,000 works stolen over a 12-year period in the 1950s and 1960s. Art Recovery International was alerted to the painting when a Lancashire-based art dealer offered it up for sale online. It depicts a flower market in the style of other street artworks by the French artist. He was eventually arrested in Chicago by the FBI in the 1960s and convicted of transporting stolen artworks across state lines. Most of the paintings were never recovered but one has now been found in the UK. The painting was bought in November 2022 by Carnes Fine Art from the Manchester-based Capes Dunn auction house. It had been consigned to the auction house in 2022 by a Cheshire estate who confirmed that it was acquired from the MacConnal-Mason Gallery in London. Mr Carnes said he paid more than £10,000 for the work.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Texas is the top producer of renewable energy in the US. The state has long generated the most wind power and is second only to California as a solar-energy producer. As of October, wind and solar met between 25% and 41% of Texas' energy demand, depending on the month. But the boom has triggered a Texas-size showdown: Gov. Greg Abbott and a group of his fellow Republicans in the state legislature launched a campaign to prop up fossil fuels and penalize renewables, arguing it would make the grid more reliable. The high-stakes battle is a microcosm of how tricky America's green transition is shaping up to be, especially when politics are involved. The US is alreadylosing billions to deadly climate-fueled disastersthat scientists warn will get worse unless the world rapidly shifts away from fossil fuels. Yet there's still money and political points to be earned in oil and gas, indicating the fight is far from over. It's a bit ironic that two Republican governors and the state's conservative, pro-business bent.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A little black kitten had found an uncapped drainpipe and climbed his way down. He had no way out and was crying for help. Miraculously, after the nine-hour ordeal, the now named Armando was a little skinny, weak and infested with fleas, but otherwise healthy. Armando is now available for adoption at Petopia. If you're in the Los Angeles area Petopia is having a big adoption event Saturday October 12th, at the Westfield Promenade Mall in Woodland Hills. Stop by and say hi! text: Phil Quartararo was a record executive for five decades at A&M, RCA, Island, EMI, Warner Bros. and Virgin Records. He is credited for helping boost the success of U2, Paula Abdul and Spice Girls, among many others. He was executive producer of the eight-hour PBS miniseries,The Soundtrack of Our Lives. No information on survivors or memorial plans was immediately available. He died of pancreatic cancer in Los Angeles at the age of 67, according to a statement from his estate. He had been married for more than 30 years to his wife of 40 years, Mary Ann, and they had two daughters, Mary Anne and Mary Ann Q, as well as a son, Philip Q, who was also a record exec. The cause of death was not immediately known, but he died at a Los Angeles hospital, the statement said. No other details were immediately available on his death. The couple was married for about 40 years and have two daughters.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Arabian sand boa is a non-venomous snake that has the cutest eyes on top of its head. They help it to see when it's hiding the rest of its body under sand, waiting for its next meal to come along. These ridiculous looking creatures eat whatever lizards, insects, and small mammals they can catch and squeeze to death. Female sand boas lay their eggs in small clutches. They have to help their young break out from the eggs when they are ready to hatch, after roughly nine weeks. The hatchlings lack an egg-tooth — a sharp projection on the snout, which the young of other snake species use to crack open their eggshells. They are common throughout their wide range and are not thought to be threatened by human activities, according to theInternational Union for Conservation of Nature Red List of Threatened Species. They truly are thecutest snakes I've ever seen!" says wildlife educator Ben G. Thomas of Live Science.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Top-seeded teams Gonzaga and North Carolina prevail in a pair of thrilling finishes on Saturday. Gonzaga squandered a 14-point, second-half lead before holding on to edge South Carolina 77-73. North Carolina grabbed an offensive rebound after missing two free throws in the final seconds to beat Oregon 77-76. The NCAA tournament final will be held on Monday in Los Angeles. The Tar Heels are trying to make amends for losing last year’s championship on a buzz-beater by Villanova.“It's a dream to get (to the championship),” North Carolina coach Roy Williams told reporters. “Now we’ve got to play better but (Gonzaga) has been fantastic all year long. They only lost one game. It”s hard to imagine.” – North Carolina senior Kennedy Meeks, who finished with 25 points and 14 rebounds, including the final one that preserved their lead. The Gonzaga point guard Nigel Williams-Goss finished with 23 points, five rebounds and six assists in the earlier game, while South Carolina had a chance to tie the game while trailling 75-72 and taking possession with 12.7 seconds left but they did not get a shot away. The final score was 75-73 before Gonzaga’'s Killian Tillie grabbed the defensive rebound and was fouled. Tillie made two free shots with two seconds remaining to ensure victory. The game was played in San Diego.
label: SAFE

text: The nearly 6-year-old California mountain lion, dubbed P-23 by scientists tracking her, was the mother of two kittens. She's the 18th mountain lion to be killed in a road collision in the region since 2002. Los Angeles is one of only two major cities in the world, along with Mumbai, that have big cats living within the city limits. The death is the latest sign of the difficult battle for survival the big cats face in the Santa Monica and Santa Ana mountains of the Los Angeles area. Wildlife and environmental activists have been advocating for the construction of a wildlife crossing over U.S. 101, which would allow for safe, freer access throughout the area by big cats. The Liberty Canyon Wildlife Crossing would create a 200-foot-long, 165-footwide overpass bridging U.s. 101 west of Liberty Canyon Road in the city of Agoura Hills, but the mission has lagged due to a lack of funds. The center last month joined with the Sierra Club and the Mountain Lion Foundation in a lawsuit against the Altair housing development approved by theCity of Temecula in Southern California. The suit argues that the 200-acre development and a multi-lane highway would impede the only passage left in the area for wildlife to move between coastal and inland mountains. The Center for Biological Diversity and other groups support use of state funds for the project, which is under review by the California Department of Transportation, known as Caltrans. The other dominant male cougar in Santa Monica Mountains is P-27.
label: SENSITIVE

text: The Waste to Waves program aims to recycle styrofoam packaging back into new products. Polystyrene, the kind used for foam packaging, is banned in various cities. Twenty pounds of foam can be recycled into about five surfboard blanks. The program partners have been working hard to prove that the recycled boards perform just as well as those made with new EPS foam, enlisting professional surfers like Torrey Meister and Rob Machado to showcase the boards’ riding potential. The challenge now is to awaken the surf industry to the potential to radically green its practices."It’s really up to us, to ask your shaper to use these things and make your next surfboard a more sustainable one," says Sustainable Surf co-founder Michael Stewart. "The surfboard is also seen as one of the most toxic vehicles in action sports,” says Kevin Whilden, co- founder of Sustainable Surf. "We found that there's no degradation or loss of strength by going to the recycled material, which was the key part of making this successful," says Marko Foam co-owner Clay Peterson. "In the two years since the program's inception, Marko has sold 1,000 blanks to shapers and recycled over 40,000lbs of foam," Stewart says. "Waste to Waves has clearly tapped into an enthusiastic desire on the part of consumers to responsibly dispose of wasteful packaging," he adds. "Until demand meets supply, we are doing whatever we can to make sure foam packaging stays out of landfills and away from the ocean"
label: SAFE

text: Olive oil prices, driven in part by two years of drought inSpain, has meant opportunity for criminals. Warehouse break-ins, dilution of premium oil with inferior product, and falsification of shipping data are on the rise. Gangs using chainsaws to steal heavily laden branches and even entire trees from unguarded groves. The crimes mean fewer olives for growers already contending with high production costs and climate change. in Greece, a 1-liter bottle of extra virgin oil jumped from $8 to $9 last year to as much as $15 this year. in Spain, a company has developed tracking devices that look like olives to try and catch thieves. in Italy’s southern Puglia region, growers are pleading with police to form an agriculture division. in February, six people were arrested in southern Greece for the theft of 8 tons of olive oil in a series of warehouse break-in over several weeks. The global olive oil market has been disrupted by a nearly two-year drought in Spain. It's expected to shrink global production to 2.5 million metric tons this crop year.
label: SENSITIVE

The firm owned 2,265 shares of the company’s stock after selling 247 shares during the quarter. CTVA has been the subject of several recent research reports. Mizuho dropped their price target on Corteva from $72.00 to $71.00 and set a “buy” rating for the company in a research report on Tuesday, October 10th. UBS Group upgraded Corteva to a ‘buy’ rating in a report on Monday, August 7th. Barclays dropped theirprice target on corteva to $67.00 in aReport. Corteva has a 1-year low of $47.21 and a 1/year high of $68.16. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 1.12, a quick ratio of 0.99 and a current ratio of 2.02.
label: SAFE

text: The sponge was found in Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument, a World Heritage Site. It measured roughly 12 feet long, 7 feet tall and 5 feet wide -- about the size of a minivan. Previously, the largest documented sponge was one discovered in 1887 off the coast of western Canada. Some marine sponges have been estimated to live more than 2,300 years and attain massive sizes, scientists say."Finding such an enormous and presumably old sponge emphasizes how much can be learned from studying deep and pristine environments," a NOAA scientist says. in a report published this week in the journal Marine Biodiversity, the scientists say the discovery "underscores the need to protect this area using the highest conservation measures available" in this area.. The discovery, made last summer by a team of National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration scientists aboard the agency's 224-foot Okeanos Explorer, is documented in the report. The sponge was discovered at a depth of 7,000 feet, the report says. It was found northwest of the main Hawaiian Islands, but not nearly as tall or wide as the one found last year in less than 100 feet of water. That sponge was comparable in length to the one discovered last summer, it says. The recent discovery, they wrote, "underlights the need for the high conservation measures" in the area. "This area ... provides important habitat to a myriad of invertebrate and microbial species," they say.
label: SAFE

text: Shaun White posted a 98.50 on his second run to lead the qualifying into the men’s final of the halfpipe. “I started seeing everyone putting these great runs in and I figured I would step it up,” White told NBC Sports. The final will take place on Wednesday (Pyeongchang local time) The 31-year-old reacted, as expected, to the score. "I’m excited,’ he said. ‘This is what I've done my whole life.’ The two-time gold medalist was injured in a practice fall that left him with 62 stitches on his face last October. He was competing in his first Winter Olympics since Sochi 2014, where he failed to win a medal in the men's halfpipe and was eliminated from the Sochi Games in the quarterfinals. He is competing in the Winter Olympics for the first time since the 2010 Vancouver Games, when he won the gold in the slopestyle event. He has won two gold medals at the Winter Games, including in the 2006 and 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, Vancouver and in the 2010 Winter Games in Sochi, which he also failed to reach the final in the half-pipe. He will compete in his third Winter Olympics, after winning gold in 2010 and 2010 in the super-pipe and the 2014 slopetalpine event in the mogul event in Pyeonchang, South Korea, in the 2014 Winter Olympics.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Final night of the Royal Ballet's curious mixed bill that seems to have been programmed by the ancient dart-throwing method. George Balanchine's iconic The Four Temperaments set a high bar for the rest of the evening, followed by a much-anticipated new work by Hofesh Shechter. And a 65-minute closer, which violates the rules of programming evenings of dance - except that it's Kenneth MacMillan's Song of the Earth, set to the sublime Mahler song cycle, Das Lied von der Erde. Still, it was hard to take any of this seriously, when her date whispered "they're singing" in a Middle Eastern accent. Until she tuned in to the BBC election debate on Thursday and got a full dose of the right-wing politician's toxic fumes, I'm not sure what I'll do next. I've got a feeling it's going to be a very long night for me. I'm going to need to go home and sleep. I feel like I've been on a rollercoaster for the last few days. I can't wait to get back to the stage. I think I've had a bit of a crash landing. I just want to get off this stage and go home. I don't want to be here anymore. I want to go back to my bed. I need to get some sleep. It's been a long day. I have a lot of work to do, and I'm tired.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Energy consumption in Germany will fall to a record low this year, according to a forecast. The Working Group on Energy Balances expects a decline of just under eight percent to 10,784 petajoules. The consumption would be around scarcely 28 per cent under the past high of 14 905 Petajoule in the year 1990. To put this in perspective, 484 terawatt hours of electricity and 847 terawatts hours of natural gas were consumed in Germany in 2022, the Federal Network Agency says. The warmer weather compared with the previous year also had a consumption-reducing effect, the AG's calculations say.. A migration-related influx of 1.35 million people would lead to an increase in energy consumption of around 200 petaj Joules in 2023, it says. It adds that the continued high prices were expected to both drive savings but also lead to cutbacks in energy-intensive production. The AG says that demographic developments, on the other hand, are expected to have a Consumption-increasing effect.
label: SAFE

text: Chinese scientists have developed a new numerical model to simulate the atmospheric environment of Mars. Known as the Global Open Planetary atmospheric model for Mars (aka. GoMars), this model offers research support in preparation for the Tianwen-3 mission. This mission will be the third in the China National Space Administration's (CNSA) Tianwen program. It will consist of a pair of launches in 2028 that will return samples to Earth in July 2031. At present, ten robotic missions are exploring Mars' surface and atmosphere, including seven orbiters, two rovers, and one helicopter. And with many more destined for Mars in the next decade (as well as crewed missions), the demand for Martian weather forecasts is growing. In the end, dust can have a significant impact on the climate on the surface of Mars and can also affect operations, particularly on the landing phase of a mission. They can also be used to simulate dust activity before and after the rover's dormancy, which can provide possible data to analyze.
label: SAFE

text: Chris and Alexa Knierim helped the United States earn the bronze medal in the team skate Monday. Chris had a huge teddy bear and a “Will you (still) be mine?” heart ready as the couple met with the media. It’s been a busy and emotional Olympic Games for the couple, who started skating together in 2012 and got married in 2016. They were alternates for the 2014 Sochi games after Chris broke his tibia during the preceding season. But in 2016, tragedy struck again when Alexa suffered from a rare and life-threatening gastrointestinal condition. She needed several surgeries and dropped to 80 pounds, but she is now healthy and back on the ice with the U.S. figure skating team. The couple got to skate together on Valentine's Day as part of the figure skating pairs competition. They won another national title in January 2018, the couple helped the US earn the third-place medal in Monday's team skate. It was Chris' third Olympic medal, and Alexa's second. It's the first time they've won a medal in figure skating at the Winter Games, and they'll be competing in the men's singles event on Sunday. They also won a gold medal in 2010 and silver in 2010 at the Vancouver Games. They've won two gold medals in the pairs event at the 2010 Vancouver Games and one in the 2006 Vancouver Games in the 4x6-kilometer freestyle event. They have won a silver medal at the 2014 Winter Games in Vancouver.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Frances Arnold is the first woman ever to win the Millennium Technology Prize. Arnold, 59, won the prize for "her discoveries that launched a field known as directed evolution" "I hope that my getting this prize will highlight the fact that yes, women can do this, they can do it well," she says. Arnold: "Science is not for everyone; it takes a lot of time and devotion to become really good, and the same is true for engineering. You have to love it. Whether they choose to pursue science or engineering depends on how they feel about their whole life experience, perhaps more so than men. Opportunities today are excellent, but there are challenges to having a family and competing at the highest levels that women often feel more acutely," Arnold says."I did not choose to become a researcher until I was almost 30. I tried other careers, but science spoke to me more and more, especially after I started studying the biological world and all the amazing molecular machines made by nature," says Arnold. "I loved languages, I enjoyed economics, I spent every break traveling and seeing different cultures," she adds. 'I loved learning and did not think too much about the future until one day it happened,' she says of becoming a scientist. "There is a lot to be learned about directed evolution," Arnold adds. "It's a technology that allows us to reliably create improved proteins for a wide range of applications. ... We have already been using the enzymes in them to improve our lives for thousands of years, from bread, beer, wine, to laundry detergents"
label: SENSITIVE

text: Torrential rains have caused rivers to overflow their banks in Eastern Colorado. Emergency services are conducting water rescues and evacuating residents from low-lying areas. Swift water rescue teams are on standby to assist anyone trapped by rising waters. Additional rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. Emergency shelters have been opened and are providing hot meals and supplies. The National Weather Service warns that additional rainfall isexpected over thenext 24 hours, and flash flood warnings are in effect for Eastern Colorado and parts of New Mexico and southern Wyoming. text: Dr. Eduardo Rodriguez performed the most extensive face transplant operation ever. He removed the face and scalp of a young victim of a fatal accident and grafted the tissue onto the head of a firefighter. Rodriguez wants face transplantation to become the “standard of care for individuals in need.” But this will happen only if some major obstacles are overcome, he says, such as the high cost of these procedures and the reluctance of families to donate their loved ones’ faces to transplant patients. The face transplant cost an estimated $1 million, and the patient's recovery has been key to his recovery, Rodriguez says. The patient has called his doctor “one of a kind,” before adding, “He’s family to me” and “Simply put, Pat is a hero,’ Rodriguez says of the firefighter.“By sharing his story, he has given so much hope to those who need it, and has shown the true impact organ donation has had on himself and his family," the patient says in a message to the Huffington Post. The operation took place at New York University Langone Medical Center in New York, where Rodriguez is a dentist-turned-plastic-surgeon. It was the first face transplant in the U.S. since 1954, when surgeons at Brigham Hospital in Boston took a kidney from one man and gave it to his twin. It took 26 hours to graft the face onto Patrick Hardison, who had been horribly burned in a 2001 fire.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Serena Williams shared some of her greatest hits of 2017. They all feature her daughter, Alexis Olympia. The video gallery provides an adorable peek into the home life of Williams, husband Alexis Ohanian and their daughter. The year just wouldn’t have been complete without a clip of Williams saying “poopin’ time.“They were all so cute to me,” Williams wrote Sunday in the caption of the Instagram post. text: Since January 2020, the numbers of homeless veterans have fallen 11% and 55% over the past 13 years. Authorities credit the Obama administration’s work to make housing veterans a top priority. Advocates also point to partnerships between government agencies, nonprofits and corporate foundations. There are more than 33,000 homeless veterans, according to the 2022 Point-in-Time count conducted by the VA and Department of Housing and Urban Development, as well as the U.S. Interagency Council on Homelessness."If you’re homeless and you need help, you couldn’t ask for a better place to go because they take care of just about everything," says Harold Tilson Jr., a 68-year-old Vietnam War-era Army veteran who has been homeless for a few months. "We are proud to say that we are not a shelter. This is a program center, meaning the veteran has to put some skin in the game," says Tony Kimbrough, the VEO's CEO.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Dermestes undulatus beetle was found on the remote Flat Holm island. Scientists believe it could be the species' last stronghold in the UK. Based in the middle of the Bristol Channel, the island has no mains power or water. It is the first time the species has been recorded in Wales, and a sighting has not be recorded in England since 2020, said Cardiff council. It's possible the beetles were brought to the island by gulls carrying scavenged remains, said ecologists. The island is famous for its role in the invention of radio, as well as being home to unique lizards, flowers and birds. It has also acted as a sanctuary for Vikings, Anglo-Saxons, silver miners, smugglers and cholera victims, and is a site of special scientific interest (SSSI) due to its gull colony. The gull colony makes up 20% of the Wales' population of the bird of the same name, according to the Welsh Environment Agency.
label: SAFE

text: Pianist Conrad Tao and dancer-choreographer Caleb Teicher perform Bach and Gershwin. Bach and tap dancing might, on the surface, have nothing in common. But here, with ecstatic energy, the artists literally bring out the spirit of dance inherent in Bach's music. Presented with genuine delight, the performances left them exhausted and the audience gobsmacked. The Tiny Desk is hosted by Catie Dull and John Sutter. text: World's 940 million cows spew nearly 10 percent of all greenhouse gas emissions. Research shows that even a modest skew away from meat-based diets can shrink an individual’s carbon footprint as much as 75 percent. Achieving a cheeseburger-free America faces formidable challenges. According to a peer-reviewed study, an animal-free agricultural system would shave just 2.6 percent off the country”s total greenhouse gas emission. The U.S. industry, worth $275 billion annually, boasts the world’S fourth largest cattle population and is its top beef and dairy producer, according to a recent study by the University of California, Los Angeles. The study found that without livestock, the acreage now used to grow silage and hay could be replaced with food crops. In fact, agriculture’ current emissions are a result of a certain balance between crops and livestock, said Robin White, a professor of animal and poultry science at Virginia Tech and the lead author of the research.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A group of teenage boys spray-painted a historically black school with racist and anti-Semitic language and symbols. Judge Alex Rueda saw the act as a “teachable moment,’ and assigned the young men book and movie reports in lieu of community service or jail time. The assigned films include “Twelve Years a Slave” and “Lincoln’; the books include The Handmaid’s Tale, The Bluest Eye, To Kill a Mockingbird and Native Son. The American Library Association has started tracking hate crimes in libraries, including those situated in schools. The boys will also have to do a research paper on swastikas and attend a Holocaust Museum with their parents. The Southern Poverty Law Center says there has been a 42 percent increase in anti-Muslim groups since 2014, and a 14 percent rise in the total number of hate groups since the same year. But precisely how these crimes will be adjudicated is another matter; studies do show that people who read books are more empathetic, but whether that's causation or merely correlation is tough to control for. Regardless, versing teens in works by writers of color and women writers can only better their understanding of the world. The Orphan Master's Son and Colson Whitehead's The Underground Railroad, the latter of which won last year's National Book Award, were featured on the list, too. The list includes works by Adam Johnson, who wrote “The Handmaids Tale”
label: SENSITIVE

text: International funding for climate resilience in developing countries slumped in 2021. Public finance to developing countries fell 15 percent to around $21 billion. Overall annual funding that developing countries need to adapt to climate impacts this decade is projected to have increased to as much as $387 billion. World leaders meeting at this year's climate talks in the United Arab Emirates will face a tough reckoning over financial solidarity between rich polluters and vulnerable nations. The failure to cut emissions is already causing intensifying climate impacts, slamming communities and causing growing losses and damages, says the UN Environment Programme (UNEP), which released a report on the Adaptation Gap on Thursday. "Storms, fires, floods, drought and extreme temperatures are becoming more frequent and more ferocious, and they're on course to get far worse," said UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres in a statement. "Yet, as needs rise, action is stalling," he said. "Fossil fuel barons have helped create this mess; they must support those suffering," he added.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Mike Bartlett’s verse play King Charles III, which finished an extended run at Wyndham's Theatre in London this past January, stages a near-future crisis. Parliament has put forward a bill that will enable Whitehall to regulate the press. In deep distress, Charles pores over a copy of Walter Bagehot's The English Constitution (1867) Can the king use the royal prerogative to prevent the bill’S passage? Bage hot's Victorian-era judgments might help guide him. Click here to read the full play by Mike Bartlett, published by Public Books, priced £16.99. text: Earth set a new mark for how far above normal temperatures were in September. Last month’s average temperature was 0.93 degrees Celsius (1.7 degrees Fahrenheit) above the 1991-2020 average. That's the warmest margin above average for a month in 83 years of records kept by the European Space Agency. Earth is on track for its hottest year on record, about 1.4degree Celsius (2.5degree Fahrenheit) warmer than pre-industrial times, Copernicus says. The world agreed in 2015 to try to limit future warming to 1.5 degree Celsius ( 2.7 degree Fahrenheit) Since then, the world has seen more than 1.6 degrees Celsius of global warming, the agency says. "This month was, in my professional opinion as a climate scientist – absolutely gobsmackingly bananas,” one scientist said on X, formerly known as Twitter. “If you have more record hot events, there is no respite for humans and nature, no time to recover," another said.

text: Scientists created two human-pig embryos, then destroyed them after a few weeks of growth. The creations included human stem cells grown inside pig embryos. The scientists’ hope is that such recombinations could be used to grow replacement organs for humans. The possibility of growing human organs in pig embryos is still “far away,” researcher Juan Carlos Izpisua Belmonte says of the experiment in the journal Cell, in an article published Thursday. The U.S. suspended taxpayer funding for such animal-human combinations in 2015, and the Salk Institute is working on making human-friendly pancreases, hearts and livers in pigs. The vision raises huge ethical concerns, such as fears about an animal developing some human-like characteristics, a bioethics expert says. the work is “just a very early step toward the goal’s goal,’’ the researcher says. “Species evolve independently, and many factors dictating the developmental programs might have diverged, which makes it difficult to blend cells from one species to a developing embryo from another.’ “The larger the evolutionary distance, the more difficult for them to mix” Such combinations had been successfully created earlier with mice and rats, but larger animals like pigs would be needed to make human-sized organs, Dr. Jun Wu says. The animals would grow the organs in place of their own, and then would be euthanized before the organ is removed.

text: Bannister was the first man to run a mile in under four minutes. The record-breaking run was on the Oxford University track during a local athletics meeting. Bannister made headlines around the world at the age of 25. He later became one of Europe’s leading neurologists and was made a knight.. British Prime Minister Theresa May led the tributes to the former athlete, who later became a neurologist and a member of the Sports Advisory Council. He died peacefully in Oxford on 3 March, aged 88, surrounded by his family who were as loved by him, as he was loved by them, his family said in a statement. He was a shy, gangling medical student who preferred to be an oarsman rather than a runner. He stood 1.8 meters tall and weighed only 68 kilograms, but was told he was too light to make a first-rate oarman. He asked for his name to be withdrawn from a list of 1948 Olympic possibles and continued his careful preparations for the 1952 games. He managed only fourth place in the Helsinki Games 1,500 meters final. After Helsinki he became the forgotten man of athletics. But he had set his sights on the four-minute-mile — a challenge which had fascinated athletes and enthusiasts for years. He enlisted the aid of his training companions and friends Chris Chataway and Chris Brasher, top athletes in their own right, as pacemakers. He then pulled out from behind Chataway to immortalize himself as the sub-four-minute miler.

text: Matthew Lopez's unexpectedly sharp comedy The Legend of Georgia McBride is now at the Lortel. The play takes place in a redneck bar in Panama City, along the Gulf of Mexico and not far from the Alabama and Georgia borders. Wayne Duvall, Afton Williamson and Matt McGrath shine in the showiest roles, with the others offering equally fine portrayals. This is a very human comedy; Casey is sweet if not-too-bright, Jo is lovely, and the needless-to-say wisecracking Tracy has one of those hearts of gold. The performances are all winning, and Lopez ends his play on a heartwarming, family-friendly note."The Legend ofGeorgia McBride" is not so much a comedy about drag queens, but a comedy which incorporates characters who happen to be drag queens. The musical selections range from the usual suspects to Sondheim; a Sweeney Todd quote gets a large laugh, although that might just be on Christopher Street. It opened in January 2014 at the Denver Center Theatre Company, with McGrath in the cast. The show opened September 9, 2015 and continues through October 4, at the Lucille LORTel. It is directed by Mike Donahue, in what appears to be his first major New York job. Like past offerings such as Wit, reasons to be pretty, The Other Place and Hand to God, this one seems a likely prospect for extended life. . text: Patricia Lockwood’s upbringing was a perfect storm of oddities. Her father, a naval veteran, calls his daughter “Bit” and drinks Irish cream liqueur. Her mother, a colorful Irish Catholic matriarch with five children, frequently spouts bon mots grounded in paranoia. The book isn’t a lighthearted ode to her youth. She struggles with her father's ingrained misogyny, which he evinces with the confidence of a man who assumes that his audience agrees with his determination to have things all his own way. It is a memoir of growing up in a Catholic home, but also a love story of a young woman and her love for poetry and the city of Savannah, Savannah, Georgia, where she lived for some time in the early 1990s. It's also a look back on a childhood and young adulthood that took the place of a brewing storm in the young eye of a poet. The memoir, with its slightly off-color-seeming title, isn't a light-hearted Ode to Her Youth, but it does have its moments of lighthearted hilarity, as well as some dark moments, such as when Lockwood writes about being sexually assaulted by a boy she met on a dating website. It also has some darker moments, like when she writes about the time she was raped by a man she met online and how her parents reacted to the news of the incident. It was a memoir that can milk all the humor out of human absurdity in one passage.
label: SENSITIVE

text: A new theory suggests that the much-debated "Planet 9" isn't just a new member of our solar system, but rather an exoplanet. There is evidence that Planet 9 -- if it exists -- was kidnapped by the sun from its original host star. Earlier this year, researchers discovered the presence of a ninth planet by studying the orbits of icy objects beyond Neptune. They noticed anomalies in the objects' orbits and tracked them -- leading them to the gravitational pull of Planet 9.. The existence ofPlanet 9 is still unproved, and images have "remained elusive" But astronomers haven't been twiddling their thumbs. They have come up with a few hypotheses for what the planet may look like, but it's still not clear if this is just a theory or the real deal.. There's much more work to be done to figure out if this was just a Theory or the Real Deal. So, until we know for sure, we'll just keep thinking our solarsystem is a master thief, and that our sun may have stolen and captured Planet 9 from itsoriginal star.. "Planet9 may very well have been 'shoved' by other planets, and when it ended up in an orbit that was too wide around its own star," researcher Alexander Mustill said in a news release. "When the sun later departed from the stellar cluster in which it was born, Planet 9 was stuck in an orbits around the sun" The theory was developed by astronomers at Lund University in Sweden.
label: SAFE

text: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection is urging residents to kindly refrain from dumping used cooking grease directly down the kitchen sink drain. There are also numerous, thrift-minded ways to reuse cooking grease in the kitchen instead of tossing it in the trash, including party favors, dog hair conditioner, and even a can of Hasbrowns. "We've spent several million dollars a year on what we call degreasing. To give you some frame of reference, it costs about $20 a gallon for the degrease agent that we use, and we use sometimes as much as 20 or 30 gallons," says a DEP deputy commissioner. "That can impact the way the sewer works. In worst case conditions, it can sometimes lead to backups in homes,” he adds. "The grease problems will cause backages, backups in the sewers that will cause blockages," says the deputy commissioner, "which can sometimes cause problems for the city's sewer system. That can be very costly" The campaign will be available in Queens for the duration of this year's holiday season, which includes Hanukkah, Thanksgiving, and the New Year's Day holiday.

text: The system, called Kepler-385, was identified using data from NASA’s Kepler mission. The two planets closest to their host star are thought to be rocky and may have thin atmospheres. NASA says that there are more than 5,500 confirmed exoplanet beyond ourSolar system. The system is 4,670 light-years distant in the constellation Cygnus, the swan. text: Mangrove restoration project in southern Pakistan is one of the world's largest mangrove restoration projects. Project will cover an area nearly the size of Rhode Island. The mangroves were a buffer between the sea and local communities,muting the impact of storm surges during cyclones and heavy storms. The area was hit hard, because the mangroVE forests that once fringed this area had died away over the decades after successive Pakistani governments built dams upstream that deprived the delta of fresh water. It's a test case for restoration, and plantingMangroves at this scale might help the fight to curb planetary warming. text: Jane Austen’s Pride & Prejudice spends little time describing what one of its principal characters, Mr. Darcy, actually looks like. This hasn’t stopped readers from surmising or projecting their own favored attributes onto a character who at the beginning of the story seems priggish and by the end is cast as kind-hearted and reserved. A thorough study by John Sutherland at University College London suggests otherwise. According to Sutherland, Darcy “would be elegant rather than brawny.” Not a soldier but a gentleman, he’d likely have “sloped shoulders,” and no facial hair, but mid-length, powdered hair on his head. “It was all about the legs,’ Sutherland wrote in his “dramatic re-appraisal” of the character. ‘The six-pack was unknown.’ But don”t be too hasty in writing him off; prejudice has the power of interfering with what could otherwise be a lasting kinship, Sutherland said. The professor combined his knowledge of values of the period to ensure a complete dismissal of preteen readers’ romantic hopes and dreams. He wrote that Darcy would be elegant, not a soldier, and not a gentleman. The study was published in the Journal of English Literature and Science, published by the University of London, and is available on Amazon.com for $24.99. text: In the Eocene, greenhouse gas concentrations were much higher than they are today. Levels of methane, which is80 times as potenta planet-warmer as carbon dioxide, were especially high. Methane could have boosted warming at the poles by 7 degrees Celsius during the coldest winter months. The Arctic is today warming up tofour times fasterthan the rest of the planet due in part to gnarly feedback loops: Ice melts, which exposes darker water or land underneath, which heats up faster, which leads to more warming and more melting.“With the recent warming that's been going on in the Arctic, the observed temperatures are now much higher. than the models have predicted,” says ecologist Isla Myers-Smith of the University of British Columbia and the. University of Edinburgh, who wasn’t involved in the new research. “If we don't have projections—that are realistic—of the warming that’s coming, then we’re probably going to get our understanding of how the system is going to shift quite wrong”

Pro-hunting groups have found new ways to thwart the public's voice. Keep Michigan Wolves Protected is collecting signatures from registered Michigan voters to put the PA 21 referendum on the ballot alongside the one related to PA 520. The deadline to submit signatures is March 12th. If you live and vote in Michigan, I hope you'll consider adding your name to this cause. We all pay the price when animals are killed for sport, thrill, out of hatred, and for trophies -- which is what brought wolves to the brink of extinction in the first place. We need to stop the senseless hunting and trapping of wolves, and ensure that important issues about Michigan wildlife will still be influenced by the electoral voice of Michigan voters. The time is now to put up a fight to protect their lives. In the end, these wolves are not nearly the threat to humans as some of us humans are to our own humanity. The truth is deliberately obscured by individuals and institutions guided solely by self-interest and profit. When that happens, animals are not the only ones who pay thePrice of the wolf hunt -- we all do. The ASPCA's mission and programs at ASPCA.org are also available on Facebook and Twitter at: www.sapca.org/campaigns/keep-michigan-wolves-protected.

He recommends startups build products that generate business and cash flow now while working on those million-dollar ideas in the background of the company's future.. Accept that to win a war sometimes requires losing a battle, right? Sometimes, companies, too, must go for new products that aren't resonating with its customers, he writes. In order to create the successful business we have today, my co-founder and I had to revisit back-burner projects we were incredibly passionate about that we’ll revisit one day, rather than one day. And to successfully pairing growth with cash flow requires focusing on one day rather than the next.

Both men grew up on the metropolitan periphery: Joel in Hicksville, Long Island, and Springsteen in Freehold, N.J. But amid this growing affluence, both were also products of downward mobility, with Joel abandoned by his corporate executive father andSpringsteen’s grandfather, a lawyer, going to prison. text: Attenborough's long-beaked echidna was captured for the first time in photos and video footage using remote trail cameras set up in the Cyclops Mountains of Indonesia's Papua Province. Echidnas are notoriously difficult to find since they are nocturnal, live in burrows, and tend to be very shy. The species is one of only five remaining species of monotremes, the sole guardians of this remarkable branch of the tree of life. It is currently classified as Critically Endangered on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The expedition also made many other remarkable finds, including Mayr's honeyeater, a bird lost to science since 2008; an entirely new genus of tree-dwelling shrimp; countless new species of insects; and a previously unknown cave system. text: Last month smashed through the previous October temperature record, by a massive margin. The heat is a result of continued greenhouse gas emissions from human activity. The emergence this year of the El Nino weather pattern, which warms the surface waters in the eastern Pacific Ocean. This year is "virtually certain" to be the warmest in 125,000 years, European Union scientists say. The only other time before October a month breached the temperature record by such a large margin was in September 2023, the EU says. last month was the world's hottest October in that period, according to data from the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) The previous record was 2016, which went back to 1940. The average surface air temperature in October was 1.7 degrees Celsius warmer than the same month in 1850-1900, which the EU defines as the pre-industrial period, it says. "When we combine our data with the IPCC, then we can say that this is thewarmest year for the last 125,00 years," says C3S Deputy Director Samantha Burgess.

text: NASA's Curiosity Rover has successfully completed four thousand days on Mars conducting exciting science. text: A three-year drought that has left millions of people with little water wouldn't have happened without human-caused climate change. The west Asian drought, which started in July 2020, is mostly because hotter-than-normal temperatures are evaporating the little rainfall that fell. It’s a case of climate change unnaturally intensifying naturally dry conditions into a humanitarian crisis, the study says. The research has not yet undergone peer review but follows scientifically valid techniques to look for the fingerprints of global warming, the scientists say. The team looked at temperatures, rainfall and moisture levels and compared what happened in the last three years to multiple computer simulations of the conditions in a world without climate change, they say. the U.S. National Drought Mitigation Center in Nebraska, who was not part of the study, said the research made sense. Drought is not unusual to the Middle East region and conflict makes the area even more vulnerable to drought because of degraded infrastructure and weakened water management.

text: The last time the U.S. had such a coast-to-coast view of a total solar eclipse was almost 100 years ago. Radio waves, microwaves, infrared light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays are all different flavors of light. Most objects, including our own planet and celestial objects like the Moon, do not give off their own visible light. Instead, they reflect and absorb light from a source that does, such as our Sun or a light bulb. Without light, particularly that from our Sun, life as we know it would not exist. A solar eclipse like the one many in America will be able to experience that day provides an excellent opportunity to reflect (pun intended!) on the wonders of light and what it does for us. The authors of “Light: The Visible Spectrum and Beyond” published by Black Dog & Leventhal. Their latest book, “Magnitude: The Scale of the Universe” by the same publisher will be available on November 7, 2017. The average career in the NFL lasts just over 3 years, the lowest of any of the four main sports in the U.S. Jean Francois has become a starter while more than doubling the NFL career average. He also owns 25 Dunkin’ Donuts franchises throughout the South, and he still has plans to expand to Houston. “Business makes you open up as a person, because now you’re more well-rounded,’” Jean Francois says of his son, who looks at him as a “father figure.’ ‘My son looks at me as a father figure, and I want to be the right figure for him,” he says of the young man he has created for his father, who died in a car crash in 2011. ‘I have to be hands-on so I can see everything grow. I gotta learn how to do it myself,' he adds of his new business venture. 'I gotta make sure that I set the mindset of people in there to be happy is the most important thing,' says Jean Francois of his Dunkin' Donuts franchise. 'Football helped me mentally, because I had to get my mind right,' says the 6-foot-3, 313-pound defensive end of the Redskins’ Media Good Guy Award. 'It opened up another world I didn’t know existed,' he says.
label: SAFE

text: French researcher Gilles-Eric Seralini published a controversial study in September 2012. The study said rats fed GM corn suffered tumors and multiple organ failure. The European Food Safety Authority said the study had serious defects in design and methodology. Reed Elsevier's Food and Chemical Toxicology said the retraction was because the study's small sample size meant no definitive conclusions could be reached. The journal said its own investigation found "no evidence of fraud or intentional misrepresentation of the data" "The major flaws in this paper make its retraction the right thing to do," said one scientist. petition calling for the study to be released was signed by more than 700 scientists across the world in November 2012. "The strain of rats used is highly susceptible to tumors after 18 months with or without GMO (genetically modified organisms) in their diets," said Cathie Martin, a professor at John Innes Centre. "But at least this has now been remedied and the journal has recognized that no conclusions can be drawn from this study, so I suppose it is better late than never," she said. "Were FCT to persist in its decision to retract our study, CRIIGEN would attack with lawyers, including in the United States, to require financial compensation for the huge damage to our group," he said in a statement. "It is clear from even a superficial reading that this paper was not fit for publication," said a professor of the Public Understanding of Risk at the University of Cambridge.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Local authorities have opened 29 emergency shelters across the region. The Red Cross has deployed disaster response teams. Residents are urged to follow evacuation routes and seek shelter immediately. Emergency hotlines are available 24/7 for assistance. The National Hurricane Center reports sustained winds of 114 mph as the storm approaches the coastline. The storm is expected to strengthen to a Category 5 storm by Friday night, with sustained winds reaching up to 100 mph. The hurricane is expected not to make landfall in the United States until at least Saturday night, the National Weather Service says. It is not expected to make a direct hit on the U.S. East Coast until after the weekend, when it is expected the storm will weaken to a tropical storm. The Hurricane Center is not predicting a direct impact on the East Coast, but is warning that the storm could make landfall as early as Saturday night if it makes landfall in New Jersey or South Carolina. The weather service has issued a mandatory evacuation order for parts of the eastern coast of New Jersey and South Carolina, with the possibility of tropical storm-force winds as far north as New York City and Long Island. It has also issued a voluntary evacuation order in parts of New York and New Jersey for coastal areas. The evacuation orders are expected to be lifted in some areas on Sunday. The emergency hotlines have been set up for those who want to seek shelter in the event of a direct strike by the hurricane. They are available for 24-hour emergency assistance, and the Red Cross is available 24-hours a day, seven days a week.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Passengers on the Spirit of Discovery describe a state of fear on board the cruise ship after it was hit by a storm in the Bay of Biscay. About 100 people were injured when the ship veered dramatically during a safety manoeuvre on Saturday. Most of the injuries were described as minor by cruise company Saga, but five people were taken to hospital. The ship departed for a 14-day cruise around the Canary Islands on 24 October with about 1,000 people on board. A decision was made to return to the UK early due to worsening weather, but on Saturday the vessel encountered a storm. It was here that the ship's safety system kicked in, causing the vessel to veer suddenly to the left and effectively stop. One passenger said some of those on board "feared for their lives", while another said tables were flying and the waves were "throwing people around all up and down the place" Despite the ordeal, she said the staff were "absolutely fantastic" She and her husband disembarked on Tuesday and described seeing workers replacing glass doors, windows and partitions that had been smashed.

text: Larry Kwong was the first person of color to play in the National Hockey League. The Chinese-Canadian athlete was born in 1923, the year Canada passed the Chinese Immigration Act. The legislation essentially banned all forms of Chinese immigration and wasn’t repealed for more than two decades. Kwong played just one major league game with the New York Rangers on March 13, 1948, and battled racism and discrimination on his way to the NHL. The hockey player was inducted into the B.C. Hockey Hall of Fame in 2010 and the Vancouver Sports Hall of fame in 2013. He is survived by a sister, daughter and two grandchildren, and died this past Thursday in Calgary, Canada, at the age of 94, according to his family’s grocery business. He was the son of Chinese immigrants and grew up in Vernon, British Columbia, during a time of fierce anti-Chinese sentiment across the country. He played hockey to entertain the troops while also building minesweepers in the shipyard during World War II. He left the NHL at the end of the season but continued playing several successful years in the Quebec Senior Hockey League and later overseas. After his sports career, he returned to his grocery business, retiring in 1996 and retiring from the NHL in 2000. He had a daughter, a son, and a daughter-in-law, all of whom are still living in the U.S., as well as a grandson, who is in his early 20s and a granddaughter.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Researchers have discovered a massive coral reef in the muddy waters of the Amazon River. They believe the reef, which lies between 164 and 329 feet deep, covers about 5,900 square miles. Researchers have gathered more samples of the reef’s inhabitants since 2012, including brittle and basket stars, huge sponges and 73 different species of fish. The discovery comes in a week marked by devastating reports that 93 percent of the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia is nearly dead. However, the Amazon reef may also be in danger, particularly from industrial oil exploration, according to the University of Georgia oceanography and climate change professor Patricia Yager. "From ocean acidification and ocean warming to plans for offshore oil exploration right on top of these new discoveries, the whole system is at risk from human impacts,” Yager said. "We found a reef where the textbooks said there shouldn't be one," study co-author Fabiano Thompson told National Geographic. "It is a sponge. It is a coral. It's a reef,’’ Yager added. “We brought up the most amazing and colorful animals I had ever seen on an expedition," Yager says in a statement. "The two systems are intricately linked," she says of the relationship between the river movement and the reef. "In the far south, it gets more light exposure, so many of the animals are more typical reef corals and things that photosynthesize for food," she adds.
label: SENSITIVE

text: U.S.-born scientists Jeffrey Hall, Michael Rosbash and Michael Young win the 2017 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine. Discovery of molecular mechanisms controlling our biological clocks helps explain jet lag. Nobel Medicine is the first of the Nobel Prizes awarded each year. The prizes for achievements in science, literature and peace were created in accordance with the will of dynamite inventor and businessman Alfred Nobel. The prize has not been without controversy, especially with the benefit of hindsight, such as with 1948 award for the discovery of DDT, a chemical that helped battle epidemics but was later banned due to its harmful environmental impact. the prize of 9 million Swedish crowns ($1.1 million) was awarded to the laureates, who used fruit flies to isolate a gene that controls the normal daily biological rhythm and showed how this gene encoded a protein that accumulates in the cell during the night and degrades during the day. The clock regulates critical functions such as behavior, hormone levels, sleep, body temperature and metabolism, the Nobel Assembly said on awarding the prize. The Nobel Committee described the reaction of Rosbash when first informed of the award: “He was silent and then he said ‘you are kidding me’”“(The three scientists’) discoveries explain how plants, animals and humans adapt their biological rhythm so that it is synchronized with the Earth’s revolutions,” the assembly said in a statement, adding that the prize was for medicine.

text: Out of about850 speciesfound in Australia, 45% are "endemic", which means they're unique to Australia. The only other country withmore endemic speciesis Indonesia. So why is it that such a high proportion of Australian birds aren't found anywhere else?Climate rules. 45 million years ago, when Australia first split from Antarctica and started to head north. It was the events that occurred during this trip that led to the diversity in Australia's birds today. When it first set out, Australia was covered in lush rainforest. As it drifted, however, the climate became much drier. Our distinctive flora of grasslands and eucalypt woodlands started to spread across the continent. Every time the climate dried, birds that preferred forests were pushed to the damper margins of the continent, where they evolved into separate species. And if you can cope with temperatures that vary from -10°C to more than 40°C, you can. cope with El Niño next week.
label: SAFE

text: The U.S. women’s Olympic hockey team eked out a victory over Canada after a tie score forced the game into a thrilling overtime. The Canada team had been ahead 2-1 towards the end of the third period when American player Monique Lamoureux-Morando scored on a breakaway. The game went into a 20-minute overtime, during which no players from either team scored thanks to quick reflexes from Canada goalie Shannon Szabados. Then, the five round shootout also ended in a tie. Finally, in the first extra round of shootouts, American Jocelyne LamouReux-Davidson scored one over her Canadian rival, giving the team its first Olympic gold since the women's competition debuted in 1998. The Canadian team had won it every year since then. You can watch some of the highlights of the nail-biter game here. text: Indexed Variable Annuities (IVAs) are designed to provide a balanced approach, offering exposure to market index gains while mitigating downside risk. IVAs deserve a look from pre-retirees and those early in retirement for their unique way of helping offer investors a blend of market participation and risk reduction tailored to their needs. Incorporating IVAs into retirement portfolios is now a prudent strategy in a continually evolving financial landscape. These annuities offer a unique blend of. market-linked growth and protective features, aligning retirement needs with those. of those navigating the market- linked growth and protecting needs of those. navigating the retirement landscape. They allow a retiree to structure their returns to match the challenge of low return markets and help them face the challenges of sequence of return risk. They also offer a stable or higher return if the market experiences minimal growth. This feature can help protect against low returns which is another risk for retirees. If the market goes down, they still have the buffer. This dual mechanism provides a structured approach to investment, where potential losses are cushioned.
