text: 25,000 bumblebees fell out of trees in an Oregon parking lot last month. Pesticides were immediately blamed, but a new study suggests the problem is more complex. The European Union recently passed a ban on neonicotinoids, which are linked to Colony Collapse Disorder. The U.S. has issued a temporary ban on the pesticides, but nothing as broad as the European law is being considered nationally. But outlawing a single class of pesticides won’t solve CCD, the study's lead author says, but it may help engender a more nuanced, effective solution. It has previously been believed that fungicides did not pose a risk to honey bees, but the Maryland and USDA scientists “found an increased probability” of bees being infected by the gut pathogen Nosema ceranae when exposed to high levels of fungicides. The fungal disease can “adversely affect honey bee colony health, and can result in complete colony collapse.” If the U.N. had banned neonicsotinoids along with the E.U., there might be 25,000 more bumble bees in Oregon. But the study hasn't identified any smoking gun either, but by offering proof that the issue is exceedingly complex, it may offer a way to reduce the number of bees that die from CCD in the first place. It’s a lot more complicated than just one product, which means of course the solution does not lie in just banning one class of product.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Report: Brussels may not initiate formal membership talks with Kiev at next month's summit. Some EU leaders have proposed to take up the topic at the March summit. Hungary could potentially block the consensus required to open talks, but the problem goes beyond Budapest. “We cannot allow Ukraine to go bankrupt, it’s not an option for us. But it's not easy,” an unnamed senior EU official told Reuters. ‘Maybe we have had too high expectations,’ the official told the agency, adding: “How do we pay for this?��” The proposal to commit an additional 50 billion euros ($54 billion) to Ukraine through 2027 has reportedly been criticized“from several sides,“and not just by Hungary, the official said. The US has proposed reducing the amount of economic aid – money used to pay government salaries – to Kiev by $275 million a month, with the expectation that the EU, Canada, and Japan would pick up the slack.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Officials in tennis are defending their decision during a crucial moment in yesterday's International Competition. The call in question determined the outcome of the game, and replay footage shows the ruling was marginal. League officials emphasize that referees make split-second decisions in high-pressure situations. Discussion has turned to whether instant replay review should be expanded. The officiating crew will meet with supervisors to review the call and discuss proper protocol. text: AirBoss of America Corp. (TSE:BOS) announced a quarterly dividend on Wednesday, November 8th. Shareholders of record on Friday, December 29th will be paid a dividend of 0.07 per share on Monday, January 15th. This represents a $0.28 annualized dividend and a yield of 7.18%. The ex-dividend date of this dividend is Thursday, December 28th. Shares of TSE BOS remained flat at C$3.90 during trading on Friday. The stock has a market capitalization of C$105.81 million, a price-to-earnings ratio of -550.53 and a beta of 1.98. The company has a current ratio of 2.44, a quick ratio of1.07 and a debt- to-equity ratio of 66.67. AirBoss of. America has a 52-week low of C $3.66 and a52-week high ofC$11.41.

text: Scientists from Cornell University and Purdue University have identified a previously undiscovered mechanism triggered by calcium when it's added to soil. Their finding could lead to more strategic use of the mineral in agriculture. Soils with higher amounts of organic carbon are also able to deliver nutrients more efficiently to plants and promote plant growth, says lead researcher Itamar Shabtai, an assistant scientist with the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station. "If we can increase carbon in soil, we can perhaps make a dent in the increase in atmospheric CO2that we're seeing," says ShabTai. The researchers used the Canadian Light Source at the University of Saskatchewan to measure the amount of plant matter decomposed following the addition of calcium, while the Mid-IR beamline enabled them to identify and quantify the stabilized carbon in the soil. The findings can potentially benefit agricultural producers by giving them another tool to help maintain and improve the organic matter in their soils. "Now that we have a better understanding of how calcium can impact how microbes improve soil carbon, we may be able to use soil amendments that contain calcium in a way that can benefitsoilorganic matter," says researcher Shab tai.
label: SAFE

text: Wayne Brady is currently starring in the Chicago production of “Hamilton.” He says it’s more important than ever to support arts programming and initiatives. “I’m a trumpeter for the rights of all of us, especially being a black man in this country,” he said. Brady is no stranger to theater, having previously starred on Broadway in “Chicago” and “Kinky Boots.“Go out, support the arts, [support] the things that he [Trump] is killing,’’ he said of the president. ‘Hamilton’ resonates with what it means to be an American, Brady said, “like the line, ‘Immigrants, we get the job done.’ My folks are from the Virgin Islands, just like [Alexander] Hamilton. It”s inspirational to know that this little chain of islands can produce such greatness” Brady stars in ”Hamilton” at Chicago’S PrivateBank Theatre through April 9. The musical is a Tony Award-winning production of Lin-Manuel Miranda's “The Color Purple” The show is set to open on Broadway on November 14. It will be directed by Michael Aronofsky, who previously directed “South of the Border” in the U.S. and ‘The Color of Love’ in the UK, among other things. For more information, go to www.Hamilton.org.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Two Just Stop Oil activists have been arrested for criminal damage, police say. They broke the glass protecting Diego Velázquez’s 17th-century “Rokeby Venus” The painting is known for having been damaged in an act of protest by suffragette Mary Raleigh Richardson in 1914. The National Gallery said on X that the room was cleared of visitors and police were called. The protest group said more than 100 people were marching in the area before the police began to arrest them, the Met posted to X. of the Metropolitan Police tweeted: “Within 15 minutes we have arrested at least 40 activists who were slow marching,” the Met said. “Whitehall is now clear. We will provide updates on arrest figures in due course.’“The painting is now being removed from display so it can be examined by conservators,’ the National Gallery added in a post on X. The activist group has also disrupted several major sporting events in England this year.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Austrian skier Matthias Mayer also sent at least one member of the media flying when he crashed out of the slalom leg of the men’s alpine combined downhill event on Tuesday. Both he and the unidentified media member appeared uninjured following Tuesday's incident. Mayer won gold in the men's downhill event at the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia. He will defend his title on Thursday. Fellow Austrian, Marcel Hirscher, snagged the gold medal in the event. France's Alexis Pinturault and Victor Muffat-Jeandet secured silver and bronze, respectively. The men's alpine Combined downhill event is scheduled to take place on Thursday in Pyeongchang, South Korea. It will be the first time the event has been held in the South Korean capital since the opening ceremony of the 2010 Winter Olympics. The event will also be the second time the Winter Olympics have taken place in South Korea after it was held in Vancouver in 2010. The last time was in 1998, when it took place in the Winter Games in the village of Whistler, Canada. It was the first Winter Olympics to be held in South Korean soil since the games began in 1998. The U.S. has been the only country to have hosted the event since it began in 2002, and it is the third time in the history of the Winter Olympic Games that it has done so. It is also the only time it has taken place at the Olympics.
label: SAFE

text: Elon Musk's Neuralink received approval for human trials in May. Thousands of people are lining up for the opportunity, according to a report. The plot of the 2015 spy caper "Kingsman: The Secret Service" features a similar neural implant as a key plot point. Musk is certainly not a believer in depopulation, and has frequently stated his belief that the planet needs more people on it, not less. And Musk won't look to ape Jackson's fictional Valentine by controlling people's minds with Neuralink's chips, becausebrain-computer interfacesdon't actually allow that. Instead, the brain controls the computer, and its possible applications for those with diseases like ALS could be significant. The film, which grossed over $400 million worldwide, came out two years before Neuralink was founded — though it seems unlikely Musk took any inspiration from a mid-budget action movie for his plans. The two also differ in cutting the world's population, with Musk not believing in it.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Former San Francisco quarterback Colin Kaepernick will win and lose with the collusion grievance he’s filed against the NFL. The odds that he can actually prove that two or more owners got together exchanged texts, emails or left some paper trail in which they agreed that they’d do everything they could to make sure he never suited up again on their team or any other NFL team is slim to none. Still, it does not meet the sky-high bar to prove collusion but it reinforces what many in the sports world, many NFL players, and many in surveys and polls have said about him. The grievance is a public relations coup that no amount of money could buy. The complaint forced the NFL to scramble and issue pious statement after pious statement that it respects individual freedoms, including the right of players to protest. It challenges the owners to do more than pay lip service to backing social justice causes and the fight against racial injustice. It forced NFL commissioner Roger Goodell to swiftly squash media speculation that the NFL owners at their scheduled meeting would clamp down on the player's anthem protests by making it mandatory that they stand at rapt attention during the playing of the anthem. It stiffens the sternum of the NFL players association in their coming contract talks with NFL owners about pay, revenue sharing, health benefits, with special emphasis on the concussion issue. This is all great for the players and their association. It's great for Kap in that he could claim much of the credit for shaking up the league, much ofThe sports establishment, and even causing a significant number of NFL and sports fans to think hard about police abuse and racial injustice in society.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Bill Murray's latest work, "New Worlds," is actually a classical music project. Murray sings songs like Stephen Foster’s “Jeanie with the Light Brown Hair” and tunes from “West Side Story.” He also reads Walt Whitman and Ernest Hemingway while cellist Jan Vogler”s trio plays Schubert, Bach and Piazzolla. “New Worlds” will premiere at Festival Napa Valley in California on July 20. The actor, in typical fashion, outlines his performance style modestly, and abstractly, in a New York Times profile. He said, “The demand is so great that if you are attending to who you are right now, it brings out something that you couldn’t have visualized or planned for.’ It’ll be epic. We can’ve wait for Jonathan Schwartz’S take on the whole thing. He’d like it to be epic, too. It will be at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 16, and there will be a recording release in August. He says his voice is “a brassy growl” The actor says he has a “brassy voice’ and “that B flat is not going to break a light bulb’ But they’re receding,” he says. ‘That B flat’’ is ‘not going to breaking a light bulbs’

text: French president Emmanuel Macron says melting glaciers are an "unprecedented challenge for humanity" Melting ice surfaces worldwide have an impact on biodiversity, rising sea levels and coastlines. Melting glaciers contribute to scarcity of drinking water, migration, greater release of CO2 and risk of a new pandemic. Heads of states, governments and diplomats from about 40 states are attending the summit in Paris, including China. Russia has not been invited, even though the country is an Arctic neighbour, according to the summit's organizers. is an annual event involving governments, nongovernmental groups and others seeking dialogue around global problems such as climate change, children's exposure to online violence and threats to human rights. In mountains from the Alps to the Himalayas, glaciers are disappearing at alarming rates due to warming temperatures, with many predicted to disappear entirely by the end of the century. The frozen Antarctic has also seen dramatic ice sheet melt, disappearing glaciers and unusually high temperatures as the world heats up, scientists say.

text: World powers are running out of time to slash their use of high-polluting fossil fuels, draft says. U.N. promises to limit global warming to less than 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 Fahrenheit) Temperatures have already risen by about 0.8 C (1.4F) since 1900. Draft estimates needed shift to low-carbon energies would cost between two and six percent of world output by 2050, it says. It says nations will have to impose drastic curbs on their still rising greenhouse gas emissions to keep a promise made by almost 200 countries in 2010 to keep global warming below 2 degrees C. The draft outlines ways to cut emissions and boost low- carbon energy, which includes renewables such as wind, hydro- and solar power, nuclear power and "clean" fossil fuels. "The window is shutting very rapidly on the 2 degrees target," said Johan Rockstrom, head of the Stockholm Resilience Centre, and an expert on risks to the planet from heatwaves, floods, droughts and rising seas. Another report by the IPCC last week in Japan showed warming already affects every continent and would damage food and water supplies and slow economic growth. The report raised the probability that human actions are the main cause of climate change since 1950 to at least 95 percent from at least 90 percent from 1950. But polls show voters are unpuaded, with many believing that natural variations are themain cause of the change in the climate and that humans are the cause.
label: SENSITIVE

text: Goliath Resources Limited (TSX-V: GOT) (OTCQB: GOTRF) (FSE: B4IF) is pleased to report assay results for 10 new drill holes from the Surebet Discovery at its 100% controlled Golddigger Property (the “Property”), Golden Triangle, British Columbia. All 10 holes intersected broad intervals of significant quartz-sulphide mineralization and widespread Visible Gold occurrences. The mineralization in hole GD-23-170 consists of 9.40 g/t AuEq (9.33 g/ t Au and 3.98 g/T Ag) over 7.00 meters. Assays are pending on 100 holes drilled on the Golddiger property in 2023. The gold-mineralization is associated with veins hosted in heavily altered siltstone sandstone characterized by strong silicification and chloritization. Several veins containing specks of Visible. Gold have been identified within the reported mineralized interval.

text: The Golden State Warriors have a postseason best 96.9 defensive rating. They have also outscored opponents by 16.5 points per game, one of the best marks ever compiled. Draymond Green is the linchpin of it all, a finely tuned Swiss army knife. With Green as dominant defensively as he’s ever been, the real boon to the Warriors has been Kevin Durant, who is one of today's most versatile defensive weapons, writes Jordan Schultz-Schultz.-schultz- Schultz- Schultz: The Warriors don’t simply guard teams, they overwhelm them; suffocate them, even. To hamstring an NBA opponent is a tall task. It requires all five players’ commitment. How many guys can switch ball screens? How many wing players can guard the low post? HowMany can protect the rim? Interchangeable pieces and versatility are crucial. This year, he averaged a career-best 1.6 blocks per game while holding opponents to 44.8 percent shooting, per NBA.com. The Warriors’ defensive guru, Ron Butler, called Green “a great helper, very good at making difficult passes’ He added: “He’ll soon earn his third straight First-Team All-NBA Defense selection.’’ The Warriors have won eight games this postseason, all wins, and are up 2-0 in the second round against the Utah Jazz. The Dubs have won six of their last seven games against the Jazz.
label: SAFE
